fields.headline: Lancashire target Tendulkar the Tyke
fields.trailText: Sachin Tendulkar, the first overseas player to bat for Yorkshire, may become one of a select few to wear both the white and the red rose if Lancashire sign the 26-year-old India captain for next season.
fields.body:
Sachin Tendulkar, the first overseas player to bat for Yorkshire, may become one of a select few to wear both the white and the red rose if Lancashire sign the 26-year-old India captain for next season.

Lancashire want Tendulkar as their overseas player as Muttiah Muralitharan, who took 66 wickets in six championship games in 1999, has been ruled out because of commitments with Sri Lanka.

Tendulkar struggled to adjust to life in the north of England in 1992, and the image of him huddled at slip under several Yorkshire jumpers is an enduring one. But he is ranked the world's best batsman and infinitely more experienced now.

Lancashire are also considering his India team-mates Saurav Ganguly and Javagal Srinath, as well as Australia's Ricky Ponting, and will decide next Monday.

Meanwhile, accusations by the Pakistan all-rounder Abdur Razzaq that Tendulkar tampered with the ball during Pakistan's 48-run defeat by India in their one-day match in Adelaide on Tuesday have been dismissed as "frivolous and without foundation" by the match referee Cammie Smith.

"The umpires had no problem with the condition of the ball," said Smith, who also "dismissed for lack of proper evidence" charges that the India pace bowler Venkatesh Prasad called Pakistan's Azhar Mahmood "nasty names" and swore at Yousuf Youhanna.

Smith, however, pulled up India's Debashish Mohanty for deliberately standing outside the 30-yard fielding circle, contrary to match conditions.

Yesterday in Adelaide Mark Waugh hammered 116 as Australia cruised to a 152-run victory over India to all but eliminate their opponents from the triangular series. Australia scored 329 for five, the highest in limited-overs internationals in Australia and the second highest by an Australian team anywhere.

fields.headline: Early shock for England
fields.trailText: The England women's team, recently arrived for a one-day series against Australia and New Zealand, were soundly beaten by five wickets by a New South Wales XI yesterday.
fields.body:
The England women's team, recently arrived for a one-day series against Australia and New Zealand, were soundly beaten by five wickets by a New South Wales XI in the suburb of Parramatta yesterday.

But it is not all doom and gloom. The 14-strong squad have had only a few hours in the nets since their arrival and met a side containing four Australia internationals.

So England were happy to reflect on a mature show of left-arm spin from the 20-year-old Dawn Holden, who plays for Thrumpton in the east midlands. Holden took four for 31 in her 10 overs to stop New South Wales, chasing a meagre target of 105, claiming a demoralising 10-wicket win.

"I hadn't bowled in the middle since September," Holden said, "while their players are all in the middle of their season. They won the toss on a damp pitch, so it was vital to bowl tight. They thump anything short, but I was pleased with the way it went."

webTitle: Atherton in dock for county attack

fields.headline: Atherton in dock for county attack
fields.standfirst: Lord's hits back at the former captain's dismissal of England's first-class game
fields.trailText: Mike Atherton may face disciplinary action from the England and Wales Cricket Board for his attack on county cricket.
fields.body:
Mike Atherton may face disciplinary action from the England and Wales Cricket Board for his attack on county cricket.

England's former captain had suggested that the domestic game was attractive to neither sponsors nor spectators, failed to prepare players for the rigours of international cricket and as such was "living on borrowed time".

A very sensitive nerve was touched. The ECB chief executive Tim Lamb delivered a strong riposte yesterday, saying that Atherton's remarks, made during a radio interview, were "potentially damaging" and had shocked the new championship sponsors PPP Healthcare.

He would not confirm whether Atherton faced censure but it would be odd, in view of the official reaction to his trenchant but heartfelt opinions, if he were not brought to book.

"It seems to me completely inappropriate for Mike to prejudge and write off a new format before it has even started," said Lamb. "We are more than disappointed and would firmly rebut his comments.

"He seems to show commercial naivety and fails to understand that comments by a former England captain attacking the game are potentially damaging. I have been in contact with our sponsors to reassure them that his views are not those of the ECB. Players must understand the responsibility they are under."

The board is particularly sensitive because it is finding sponsorship hard to come by. There is no sponsor, for example, for this summer's triangular one-day international tournament, and talks are still under way to replace Cornhill, which recently announced the end of its long-standing sponsorship of home Test series.

In fact there are many who agree with Atherton that county cricket, even in its two-division form, which after all will still be of the same poor standard overall regardless of how "competitive" it is, does indeed not provide adequate grounding for the step up to international level. A regional competition, with talent concentrated and players examined more stringently, would be the alternative.

"I do not have an argument in defence of county cricket," said Atherton, recently returned from South Africa where England lost yet another Test series. He added that nothing would change fundamentally while the counties themselves had control of the game.

Lamb disagreed. "Any suggestion that we should be doing away with any counties would be counter-productive and would not serve the wider interest of English cricket. A two-division championship will go a long way towards improving the competitiveness of the domestic game and it deserves a chance to work before being written off.

"But the raison d'etre of the counties extends beyond just putting out competitive teams. They are the centres of excellence and focus of interest in their respective regions."

Of the lack of spectators, Lamb said: "It is unrealistic to expect huge crowds midweek because of people's lifestyles. But the four-day game is followed round the world via newspapers, text and internet. What we have to do is make what we have better. We have a vision of the future and we're working towards it."

webTitle: Valiant England come up short by one run

fields.headline: Valiant England come up short by one run
fields.standfirst:
South Africa 204-7
England 203-9
South Africa won by one run
fields.trailText: England have played with such zest in the past 10 days that it is perhaps just as well they faltered last night: another success here and they might have been tested for performance-enhancing biltong.
fields.body:
England have played with such zest in the past 10 days that it is perhaps just as well they faltered last night: another success here and they might have been tested for performance-enhancing biltong.

Asked to score an apparently modest 205 to beat South Africa for the second time in four days, they failed by the narrowest margin, one run, after Mark Ealham and Chris Read put on 39 in four overs.

"We left ourselves a little too much to do," Nasser Hussain said afterwards. "The difference was South Africa's fielding and bowling."

England looked out of it when they needed 25 from the last two overs with their top seven batsmen back in the pavilion. But the penultimate over, bowled by Shaun Pollock, yielded 16 runs. Read hit him to cow corner for six and there was also a four in his unbeaten 23-ball 26.

Nine were needed from the last over, which boiled down to four from the last ball with the last man Darren Gough on strike; he managed only a frenetic two.

As in the Test series, England were betrayed by a lack of batting experience. Even when Mark Alleyne was fifth out at 121 they still needed only 84 from 16 overs; then 72 from 12.

The situation cried out not for a dose of the long handle but for a piece of acquisitive batting as practised by Graham Thorpe or Neil Fairbrother.

It may sound a little hollow-headed to cast one's sentimental eyes back to England's World Cup non-heroes. But the crassness of the decision to send Alec Stewart home after the Test series was always likely to embarrass this tour management and last night, under the Newlands floodlights, their folly was exposed as brightly as a clown's red nose.

The dismissal of their two key one-day batsmen, Graeme Hick and Nick Knight, in the space of three balls left England with a Table Mountain to climb. They were taken halfway up by Chris Adams (42) after Vikram Solanki, Alleyne and Craig White, to an outstanding catch by Jonty Rhodes, had all failed, but the tail was left with a fraction too much to do.

When South Africa were restricted to 204 for seven there was considerable optimism, even celebration, among the many tightly packed bands of England supporters.

In fact the home side had achieved slightly better than par on this peculiarly low-scoring ground, where the texture of the grass tugs at the ball as if the outfield was under water.

In the 11 one-day internationals South Africa have played at this arena the average first-innings score is 201 and the highest score of 245 looks modest by the contemporary standards of the limited-over game. The highest winning second-innings score here is 229, with 185 next. Moreover, the side batting first here under lights had won five times out of seven.

England had made one change from the side that opened this series in Bloemfontein on Sunday, Alleyne re placing Graeme Swann. South Africa made three changes, with Rhodes, Nantie Hayward and the seamer Henry Williams replacing Dale Benkenstein, Nicky Boje and David Terbrugge.

South Africa are still rather sulkily ruminating on their failure to win last summer's World Cup. They naturally want to win this series but their main aim is to try out players in order to build for the two one-day series against Australia in April and August and, beyond that, the 2003 World Cup.

In the field England, for the most part, matched the excellent standard they had set at Goodyear Park. They bowled well and, apart from a couple of ghastly lapses from Solanki of all people, fielded with the same elan.

The most successful bowler was Gough, who with figures of three for 36 pulled level with Phil DeFreitas on 115 wickets in one-day internationals. It is a record he covets. Only Ian Botham (145) stands ahead of him.

Gough broke through in the seventh over when he had Gary Kirsten lbw with one that straightened. In his next over he had Herschelle Gibbs caught-and-bowled from a leading edge. South Africa, 32 for two in the ninth, were never able to bring momentum to their innings after that.

Jacques Kallis threatened to, especially when he strode down the wicket in Ealham's first over and lifted him over long-off for six.

Rhodes chipped White to mid-on, Ealham got his revenge on Kallis with a direct-hit run-out from mid-on, and Hansie Cronje was caught behind attempting to run Gough down to third man.

With Lance Klusener no innings is a write-off, but here even he found fluent striking a stranger. His unbeaten 42 from 48 deliveries was unremarkable by his standards. In fact, there were only nine fours and two sixes in the entire South Africa innings.

fields.headline: Tranmere make final offer
fields.trailText: The dream has become a reality for Tranmere Rovers even if they are still pinching themselves.
fields.body:
The dream has become a reality for Tranmere Rovers even if they are still pinching themselves.

John Aldridge's gallant side will carry the hopes of Merseyside to Wembley in the Worthington Cup final after contemptuously dismissing the tepid challenge of Bolton Wanderers here last night.

The unfashionable Wirral side almost preposterously stand within tantalising reach of a place in Europe and their previous excursions against top flight opposition this season indicate that neither Leicester City nor Aston Villa will induce much fear come February 27.

For now, however, they can be forgiven for enjoying the present rather than the future. After all, 114 years is a long time to harbour an inferiority complex in the shadows of Liverpool and Everton. How their illustrious neighbours must be green with envy this morning.

Tranmere had more than a 1-0 lead to preserve but also their improbable status as the team of the moment on Merseyside. Having accounted for four Premiership teams already this season, they richly deserved to emerge with a more commanding advantage from a one-sided encounter at the Reebok Stadium two weeks ago.

Since then, both clubs have indulged in an undignified spat of mudslinging and the buzz of expectancy last night was matched by the acrimony hanging thick in the air.

John Aldridge fielded four changes from the first leg but, crucially, Dave Challinor had recovered from an ankle ligament injury. The man with the world-record throw-in provides a supply line as valuable to Tranmere as anything conjured up by David Beckham at Manchester United.

His first throw left Bolton's goalkeeper Steve Banks grasping at thin air inside the six-yard area and so the precedent was set.

The next missile was headed half away and Nick Henry was there 25 yards from goal to lash a sumptuous left-foot volley into the top left-hand corner of Banks's goal. It was a strike comparable to his FA Cup winner against West Ham United, only probably better.

After 20 minutes the euphoria had turned to delirium and Aldridge was charging down the touchline like Basil Fawlty. Scott Taylor, a one-time Bolton player, totally flummoxed Mike Whitlow before being dragged to the ground by his former colleague. It was as clear a penalty as they come and Alan Mahon, having shown off his aim with a spectacular 30-yarder against the crossbar ten minutes earlier, would have been embarrassed to miss from 12 yards.

With three goals to find Bolton had little option but to adopt a more positive attitude in the second 45 minutes but Sam Allardyce's team were finding cul-de-sacs and Banks remained the busier goalkeeper. His finest moment arrived on the hour with a point-blank save to deny Taylor from adding insult to injury.

By then, however, victory was something of a foregone conclusion. The public announcer was requesting that Tranmere's fans refrained from celebrating on the pitch after the final whistle and David Kelly capped the finest moment in their history 20 minutes from time with a left-foot shot in off the post.

webTitle: Liverpool ready to gamble with Ravanelli

fields.headline: Liverpool ready to gamble with Ravanelli
fields.trailText: Fabrizio Ravanelli is poised for an improbable return to English football in a four-month loan deal at Liverpool.
fields.body:
Fabrizio Ravanelli is poised for an improbable return to English football in a four-month loan deal at Liverpool.

Gérard Houllier, the club's manager, believes the 31-year-old former Middlesbrough striker is the man best qualified to plug the gaps left in Liverpool's first team by the absence of the injured England pair Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler.

The much-travelled and highly problematical Italian is currently playing for Lazio, and sources in Italy last night confirmed that negotiations between the clubs were at "an advanced stage".

Although Ravanelli is believed to have indicated his desire for a long-term move to the Merseyside club, Houllier is confident of persuading him to sign a loan deal, an agreement which could conceivably hold the possibility of a longer contract were he to prove successful at Anfield.

Houllier is seemingly unconcerned about the player's reputation for petulance, believing that despite Ravanelli's temperament and advancing years he still has the potential to score the goals that might see Liverpool secure a place in next season's Champions League.

Ravanelli left English football under a cloud in September 1997, only 14 months after becoming Middlesbrough's record signing when he arrived from Juventus for £7m.

Despite scoring 31 league and cup goals in his only full season in England, including a hat-trick against Liverpool on his debut, he was unable to prevent the Teesside club's immediate return to the First Division.

Almost immediately he began to seek a way out of the Riverside, almost joining Everton in a £5.5m deal in the summer of 1997, shortly before he was sold to Marseille for £5m. His spell in France ended late last year with a £2m move back to his native Italy.

After being informed that Fowler would be missing until late March at the earliest after a second operation on his damaged ankle, and that Owen's entire season might well be disrupted by persistent hamstring trouble, Houllier was given permission to bring in an experienced forward on an extended loan.

Among those to have come under discussion in the Liverpool boardroom in the past seven days are Rangers' out-of-favour Italian striker Marco Negri and Internazionale's "Divine Ponytail", Roberto Baggio.

Baggio, however, yesterday insisted he would remain with Inter in an attempt to get back into the first team. "I am more than happy to stay and fight for my place," he said.

fields.headline: Hillsborough eyes new technology
fields.trailText: After conceding the goal that never was in their FA Cup tie against Wolves, Sheffield Wednesday have volunteered to install an experimental electronic eye in each goalmouth to help match officials.
fields.body:
After conceding the goal that never was in their FA Cup tie against Wolves, Sheffield Wednesday have volunteered to be guinea pigs for an experiment with new technology.

The south Yorkshire club are willing to install an electronic eye in each goalmouth to help match officials.

A device in the goalposts would determine whether the ball has crossed the line, with the verdict delivered in the form of an electronic bleep or signal in the referee's earpiece.

Almost three weeks ago Wednesday were denied victory in a fourth-round tie at Hillsborough when Wolves were awarded a goal which replays confirmed had not crossed the line.

Wednesday's chairman Dave Richards, a member of Fifa's International Board and chairman of the Premier League, said football's world governing body had been in favour of new technology for two years.

"It went through at the Premier League summer meeting for more experiments to take place," he said. "Hillsborough has been offered as a possible venue if they should want to try it out. We should find out very soon about any possible trials."

Turkey have asked Muzzy Izzet to play for them in this summer's Euro 2000 finals. The Leicester midfielder, whose father is a Turk, has previously stated a desire to play for England but Turkey have now said that he will not have to do national service if he plays for them, the demand that put him off when first approached.

fields.headline: Flying Scots are chuffed
fields.trailText: Scotland were happy yesterday to accept a gamble that their campaign for a place in the 2002 World Cup will not be sabotaged at the start. They will travel to their first three fixtures, hoping that they will be in pole position before they even set foot in Hampden Park.
fields.body:
Scotland were happy yesterday to accept a gamble that their campaign for a place in the 2002 World Cup will not be sabotaged at the start. They will travel to their first three fixtures, hoping that they will be in pole position before they even set foot in Hampden Park.

They emerged from a meeting in Brussels happy that they will play in Latvia, San Marino and Croatia within a five-week period this autumn seeking the points that will put the group favourites Croatia and Belgium under pressure. But the schedule represents a high-risk strategy.

"We always want to start with difficult away matches," said the manager Craig Brown. "Although the games could be tricky, the real advantage is that we have managed to avoid playing any games in June, when our players will be tired."

Scotland's first match at home will be in March 2001, when they play Belgium. In theory the dates seem to give them an advantage over their rivals, so long as they do not drop off the pace early. Another advantage is that their home games will all be played on Saturdays.

Brown will waste no time in doing his usual extensive homework on the opposition. He intends to be in Cyprus next week when Latvia are involved in a competition under their new coach Gary Johnson.

webTitle: Ferguson targets Brazilian Dida in keeper quest

fields.headline: Ferguson targets Brazilian Dida in keeper quest
fields.trailText: Manchester United have opened negotiations which may bring the highly respected Brazilian international goalkeeper Dida to Old Trafford this summer.
fields.body:
The legacy of Manchester United's appearance in the World Club Championship in Brazil may prove more meaningful than an increased bank balance and a squad of sun-tanned players.

United have opened negotiations which may bring the highly respected Brazilian international goalkeeper Dida to Old Trafford this summer.

Dida, 26, is on loan with the Sao Paulo club Corinthians after failing to establish himself with Milan in Serie A following his £3m move from another Brazilian club, Cruzeiro, 18 months ago.

Although Corinthians did not play United on their way to winning the inaugural World Club Championship it is understood that Sir Alex Ferguson had a representative at their fixtures and received favourable reports on Dida.

Brazil's goalkeeper of the year in 1993, 1996 and 1998 shows no inclination to return to reserve team football in Italy, and Milan, anxious to cut their losses, are likely to demand a fee of around £4.5m.

Despite signing two goalkeepers in the past six months, Ferguson still appears to be wrestling with the problem of how to fill the void created by Peter Schmeichel's departure to Sporting Lisbon after the Champions' League triumph.

He invested £4.5m in Massimo Taibi but the Italian international had an uncomfortable opening to his Premiership career and last month joined the Italian club Reggina on loan until the end of the season. Although Taibi insisted he would seek to pick up the threads of his United career this summer, a successful move for Dida would signal the end of a brief stint in English football.

Ferguson is happy with the form of the current first-choice Mark Bosnich but his understudy, Raimond van der Gouw, is nearer the end of his career than the beginning.

The United manager is also believed to have shown interest in the Lazio centre-back Manuel Fernando Couto, who is likely to be available at a knockdown £1.75m. The 30-year-old Portuguese international is in dispute with the Rome club and wants to move as quickly as possible.

United will turn the clock back 24 years on Saturday when for the first time since Tommy Docherty was manager a crowd of more than 60,000 will watch a game at Old Trafford. The attendance for the visit of Middlesbrough will also be the largest for a Premiership match since the competition was launched in 1992.

A crowd of 58,293 saw United draw 1-1 with Arsenal on Monday but, as work on the extension of the east stand nears completion, an additional 3,000 seats have been made available.

Not since the days of standing on the terraces has Old Trafford catered for such numbers. The last time United broke the 60,000 barrier was for a league game against Everton on April 17 1976 when 61,879 saw a 2-1 win.

In 1967-68 United attendances topped 60,000 at nine home league games but with only eight Premiership home fixtures remaining this season that record will remain until next year. By then the capacity will be 68,000.

fields.headline: Crocked players in legal threat
fields.standfirst: Report accuses doctors of being 'unqualified and inefficient'
fields.trailText: Liverpool and Arsenal are among several clubs facing legal action from former players alleging that medical malpractice has left them suffering from arthritis.
fields.body:
Liverpool and Arsenal are among several clubs facing legal action from former players alleging that medical malpractice has left them suffering from arthritis.

The Professional Footballers' Association estimates that hundreds of retired players are now unable to walk properly because of incorrect treatment for their injuries.

One former player, now 40% disabled, is preparing a lawsuit which could act as a test case for hundreds of other claims against Premiership and Football League clubs.

Most of the allegations involve physiotherapists abusing the use of cortisone injections so that teams can field players carrying injuries. An 18-month study by academics at Leicester University has also found that many club doctors are "unqualified, untrustworthy and inefficient".

The Football Association is assessing the report, and arthritic former professionals including Allan Clarke, Peter Osgood and Tommy Smith have formed a team called Arthritis Athletic, who will appear on television tonight to highlight their plight.

The youngest recruit is Paul Lake, who was the captain of Manchester City, a regular at England Under-21 level and destined for full international honours before he snapped the cruciate ligaments in his right knee in September 1990. He had 17 operations before retiring 5 years later.

He is now the physiothera pist at Altrincham but his work is restricted. "I cannot run or cycle any more. My knee is always swollen and sometimes it totally locks," he says. "If I go to the pictures or the theatre, the pain is too much after 15 minutes unless I can get a seat with the aisle on my right. My hope is that surgery will become available enabling me to have a total knee replacement. In the meantime it is going to get only worse. I am only in the early stages. Imagine what it must be like in your 50s or 60s, constantly in pain and unable to make the most of having grandchildren. It's them I feel for."

Lake, 31, contemplated legal action but did not want to leave City on bad terms. "In my heart of hearts I still believe I had a case against them for mismanagement. I left with goodwill but there are players in the lower divisions who have not been looked after at all. They are the ones who may feel entitled to file lawsuits."

If so, their legal representatives should arm themselves with a copy of the Leicester University report. It found that physiotherapists were often under "unacceptable" pressure from managers to rush back players before they were fully fit.

"We uncovered a startling catalogue of bad practice," said the author, Dr Ivan Waddington. "Out of 58 medics who returned a questionnaire, only three were properly qualified.

"Most got the job on the basis of who they knew rather than what they knew. Many had no experience of sports medicine, and only three positions were publicly advertised.

"We spoke to some players who said their advice was ignored and players had then gone down after 15 minutes. A lot of what is going on involves some astonishing breaches of medical rules and ethics."

 This story will feature on Tonight with Trevor McDonald at 10.0 tonight

webTitle: The man from out of Toon

fields.headline: The man from out of Toon
fields.standfirst: After spells with Newcastle and Sunderland, Mohamed al Fayed's most expensive import, Lee Clark, happy to consider the south-east a home from home - especially if Fulham beat Tranmere on Saturday
fields.trailText: After spells with Newcastle and Sunderland, Mohamed al Fayed's most expensive import is happy to consider the south-east a home from home - especially if Fulham beat Tranmere on Saturday.
fields.body:
At Fulham's Motspur Park training ground, the most expensive of Mohamed al Fayed's imports is adjusting to life miles from home. But this £3m midfielder is no foreign fancy dan. "You understand Geordie, do you?" he asks, his north-east twang alien to this pocket of Surrey suburbia.

It is said as a joke, but it quickly becomes clear that Lee Clark's Tyneside roots are as important now as when he stood on the Gallowgate, or ran out for his debut at St James' Park as an 18-year-old. Or, indeed, when he was photographed wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with an anti-Sunderland logo after last season's FA Cup final. He was contracted to the Wearsiders at the time, of course.

Now Clark has found a home from home at Fulham and is preparing for a fifth-round tie with Tranmere. "It'll be tough," he says. "But we're at home so we have to be confident. We know we can still make an impact in the Cup and the league."

A goal drought of more than 12 hours duration in the league is threatening to derail Fulham. They have scored nine times in three cup games against Premiership opposition over the same period but Tranmere are the only First Division side they have beaten since November, that courtesy of an own-goal.

"People keep going on about the 12-hour stuff, but we had some great chances on Saturday," Clark says, recalling how Grimsby scored with their only effort and won 1-0. "As long as we keep our belief in front of goal, things will turn around. We're still a good side and people overlook that we dominate games. We just need a bit of luck."

He still wears black and white and his thoughts regularly stray to his days in a free-scoring Newcastle team where he was the local boy made very good.

"It was the best time of my life. I realise that now," he says. "It was a dream come true, but you only appreciate it when you move on to other clubs.

"To be involved when Newcastle came out of the shadows, when the sleeping giant at the bottom of the First Division woke up into the Premier League, was unbelievable. I was a local lad doing what 36,000 people every week wished they were doing. Moving on has made me realise how special it was at Newcastle. Every time I go back and watch, it is with a certain amount of envy."

He watches quite a bit. His Fulham commitments permitting, he sits with the Toon Army, chanting and urging the team on just as he did before he played for them. And just as he continued to do when he chose to move to their bitter rivals Sunderland in 1997.

The deal had originally been set up by Kevin Keegan. "Kenny Dalglish did not force me out the door; he even offered me a new long-term contract," says Clark. "But I decided that the time was right to move on.

"Staying in the north-east was important, but looking back, maybe it was a bit too much for me. It might have been different if I'd just played for Newcastle, but I support them as well. Perhaps it was the wrong decision.

"Once I'm on the pitch I give nothing but my best," he says. "It was difficult for my family, who are Newcastle supporters. But the Sunderland fans appreciated my honesty on and off the pitch; they realised I did not hide the fact I was a Newcastle fan and I was giving my best."

That was until his Tyneside loyalties were so blatantly displayed across his T-shirt last May. "It was my decision to leave Sunderland," he insists. "I was always thinking about moving on. The incident made it inevitable. I could never have stayed there after that, but as soon as we got promoted and won the league, my thoughts were on moving away."

Clark is, incidentally, wearing a plain black T-shirt today. He is settled in London, the upheaval of leaving the north-east tempered by the presence of his manager Paul Bracewell, a former team-mate at Newcastle and Sunderland.

"The club's probably risen too quickly for its own good," he says. "We've got an ambitious manager, an ambitious chairman and ambitious players; there are shades of Newcastle here.

"It's a new challenge. Hopefully it will end in a similar way to the last two clubs I've been at: with promotion to the Premiership."

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Stephen Sommers, director
fields.trailText: Stephen Sommers: At the moment I'm still promoting The Mummy on DVD: apparently when it came out over here it immediately became the second biggest DVD of the year.
fields.body:
At the moment I'm still promoting The Mummy on DVD: apparently when it came out over here it immediately became the second biggest DVD of the year. My editor and I went in the studio and did the commentary, there's a "making of" documentary, loads of Industrial Light and Magic (ILM) stuff, step-by-step explanations. In some ways the whole process is like a magician giving away his tricks, but when the next movie comes out we'll have a whole new bag of tricks.

This brings the lifecycle of the original to an end, and so we've just started up on the sequel. We finished the script but now we're doing the inevitable rewrites, as well as location scouting and production designing.

We're bringing back six of the original cast members (though I'm not going to reveal who) - plus the entire crew is coming back. I basically made one phone call to London and got my entire crew back together. I love filming over there. I had such a fun time working with the cast and crew, it's definitely one of the most pleasurable experiences I've had in the business. These movies are too time consuming and too expensive just to crank out, we've really been working hard on it. Everybody's goal is to make a bigger and better sequel.

When ILM read the script they were very pumped up: we bring back a couple of effects from the first movie - with a few new twists - but basically it's a whole new ballgame. We need to surprise the audience all over again.

Filming starts in May. So far everyone who's read the script thinks it's a better movie, so we're on course. I don't want to give too much away but what I will say is this - it's got everything you'd ever want from a mummy movie.

Stephen Sommers' The Mummy is released on DVD on Monday (Columbia).

webTitle: The Russians spent decades getting hold of pictures like these. Now anyone can order them on the net

fields.headline: The Russians spent decades getting hold of pictures like these. Now anyone can order them on the net
fields.standfirst:
Business and new technology are making a mockery of the UK's secrecy rules. Felicity Lawrence and Richard Norton-Taylor report

See the maps
fields.trailText: Walkers who explore the spectacular south-west coast trail a few kilometres north of Bude stumble across an unexpected view: from the path kept open for the public by the National Trust, a forest of satellite dishes and strange mushroom-like structures can be seen rising up from the fields.
fields.body:
Walkers who explore the spectacular south-west coast trail a few kilometres north of Bude stumble across an unexpected view: from the path kept open for the public by the National Trust, a forest of satellite dishes and strange mushroom-like structures can be seen rising up from the fields. A quick look at the Ordnance Survey map would tell them simply that they were passing a "radio station". This is in fact Sharpnose Point, an outstation of GCHQ, the government's electronic eavesdropping centre based in Cheltenham.

It is conveniently situated to exchange secret intelligence with GCHQ's partner, the US National Security Agency based at Fort Meade in Maryland. According to US sources, it has also been used to intercept civilian American communications via BT's satellite receiving station at Goonhilly Downs about 65 miles further south along the coast.

It is mentioned occasionally in books and articles. Yet few people who walk past have any idea what it does. For decades, the Russians spent millions of pounds trying to obtain pictures of places such as Sharpnose Point. Yet from next week it will be possible for anyone to get hold of detailed and high quality aerial photographs of this and any other of Britain's most sensitive installations through the internet.

On Monday, the Millennium Map, a photographic record of the whole of Britain from the air, will be launched on a new website, www.getmapping.com. The map, a 21st century version of the Doomsday Book, provides an inventory of every building and piece of land in the country in unprecedented detail. Every outdoor object larger than 10 inches is visible.

The site will be undergoing testing next week but soon anyone with a PC will be able to type in a postcode or grid reference and zoom in on an area, from their own back garden, to Buckingham Palace to a military base.

The release of the Millennium Map is the latest reminder that the kind of information which governments once controlled tightly, and which the superpowers once invested billions of dollars to obtain covertly, is now as readily available as a street map for a European city.

The rules about secrecy, about what we are allowed to see and publish, have been left trailing behind as commercial organisations exploit great leaps in technology. A pillar of "national security", and the longstanding system for protecting Britain's most senstive sites, appears to be crumbling before our eyes.

The Millennium Map project is the brainchild of Tristram Cary, an ex-Navy navigation systems expert, who until recently was working at the National Remote Sensing Centre, where satellite data is processed for use. Since last spring, he has had four pilots flying up and down the country at 4,500ft with special computer-controlled cameras taking pictures. The map represents an investment of some £3m, raised from private shareholders who include its patron, the Queen. "We've taken pictures of everything. There was no part of the country where we were not allowed to fly," Cary says.

Pictures in similar detail - at a resolution of one metre (ie, capable of showing clearly objects down to one square metre) - are already available commercially over the internet from an American satellite company, Space Imaging. Its Ikonos satellite, launched last year, passes over the same point of the earth every three days and if you have a credit card you can order photographs of more or less anything for $1,000 or so.

"There are currently no restrictions anywhere in the world. We operate under open skies policies, which are part of UN principles," says Space Imaging's director of Washington operations, Mark Brender. UK Perspectives, a company formed by the National Remote Sensing Centre to market observation data, is in the middle of a rival programme to photograph the whole of Britain from the air. As a privatised, ex-government organisation, the NRSC has its own view on the significance of the security issues involved. The marketing director of UK Perspectives, Helen Stannard, explained: "We were flying over all sorts of security areas, so we invited various security people together for a D-notice seminar."

Following the seminar, the D-notice list was reduced to about 10 sites. This fact is being recognised by Nick Wilkinson, a retired admiral and the new secretary of the D-notice committee which brings together senior Whitehall officials and a number of media executives. "The lists of sites should be removed altogether", he said yesterday. "If they have to be hidden they will have to be hidden in some other way."

Past attempts to prevent taking pictures of defence or spying installations have also been undermined by the post cold war "open skies" treaty, an international agreement made in 1992 and designed to ensure that countries are keeping to promises to reduce their weapons systems. It is a confidence-building measure, to promote détente and international security.

Thus, as this paper reported last year, the Russian airforce has been allowed to fly over sensitive British bases, including GCHQ and US bases in east Anglia - easily identifiable, as our pictures show, by their baseball pitches. The government knows that it cannot hide from spy satellites, or, now it seems, from high resolution pictures taken entirely legally by aircraft for private companies. But some security experts take a less sanguine view.

"That one metre resolution photographs are available and to anyone in the world is a very great concern for security operations," according to David Baker, editor of Jane's Space Directory. "You can see a tremendous amount, you can measure shadows, work out creep routes, see layers of security. You are opening the door on a technology that has been hitherto very strictly limited. While security experts try to catch up with the implications of current state of the art information systems, the technology continues to run ahead.

"The next thing," according to Baker, "is that you will be able to penetrate floors of buildings with radar. Then someone in a tent in the Middle East can plan how to drop a missile down a lavatory in Whitehall."

fields.headline: What is the Millennium Map?
fields.trailText: The Millennium Map is a modern day hi-tech Doomsday Book. Using the latest digital cameras, a team of pilots have spent months photographing the whole of Britain from the air to produce a record of every building and field. Recent advances in technology have made it possible for the vast amount of data they have collected (20 terabytes, or about 5,000 times the amount of information that can be accommodated on the hard disk of a modern PC) to be compressed and stored in a computer's memory. The result is that visitors to the company's website will be able to view the whole of England on a scale of one to a million, or zoom in on a single house at a scale of less than one to 1,000.

The Millennium Map is a modern day hi-tech Doomsday Book. Using the latest digital cameras, a team of pilots have spent months photographing the whole of Britain from the air to produce a record of every building and field. Recent advances in technology have made it possible for the vast amount of data they have collected (20 terabytes, or about 5,000 times the amount of information that can be accommodated on the hard disk of a modern PC) to be compressed and stored in a computer's memory. The result is that visitors to the company's website will be able to view the whole of England on a scale of one to a million, or zoom in on a single house at a scale of less than one to 1,000.

Until now few people other than local authorities and the military have had access to aerial photography of the country. The aim of the owner, Tristram Cary, and his partner, Joe Studholme, is to make high quality photos available to ordinary people at a reasonable price. Customers will be able to type a postcode into the website and order a picture of their house, school, or neighbourhood for £17.50.The map will be updated every five years and provide a record which will enable environmentalists to track changes, such as the loss of habitats, or the number and size of brownfield sites, and traffic density. The Millennium Map can be viewed at www.getmapping.com/ from January 31.

fields.headline: State of the union address
fields.standfirst:
More about the State of the Union address

President Bill Clinton delivers his last state of the union message tonight. He will give himself a big pat on the back for presiding over a robust economy in which Wall Street has soared to new heights and he will do his best to boost vice president Al Gore's chances of winning the 2000 presidential campaign.
fields.trailText: What is the state of the union address?
fields.body:
What is the state of the union address?

Every year since George Washington, the president of the United States goes before Congress to deliver a summing up of the state of the country. In an occasion full of pomp and ceremony, the president usually tells the country what his administration has achieved, glosses over its failures and lays out his future goals. Present in the chamber are senators, members of the House, ambassadors and invited guests.

Has the message always been known by this name?

The message was generally known as the president's annual message to congress until well into the 20 century. Although some historians suggest that the phrase state of the union emerged only after the second world war, president Franklin Roosevelt's 1934 message is identified in his papers as his annual message to congress on the state of the union.

When and where was the first state of the union message delivered, and by which president?

President George Washington delivered the first message before a joint session of congress in New York on January 8, 1790.

What was the early practice?

During the administrations of presidents Washington and Adams, the president customarily appeared before a joint session of Congress to deliver the address personally. Each chamber subsequently debated and approved official replies to the president's message, which were then delivered personally to the president by delegations of senators and representatives.

When and where does the ceremony take place?

Until the 20th amendment changed the opening time for congressional sessions, the annual message was delivered in December. Since 1934, messages have been delivered on a range of dates, between January 3 and February 2 of each year. The state of the union message is now delivered in the chamber of the house of representatives before a joint session of both houses of congress.

What is Mr Clinton expected to say?

Look for a big increase in defence spending so that Republicans cannot accuse Al Gore and the Democrats of being weak in a presidential year. Mr Clinton also wants to introduce legislation on issues such as prescription drug benefits for the elderly, an increase in the minimum wage, a bill of patients' rights with their health insurance companies and gun control measures after a spate of school shootings. In foreign policy, Mr Clinton will surely mention his peace efforts in the Middle East and Northern Ireland.

What to look for?

One of the things to look for is who is sitting next to whom. In one state of the union address, (federal reserve home page) the powerful federal reserve chairman Alan Greenspan sat next to Hillary Clinton, setting many tongues wagging. Republicans thought Mr Greenspan's strict neutrality had been compromised by the occasion. Mr Greenspan was said to have been uncomfortable at having been placed next to the first lady. But the picture did tell an interesting story; it symbolised a useful relationship. Mr Clinton brought down the budget deficit, allowing Mr Greenspan to bring down and keep interest rates low, laying the groundwork for the greatest bull market the world has seen.

Is it always the same?

Ronald Reagan brought a bit of Hollywood pizzaz to the state of the union. In his first address, the former Hollywood actor cited one of the guests in the audience, a former prisoner of war, as a true hero. It was corny but highly effective stuff, reminding the audience of Mr Reagan's brilliant political touch, only equalled since by Bill Clinton.

How does the speaker say goodbye?

Mr Clinton could do worse than look at Mr Reagan's farewell state of the union message. Despite the Iran-contra arms for hostages scandal, Mr Reagan remained a popular leader and his state of the union in 1988 showed why, full of little touches of humour to leaven the pomp of the occasion. Quoting Lao-tzu, the Chinese philosopher, the old crowd-pleaser said: "Govern a great nation as you would cook a small fish; do not overdo it."

fields.headline: Doctors of death
fields.standfirst: Few doctors have been found guilty of murder - but many believed Dr John Bodkin Adams got away with it
fields.trailText: Few doctors have been found guilty of murder - but many believed Dr John Bodkin Adams got away with it
fields.body:
Few doctors have been found guilty of murder in Britain. Last May, Newcastle GP David Moor was acquitted after giving an elderly, terminally-ill patient a massive overdose of diamorphine. The case was regarded as a vindication for euthanasia campaigners.

In 1992, Nigel Cox, a consultant rheumatologist, was convicted of killing an elderly arthritis sufferer with an injection of potassium chloride. But the charge of "attempted murder" enabled him to be freed with a suspended sentence.

The most celebrated case of a doctor walking free from a murder charge was the sensational trial of Dr John Bodkin Adams in 1957. A fashionable Eastbourne GP, Dr Adams preached a different kind of euthanasia. Everyone has to die sometime, so we should do what we can to "ease the passing", he argued during the Old Bailey court case in which he was accused of killing an elderly patient in order to benefit from her will.

Sensational press coverage before the trial suggested he had been responsible for the poisoning of many rich old ladies shortly after they altered their wills in his favour. The GP's Rolls-Royce was alleged to be the result of one such transaction.

The Express's crime reporter, Percy Hoskins, went against Fleet Street opinion and maintained that Dr Adams was innocent. He exposed a police campaign against Dr Adams, in which Scotland Yard planted anti-Adams stories in national newspapers.

After a 17-day trial, the jury rejected police evidence and Dr Adams was acquitted. Afterwards, the doctor received large sums of money from the court actions he took against several newspapers for seeking to prejudice the outcome of the trial.

Dr Adams was a free man, but he could never escape notoriety. The trial judge, Lord Devlin, broke with precedent and wrote about the case in a 1985 book, which he titled Easing the Passing.

Dr Adams died in 1983.

webTitle: M&S hopes for brighter future by ditching dowdy image

fields.headline: M&S hopes for brighter future by ditching dowdy image
fields.trailText: To the accompaniment of warm mozzarella and pesto panini and the fashionable strains of Macy Gray, Marks & Spencer unveiled its spring/summer collection yesterday.
fields.body:
To the accompaniment of warm mozzarella and pesto panini and the fashionable strains of Macy Gray, Marks & Spencer unveiled its spring/summer collection yesterday.

The troubled retailer, which experienced a 9% drop in sales for Christmas compared with the same period in 1998, hopes its new direction, pegged as offering "something for everyone", will revive the store's fortunes and counter allegations that its clothes are too dowdy.

"We are responding more closely than ever to customer needs," said spokeswoman Carol Richardson, adding that the store had used focus groups for the first time to get a stronger idea of what customers wanted. "It was overwhelmingly voiced that we should introduce more colour."

Should we bid farewell, then, to beige and navy, two of M&S's most popular hues? Not quite. Amid all the "look at me" trend-led pieces were plenty of seasonless trousers, cardies and jackets in pewter, khaki, slate and stone.

These aside, the overwhelming message for spring/summer is that M&S is desperately trying to woo back younger customers. How else to explain cropped dark denim trousers with diamante-studded pockets, knee-length skirts trimmed with a girly frill, and an abundance of strappy lycra suntops?

"We have divided the collection into three key areas: classic, contemporary and sport," said Ms Richardson. "It's fortunate that the classic look is fashionable this spring, as we do it very well."

Fashion victims are sure to make a beeline for the store's belted trenchcoats, polkadot chiffon skirts, and sleeveless blouses with modest pussy bows. There is even a chainstore version of the aviator sunglasses put out by designer labels like Prada and Chloe this spring.

Most successful are the accessories. At an average retail price of £35, pearlised pastel leather sandals, red gingham mules and blonde ponyskin pumps are bargains. Items like these, along with sexier lingerie will keep fashion-conscious customers happy.

In February, the store will introduce its new Autograph Collection, where designers will bear their name on the label for the first time.

Stylish the new spring collection may be, but until it revamps its fusty, harshly-lit stores, the M&S shopping experience will never be a chic one.

fields.headline: Straw extends race bill
fields.standfirst:
Move to ban indirect discrimination in public sector after revolt threat

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, last night attempted to restore his anti-racist credentials by announcing he is not only to extend his race relations bill to combat "institutional racism" but will go much further and place a positive legal duty on the whole of the public sector - from the police to schools and hospitals - to promote equality.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, last night attempted to restore his anti-racist credentials by announcing he is not only to extend his race relations bill to combat "institutional racism" but will go much further and place a positive legal duty on the whole of the public sector - from the police to schools and hospitals - to promote equality.

The decision not to include powers to combat indirect discrimination in Mr Straw's original bill, even though they were recommended last year in the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report, stunned race equality campaigners.

The move to add them follows trenchant criticism and the threat of a highly embarrassing revolt in the House of Lords today by nearly all the black and Asian Labour peers appointed by Tony Blair.

The changes announced by Mr Straw last night to the race relations (amendment) bill will mean that every aspect of the public sector - from police stop and search powers, to admission policies of schools and the allocation of street market stalls - will come under anti-discrimination laws.

The provision on the public sector to promote equality will mean that every part of it, including local authorities, will have to look at its career structures and workforce and account for the lack of black and Asian faces in senior positions.

But the new powers will stop short of giving legal cover to "positive action" measures such as training only unemployed black people with specific skills.

"This is about making sure that what you do does not continue to disadvantage somebody. It is not about giving a special leg up," said a spokesman for the commission for racial equality.

The decision to bring the police, prisons and immigration service within the new powers banning indirect discrimination will have far-reaching effects. It means their practices and policies, while not in themselves racist, but having a discriminatory effect on particular racial groups, will be open to court challenge.

For example as the original bill was published, individuals could sue the police and claim compensation if they believed they were being repeatedly stopped and search in the street because of their colour.

Now, a CRE spokesman explained, the stop and search policy in an entire area of a city could be deemed illegal if it could be proved that it indirectly discriminated against black or Asian people, even if the discrimination was unintentional.

Last night Mr Straw said he had decided to extend the bill to cover indirect discrimination in the public sector after very careful consideration.

"The government has always been in favour of this in principle, but had been concerned to ensure that the provisions were effective without leaving public bodies open to routine legal challenge in circumstances where their policies were entirely proper," he said.

Home office civil servants had warned that such powers in a race relations bill could leave other policies which discriminated in favour of a particular group, such as subsidised bus passes for pensioners or the new deal for the young unemployed, open to legal challenge.

Mr Straw conceded that he could live with the possibility of such "spurious challenges".

The home secretary said the announcement also meant that the race relations act would be extended to institutional racism in areas such as the "implementation of central and local government's regulatory, economic and social policies and law enforcement".

He said the legal commitment to promote equality would "send the clearest possible message that discrimination is not acceptable and will not be tolerated".

The decision not to include powers to combat indirect discrimination in Mr Straw's original bill, even though they were recommended last year in the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report, stunned race equality campaigners. The move to add them follows trenchant criticism and the threat of a highly embarrassing revolt in the House of Lords today by nearly all the black and Asian Labour peers appointed by Tony Blair. The changes announced by Mr Straw last night to the race relations (amendment) bill will mean that every aspect of the public sector - from police stop and search powers, to admission policies of schools and the allocation of street market stalls - will come under anti-discrimination laws. The provision on the public sector to promote equality will mean that every part of it, including local authorities, will have to look at its career structures and workforce and account for the lack of black and Asian faces in senior positions. But the new powers will stop short of giving legal cover to "positive action" measures such as training only unemployed black people with specific skills. "This is about making sure that what you do does not continue to disadvantage somebody. It is not about giving a special leg up," said a spokesman for the commission for racial equality. The decision to bring the police, prisons and immigration service within the new powers banning indirect discrimination will have far-reaching effects. It means their practices and policies, while not in themselves racist, but having a discriminatory effect on particular racial groups, will be open to court challenge. fields.headline: Pathologist's doubts on 'suicide' hanging
fields.standfirst:
Family of black man in double death riddle say police failed to make race hate connection as doctor asks for further documentation

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A pathologist who is examining the body of a black man found hanged on New Year's Day is not satisfied that he committed suicide, the man's family's lawyer said last night.
fields.body:
A pathologist who is examining the body of a black man found hanged on New Year's Day is not satisfied that he committed suicide, the man's family's lawyer said last night.

The family of Jason McGowan, who was discovered hanging from railings by a playing field in Telford, Shropshire, six months after his uncle was also found hanged, believe both men were the victims of racist killings.

They have accused the police of failing to link the incidents to a campaign of intimidation against members of the family and of assuming the deaths were suicide.

In a statement yesterday, West Mercia police denied charges that their investigation was flawed. They have completed a report into the death of Harold McGowan, 34, also known as Erroll, which will be considered by a coroner's jury on February 28. They are still investigating the death of his nephew, Jason, 20.

The police insisted yesterday: "Extensive inquiries have not yet revealed any evidence to suggest the direct involvement of a third party in either death."

But the family's solicitor Errol Robinson, said yesterday that a preliminary investigation by Nat Carey from Guy's hospital, London, a pathologist appointed by the family, had cast doubt on Jason's death. Although inquiries are not yet complete, Dr Carey reportedly is "very unhappy" about the circumstances of the death and has demanded further documentation before he completes his report.

One of the things he wants to look at is the original toxicology report. "One of the possibilities is that he could have been drugged," said Mr Robinson, although he stressed the family were neither ruling this in nor out. Other concerns include the absence of a suicide note from Jason and the public nature of the place he was found.

Errol McGowan's brother, Clifton, said there were also concerns about the belt fastened around Jason's neck which tied him to the railings. The buckle of the belt was round the front of his neck.

"Before you even get in a position to strangle yourself the pain alone would make you stop," he said.

Last night Jason's widow Sinead, 23, told the Guardian how she last saw her husband of four months just a few minutes before midnight on December 31.

The couple had gone with friends to the Elephant and Castle pub in Telford, opposite the Shropshire Star building where Mr McGowan worked as a production manager.

They paid £5 to get in and bought drinks and cigars. Jason asked his friends if they had any new year's resolutions but told them he was happy with a beautiful wife a home and a job he loved.

"There's no reason to change anything. I am totally happy," his wife remembers him saying.

"He was with his friends and his wife and having a good night," said one of those with him, Peter Hanson, 21, who was best man at his wedding.

Mrs McGowan said that about 11.30pm Jason left the pub. "He just went out. He said 'I just want five minutes to my self'. I followed him out of the pub. It was a bit cold so I just said 'I'll see you in a bit'."

There was nothing remarkable about this, as the pub was packed and hot. A few minutes later she went out to look for him again, and he was nowhere to be seen.

"I just assumed he'd either gone down the road to his mother's house or that he'd gone to Erroll's grave."

She phoned his mother and made a request for him to return to the pub if he turned up at his parents' home. But the phone calls to Jason's mobile grew more frantic throughout the night.

He was discovered dead at 6am on railings between a field and a road about 100 yards away. Today there are some 26 wreaths at the spot where he was found.

Mrs McGowan said the couple had planned to start a family.

Jason had been close to his uncle and was distraught when he was discovered dead in a dilapidated semi-detached house in Urban Gardens, Telford, on July 2 last year. Mrs McGowan says: "He was not depressed. He was just adamant he was going to find out what happened."

It appears that a campaign of racist intimidation of the McGowan family originated about two and a half years ago when Erroll, a doorman at the Charlton Arms pub in Wellington, part of the Telford new town, obeyed a management order and refused entry to a previously banned white man.

After the incident he was attacked at least twice and received numerous threats, the family said.

He phoned police on several occasions telling them once about 10 days before he died: "I fear for my life."

On another occasion, according to the family, he was the target of a racist assault but when police were called, he and his friends were arrested.

According to their lawyer, sources have revealed that some of the people attacking him were members of the neo-Nazi Combat 18 group.

Sinead McGowan said that Jason was not one of the family members who had been singled out since Erroll's death, although 18 months ago a friend of his had been stabbed in Shrewsbury.

For all the family's insistence there is some scepticism locally. While elements in the black press are supporting the family, the local press is more cautious.

Yesterday the police moved to correct "factual inaccuracies" in some coverage. West Mercia said it had immediately recognised that Erroll McGowan's death "was a serious incident and extensive resources were employed from the outset".

An assistant chief constable was immediately involved and a senior investigating officer assigned to the case.

After the second death, police said, the "likelihood of sinister implications was immediately recognised and taken into account".

A full report on Erroll McGowan's death had been forwarded to the coroner, and inquiries into Jason's death were continuing.

A police spokeswoman said she was not aware Telford had any more of a problem with racial harassment or far-right organisations than any other comparable town.

webTitle: Scurrilous jigsaws, Special cakes and Squashed kittens

fields.headline: Scurrilous jigsaws, Special cakes and Squashed kittens
fields.trailText: ZID UP AND PAY ATTENTION
fields.body:
ZID UP AND PAY ATTENTION

For some reason, the rumour mill is currently working overtime, churning out bags of fallacious flour by the hour. Ronaldo to Man United? Fonseca to Arsenal? Esteban Fuertes to the HM Customs Stansted XI? All have proven to be rubbish. So, as we start banging on about Zinedine Zidane joining Liverpool, please don't jump out of your seat and hug your neighbour.

Actually, hug away, let them know you care - life's too short. But back to the follically-challenged Frenchman. The notoriously excitable Italian press (imagine Rob Shepherd on Thai 'diet pills' and you're nearly there) have insisted on more than one occasion recently that Zidane is on his way out of Juventus at the end of the season, that he is tired of coach Carlo Ancelotti's tactics and that he fancies a new challenge.

To spice matters up further, Zidane gave an interview in a Juve programme in which he sang the praises of a certain G Houllier. "I would love to move to the Premiership with a fellow Frenchman as my manager," said Zid. "I adore the coaching skills that [Houllier] has shown for PSG, France and, most importantly, at the present for Liverpool." Which is slightly more reliable than the usual whispers from 'pals' (ie agents).

The final piece in this scurrilous jigsaw is Uruguayan midfielder Fabian O'Neill (who has never spoken to Martin since they were separated at birth) - recently making a name for himself with Serie A side Cagliari. According to O'Neill, who plays in the same position as Zidane, "my agent has assured me that next season I will be playing for Juventus". O'Neill doesn't sound like the most sophisticated of souls, but Gerard might do well to keep £20m at his bedside just in case.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HERE, IN DEEPEST LANCASHIRE

As the fevered campaign to host World Cup 2006 continues, countries will do anything to steal a march on their competitors. Moroccan plans to hand special cakes to Fifa delegates were apparently only scuppered by a lack of doilies, while Sir Bobby Charlton is rumoured to be ready to film a Roger Cook-style exposé of South Africa's violent underbelly at a moment's notice. However the South African campaign have themselves taken the biscuit, by drafting in Deepdale, home of Preston North End.

For some reason instead of showcasing the next-generation stadia that should be the cornerstone of the South African bid, a glossy brochure entitled '2006: Africa's Call' features Preston's 21,000 capacity ground instead. "Why didn't we think of it first?" scream the Germans, and it is a brilliant idea, although transport could turn out to be a problem - taking the M6 to Pretoria can be a nightmare at rush hour.

Not surprisingly, the FA were intrigued by developments. Faxing the Fiver a rather fuzzy rendition of the brochure in question, an apparatchik explained that the offending image shows "an African ethnic type rug," melting into a picture of Tom Finney and Deepdale above the legend 'feel the pull in your soul'. Feel the pull in your plonker more like, but it does give the Fiver an idea. How's about a nice Laura Ashley tablecloth, blending into a picture of Phil Masinga standing on Table Mountain? It's a long shot, but it might just work.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Chris Sutton is a real striker and I want to play with him." George Weah reveals his diplomatic skills to the British press.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BRING THE MANCHESTER UNITED EXPERIENCE TO YOUR CLUB - NOW HALF PRICE

January is the cruellest month. Furbies lie babbling incoherently in loft-bound cardboard boxes, fluffy kittens are gently dropped onto the nation's motorway hard-shoulders, and Manchester United kick all the cute little Murps (Manchester United Remaindered Player Stock) out of their youth emporium.

Jonathan Greening, Mark Wilson, Michael Clegg and John Curtis are the latest Murps cruelly forced to take their first unsteady steps out of Old Trafford's reserves. Greening has already been put on the transfer list after failing to agree a new contract and, according to the Mirror, the rest are on offer at truly knock-down prices, ranging from £2million to £750,000. Interested buyers might like to calculate the market price by using this simple formula: Worthington cup appearances + meaningless European fixtures x £500,000 = Murp.

Like a stick of rock, the United brand runs right through all Murps. And like the classic sports-cars they watch Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke drive into training, a Murp will never depreciate in value. Clubs only need to look at previous Murps for assurance of their quality. Step forward Chris Casper, Ben Thornley, Terry Cooke and Phil Mulryne - just four of the stars who have sprinkled that United stardust over the nether regions of the Nationwide.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United have been linked in various places with moves for Corinthians' Brazilian international goalkeeper Dida, Real Madrid's Roberto Carlos, and Lazio defender Fernando Couto.

Wimbledon want Mark Crossley as a replacement for imminent Bosman departure Neil Sullivan.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

The government have announced a scheme which will allow supporters to have a say in their club's affairs. Supporters Direct was launched by the culture secretary Chris Smith today and will allow fans to create Supporters' Trusts to acquire shares in their clubs. The project is backed by the Co-operative Bank, which has started a preferential banking service for fans. Similar schemes are already in place at Northampton and Bournemouth and England coach Kelvin Koogan said the plan: "will help forge stronger links between clubs and their fans."

Aston Villa have agreed a new three-year kit sponsorship deal with Diadora which will earn the club more than £6m.

Southampton have won their appeal for a work permit for Latvia international Imants Bleidelis following his £600,000 move from Skonto Riga. Bristol Rovers have also been granted a permit for Latvian captain Vitalijs Astafjevs.

Former England defender Bert Sproston, whose playing career included spells at Leeds, Tottenham and Manchester City and later coached at Bolton, has died.

The Scottish FA have declared their willingness to resurrect the international career of Duncan Ferguson if the Newcastle striker ever opts to come out of his voluntary retirement.

Liverpool captain Jamie Redknapp has returned to training after injury.

Nottingham Forest have signed Grimsby striker Jack Lester for £300,000.

Newcastle midfielder Silvio Maric has returned to Croatia Zagreb on loan until the end of the season.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV World football (3.05am) All the action from the Laos under-20s intermediate league.

Channel 5: Argentinian football (12.50am) Boca Juniors v River Plate. It's the fixture they've been crying out for, but we don't understand what they're saying!

International football (2.20am) Australia v Brazil. It's the fixture they've been crying out for, and it took place two months ago!

Sky Sports 1: Football League review (7pm) Zadie Smith is the future of English fiction, says Nottingham Forest's Stern John.

Fifa TV (7.30pm) Sepp Blatter with another action-packed show, this week featuring Bureaucratic Bingo ("88 - two Lennart Johanssons").

Spanish football (8pm) Live Primera Liga match, or coverage of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's groin operation.

Eurosport: South Africa v Congo (6.30pm) Live from Lancashire.

talkSPORT: Just like watching Brazil (7pm) Baldy, baldy slaphead.

The Royal Insititution of Chartered Surveyors seemed to be saying that last week, to publicise a slab of futurological research entitled, 2020: Visions Of the Future. In fact it doesn't quite say that.

David Fitzpatrick, RICS Research Foundation director, admits that this particular hook was dreamt up by their PR advisers. What the report does say is that a large portion of the high street will come under pressure - both from the net and from social trends. It will need to adapt to survive.

Mike Godliman, director of the retail researchers Verdict, agrees. Customers want to save time or have fun. "There has been a general trend towards people wanting either quality or value," he says. "That's why middle market retailers like Sainsburys and British Home Stores have had problems." People can, in theory, minimise 'chore' shopping at the supermarket and instead try out retail entertainment destinations, like the funky new coffee shop.

People in the UK clearly want to supermarket shop online, according to market leader Tesco, which today took the number one slot in a survey of the fastest growing internet companies in the world by Novell. Last week Tesco annouced that, due to consumer demand, it would treble the number of stores offering online shopping. It's been trialing its Tesco Direct service at 100 stores, and plans to offer it at 300 outlets by the end of the year.

To survive, the average high street needs to respond , says Fitzpatrick. It needs to ditch the standardised BHS style of shopping for more niche experiences, for shops that change and reinvent themselves and their markets regularly. Net shopping may even be catered for on the high street, Fitzpatrick suggests, through businesses that offer access to net shopping and serve as pick up points for deliveries.

There could even be a resurgence in neighbourhood shops, Verdict's Mike Godliman states. "The neighbourhood is beginning to bounce back, because people want convenience. They want to supplement their main shop with individual items, which they can do at the corner shop. Neighbourhood shops could also be a marvellous place to pick up your net purchases. No one's tried that yet. But it could help people who buy online but are out at work all day."

Similar ideas are explored by William Mitchell, Dean of the MIT school of Architecture and Planning, in his new book E-Topia (published by MIT Press), which looks at the general impact of networks on urban centres. Mitchell suggests that the growth in teleworking could drive a neighbourhood renaissance. Bored teleworkers will be looking to take a break from the screen at home, but won't have time to go far. So there is an opportunity for shops that target them.

Over the years, different infrastructures like water supplies and electricity grids have been imposed on cities and changed them, Mitchell argues. He sees the arrival of digital telecommunications as continuing the general 'fragmentation and recombination' that takes place when new infra-structures are deployed. "You see contradictory things happening at once. In retailing, you get decentralisation of the browsing and purchasing functions. Those functions used to be within a store and now fragment and recombine with domestic space.

"At the same time, to achieve economies of scale, the distribution functions tend to centralise. So you get big warehouses. You get neither rampant centralisation nor rampant decentralisation but a complicated process of fragmentation and recombination."

Mitchell doesn't believe that high streets and malls will die. However, he does suggest that, thanks to the efficiencies of e-commerce, bookshops may not be around in the same way in 30 years time. Those with a historical aura - for example, City Lights, in San Francisco, the honorary home of the Beats - will survive.

British researchers are less willing to predict the death of certain retail sectors. Professor Leigh Sparks, author of the RICS Research Foundation's report on the future of shopping, suggests that - despite people generally assuming clothes shops will survive but that travel agents and financial services will be vulnerable to online competition - you can't generalise.

"The shops that will suffer are those that are providing functional transactions. If they're not providing anything more than that, why should I bother going to them when I can do that functional transaction every bit as well online or at a remote location?" In other words, if a travel agent offers a different sort of experience - better information, a nice place to browse - it may survive. So what about music? This week EMI was absorbed by Time Warner-AOL. Analysts suggested that the company was looking to prepare itself for a future in which music is delivered to consumers via the net. Sparks agrees that much music will be delivered digitally in the future, but argues that many consumers may not prefer to own music in that way. "They may prefer to go to a store, listen to a range of things, have a coffee, maybe download 10 tracks from the EMI back catalogue onto a specially made CD."

Discussion about the effects of net shopping tends to focus on the high street. Might the big out-of-town superstores also come under pressure as more people shop online for groceries and other bulk purchases? Verdict's Mike Godliman believes that out of town shopping for DIY goods, electricals and furniture, will take a while to take off online, but that the threat of the net may force these real world stores to get better. "If you think about electrical stores, they're not that enjoyable an environment to be in, for most people. But they could be brilliant. There are so many fantastic little goodies in there to play with. I think the net will act as a catalyst for electrical stores to start thinking more creatively about their space."

The general conclusion seems to be that the rise of net shopping could actually be an opportunity for creative high street retailers. It's a potentially positive message, though one that ignores a few key problems, according to the RICS's David Fitzpatrick. "We're seeing a clear divide between those who have and those who have not. Those who have access to the technology will be able to decide when they want to buy something and how they want to buy it, and then spend time with fairly high cost differentiation in the high street. So they'll go to the nice coffee shops or the nice clothes shops and they'll become more interested in retail-tainment."

Those who don't have access may find themselves shut out of all sorts of retail spaces and given access to a limited range of low quality goods, he continues. So creative government intervention may be needed to solve these problems of access, he concludes. It's certainly easy to see how high streets might dodge death by reinventing themselves as "differentiated themed experiences". It's rather harder to see how they might be really reborn as genuine community centres.

For more information about the RICS Research Foundation and 2020: Visions of the Future, go to www.rics-foundation.org. Verdict's website is at http://www.verdict.co.uk. William Mitchell's website is http://loohooloo.mit.edu/people/mitchell.html.
