webTitle: Austria gets pariah warning over Haider

fields.headline: Austria gets pariah warning over Haider
fields.trailText: Austria was warned last night that it could become a pariah, as conservatives negotiated to form a government with Jörg Haider, a far-right politician who once praised Adolf Hitler's employment policies.
fields.body:
Austria was warned last night that it could become a pariah, as conservatives negotiated to form a government with Jörg Haider, a far-right politician who once praised Adolf Hitler's employment policies.

A chorus of condemnation from Israel, Germany, France, Italy, Sweden and the Czech Republic descended on the central European state as Mr Haider scurried to apologise for past pro-Nazi remarks and the prospective chancellor in the centre-right alliance, Wolfgang Schüssel, tried to allay international concerns.

In Jerusalem, Israel's Nobel peace laureate, Shimon Peres, compared Mr Haider's rise with that of Hitler.

"[Hitler] was from Austria and any man who raises so many doubts must also raise the alarm everywhere," said Mr Peres, minister of regional cooperation in the government of the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak.

Coalition talks began on Tuesday between Mr Schüssel's People's party and Mr Haider's Freedom party after Mr Schüssel refused to renew his long-time coalition with the leading Social Democrats.

Mr Barak, who is attending a conference on the Holocaust in Sweden, said the rise of the extreme right in Austria was extremely worrying: "For every Jew in the world it is a highly disturbing signal... it touches every one of us."

Israel has threatened to break off diplomatic relations with Vienna if Mr Haider joins the government.

Also at the conference, Austria's acting chancellor, Viktor Klima, said that anyone who minimised Nazi atrocities lacked "the basic human qualities that are a precondition for any responsibility in politics".

Germany was no less forthright last night. A foreign ministry spokesman, Andreas Michaelis, said: "Austria has a special responsibility because of its membership in the European Union, as well as the fact that it will soon hold the chairmanship of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe."

A senior member of Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's ruling Social Democrats accused Mr Schüssel of damaging his country's standing.

"His strategy runs the risk of sending Austria into isolation," said Gernot Erler, deputy chief whip of the SPD. "No one in Europe trusts Haider and it won't be just Israel that draws the consequences."

A spokeswoman for France's foreign ministry said Austria would put itself into a "deplorable position" if Mr Haider joined the government.

The condemnation was on a scale not seen since Kurt Waldheim was elected Austrian president in 1986, despite having lied about his wartime service as an army intelligence officer. Mr Schüssel claimed yesterday that he had the reason and experience to handle Mr Haider's party. "No one should be afraid. I believe I am the guarantor for that."

Senior officials of Mr Schüssel's party also claimed that in power the far right party would moderate its anti-immigration policies. "The political culture and political style of the Freedom party will have to change," People's party general secretary Maria Rauch-Kallat told ORF television.

Wolfgang Schüssel denied yesterday that he had links with an arms dealer at the centre of a political scandal in Germany. Greens member of parliament Peter Pilz had accused the acting foreign minister of having manipulated a 1994 Austrian tender for radar equipment to ensure that it was won by France's Thomson.

He said Mr Schüssel's name was mentioned in a notebook belonging to Karlheinz Schreiber, an arms broker wanted in Germany in connection with donations to the opposition Christian Democrats.

fields.headline: The best lift cadging scene
fields.standfirst: Limbo
fields.trailText: Alaska. Having just finished a disastrous outdoor concert, lounge singer Donna De Angelo (Mary Elisabeth Mastrantonio) is eager to get away as quickly as possible. She approaches Joe Gastineau (David Strathairn), who is packing away equipment in his beaten-up truck.
fields.body:
Alaska. Having just finished a disastrous outdoor concert, lounge singer Donna De Angelo (Mary Elisabeth Mastrantonio) is eager to get away as quickly as possible. She approaches Joe Gastineau (David Strathairn), who is packing away equipment in his beaten-up truck.

"Is this your truck?" she asks.

"Uh-huh", Joe answers non-commitally.

"Been working here?"

"I've got to load this up and help tear things down after."

Suddenly, it becomes apparent Donna is close to tears.

"Could you give me a ride?"

"Ah... I guess... after I..."

He pauses.

"How far is it?"

"Just into town."

"Well, let me know when you're ready."

Before the last syllable has even left Joe's lips, Donna replies.

"I'm ready now."

"Aren't you the singer?"

"Well, I was."

"You're really good."

"Thanks. Listen, I just broke up with a guy and he's here. And if I'm going to keep my shit together without making a scene I need to go now."

Joe climbs into the driving seat.

"Alright."

See also: There's Something About Mary, The Hitcher, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre

Don't see also: Starman

Pointless trivia: Limbo is the seventh John Sayles film since 1980 to feature an appearance from David Strathairn

fields.headline: Clinton's last hurrah
fields.standfirst:
The president will unveil an ambitious legislative agenda in his final state of the union adress tonight

Special report: the US election race
fields.trailText:
President Bill Clinton will unveil an ambitious legislative
agenda in his final state of the union message tonight, seeking
to make amends for a presidency blighted by sexual scandal.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton will unveil an ambitious legislative agenda in his final state of the union message tonight, seeking to make amends for a presidency blighted by sexual scandal.

US officials say Mr Clinton will outline a bold "new opportunity" agenda more appropriate for a newly elected president than a lame duck at the end of his second term.

"This is not going to sound like somebody looking backward," said White House deputy chief of staff Maria Echaveste. "I think they will be surprised - but if they know the president, they shouldn't be."

Mr Clinton will give himself a broad pat on the back and use the occasion to extend a helping hand to Al Gore in his White House bid as the vice-president prepares for next week's crucial New Hampshire primary. By announcing an increase of nearly 7% in defence spending, the biggest rise in the Pentagon's budget since the Reagan-era military buildup of the 1980s, Mr Clinton will pre-empt any Republican argument that Mr Gore and the Democrats are weak on defence.

Health care is likely to be a big theme. Mr Clinton has proposed an ambitious $110bn programme to expand health care coverage for uninsured Americans, including a plan first suggested by Mr Gore to extend health cover to parents whose children are covered under the government's children's health insurance programme.

Mr Clinton's health care initiative is an attempt to offset criticism of Mr Gore on the issue by Democrat presidential challenger Bill Bradley. Mr Clinton is expected to press Congress to pass the so-called patient's bill of rights, giving patients new powers in dealing with their health insurance companies and other managed care plans.

While looking to boost Mr Gore's presidential chances, Mr Clinton will not be shy in taking credit for a robust economy, the longest peacetime expansion in US history, the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years and the first budget surpluses in 43 years.

Past experience suggests that Mr Clinton might persuade congress to adopt some of his proposals. Presidential election years have often proved fertile ground for legislative accomplishments.

In 1996, Mr Clinton and the Republican-controlled congress collaborated on a slew of measures that saw an increase in the minimum wage (to the current $5.15 an hour), more health insurance coverage for workers and sweeping reform of the national welfare system. Sweeping deregulation of the telecommunications industry paved the way for mega-mergers among phone companies.

The Republicans also have an incentive to look productive to avoid being tarred as "do-nothings" at a time when Americans want action in a number of areas. The Democrats and the Republicans do see eye-to-eye on some issues: prescription drug benefits for the elderly, an increase in the minimum wage, new legal safeguards for patients dealing with their health insurance companies, modest gun control measures and tax relief for married couples.

One thing is almost certain. This should be a long state of the union message, running well past an hour. This will be the last time that Mr Clinton occupies such a prestigious podium, looking out on a sea of faces in the ornate halls on Capitol Hill, and watched by millions in their living rooms. Mr Clinton will want to hog the limelight as long as he can.

webTitle: BT brings million more for Smith's website

fields.headline: BT brings million more for Smith's website
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: WHSmith has grabbed access to more than one million potential new book-buying customers with a BT internet deal.
fields.body:
WHSmith has grabbed access to more than one million potential new book-buying customers with a BT internet deal.

WHSmith Online, which the stationery chain claims is already Britain's biggest web bookseller, will become BT's principal books retailer on all BT-controlled internet services including btclick.com, BT Internet and email address service talk21.

Details of the new internet deal came as Smith's revealed a solid set of Christmas trading figures.

Many analysts had expected the chain to issue a profit warning based on lacklustre seasonal sales but, in the event, the group reported total sales up 2.5% in the 19 weeks to January 8 and like-for-like sales, which exclude sales gained as a result of extra shopfloor space, up 1.5%.

Book sales climbed 7% and the company said there was also "a strong performance in computer and telephone peripherals." The music, video and computer game business was much tougher, leaving margins down 0.2% overall.

Internet orders in the year to date were up 85% and underlying sales at Hodder Headline, the publisher acquired by WHSmith last May, were ahead by 8%.

Chief executive Richard Handover said: "This was a tough Christmas trading period and we have performed well in difficult conditions".

He said he was pleased with results in books, magazines and stationery but there was "a lot of scope to improve" in music and video.

The shares, which stood at 492p on January 4, closed up just p at 345p. Less than 12 months ago they were changing hands at 775p.

WHSmith aims to grab 30% of the British online book market within three years and plans to offer buyers the opportunity to have their purchases delivered to their home or work, or to their nearest WHSmith branch, if that is more convenient.

As part of its expansion plan the retailer last year bought the Hodder Headline publisher whose authors include Stephen King and Manchester United football manager Sir Alex Ferguson.

Analysts said that there was relief in the City that the company had produced such good results. "There were expectations that they would do a deal with somebody to give them access to more eyeballs," said Credit Suisse First Boston's stores analyst, Tony Shiret.

fields.headline: Blair backs his 'unspun' hero
fields.trailText: The prime minister hailed Frank Dobson as "an unspun, unspoilt politician" as he helped stage a final photo call before Labour voters help decide on the party's candidate for mayor of London.
fields.body:
The prime minister hailed Frank Dobson as "an unspun, unspoilt politician" as he helped stage a final photo call before Labour voters help decide on the party's candidate for mayor of London.

Tony Blair's latest endorsement of the former health secretary came as the pair posed for photographs this morning alongside cabinet office Minister Mo Mowlam, who the Mirror campaigned for to stand for the post, and Mr Dobson's running-mate Trevor Phillips.

Mr Dobson "is someone I can trust and he will get things done, he is a team player. All of us who have worked with him for a long time are out supporting him," Mr Blair's said, in remarks designed to suggest that he and his cabinet colleagues have little time for an individualist such as Ken Livingstone.

Last night, in his fifth question and answer session of the campaign Mr Blair was noticeably less critical of Mr Livingstone than in the past, telling party members it was their choice.

"It is your decision, you decide but we have been two-and-a-half years in government after 18 years in opposition. Don't let us do anything to throw it all away," Mr Blair told an audience of 500 in Southall, west London.

Mr Livingstone says he could yet win the nomination, and there have been suggestions that Downing Street has been forced to draw up a strategy for the prime minister to "live with" an administration for the capital led by him.

As party members prepared to vote, Ms Jackson called for an internal inquiry into the way in the candidate is being selected.

"It is absolutely vital for the credibility of whoever is selected that they are seen to have done so through a process that has been free and fair, given the criticism that has surrounded the contest," she said. "The only way to ensure that is to have a full inquiry."

A particular focus of the inquiry, which should be carried out by Labour's National Executive Committee, should be the question of candidates being supplied with membership lists for use in canvassing, she said.

"It is undoubtedly true from my experience touring the constituencies that the attacks on me and Ken have, if anything, boosted our support and been counter-productive to those carrying them out."

 There was a rare moment of unity between Mr Dobson and the other candidates today as they united with Conservative hopeful Steve Norris and Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer to support the repeal of Section 28, which bars local authorities from "promoting" homosexuality in schools.

In a joint letter to the Times, the five said: "Far from protecting young people, Section 28 has helped to foster widespread homophobic bullying in schools. "In addition, research has shown that younger gay people are particularly vulnerable to both physical and verbal violence.

"The government should repeal Section 28 at the earliest opportunity."

webTitle: War crimes court cuts sentence slashed

fields.headline: War crimes court cuts sentence slashed
fields.trailText: A UN court yesterday reduced the sentence imposed on Dusan Tadic, the notorious Bosnian Serb jailed for the murder of Muslims, ending the longest international war crimes prosecution since the Nuremberg trials after the second world war.
fields.body:
A UN court yesterday reduced the sentence imposed on Dusan Tadic, the notorious Bosnian Serb jailed for the murder of Muslims, ending the longest international war crimes prosecution since the Nuremberg trials after the second world war.

In a decision which will set guidelines for future prosecutions - specifically that punishment should reflect the rank of indicted war criminals - appeal judges of the UN tribunal for the former Yugoslavia reduced Tadic's 25-year sentence by five years.

Judge Mohammed Shahabuddeen said the original sentence against Tadic, 44, was too harsh, given his relatively low position in the Bosnian Serb hierarchy. "Although the criminal conduct underlying the charges of which the appellant now stands convicted was incontestably heinous, his level in the command structure. . . was low," he said.

Tadic, 44, would get credit for the time he spent in pre-trial custody in Germany and the Netherlands, amounting to nearly six years, he added.

The ruling was welcomed by the chief prosecutor at the tribunal in The Hague, Carla Del Ponte. "We are hoping that this is the last the tribunal will hear of Dusko Tadic, that he will be able to start serving his sentence," her spokesman, Paul Risley, said using the defendant's nickname. Tadic, a Bosnian Serb reserve policeman, former pub owner and karate instructor, was convicted for the torture and murder of Muslims and Croats at detention camps in Bosnia. He was arrested by German police in Munich in February 1994, after refugees recognised him from the Omarska and Trnopolje prison camps in northwest Bosnia.

Televised pictures of emaciated prisoners at those camps in 1993 increased pressure on the UN to set up a war crimes tribunal.

His case, which began in May 1996, was the tribunal's first and longest trial. The court was accused of making Tadic a scapegoat for the crimes of his superiors, who remained free. Tadic's lawyers argued he was a mere "tadpole in a pool of sharks".

fields.headline: Putin hikes up defence spending
fields.trailText:
Russia's acting president Vladimir Putin today announced a 50% increase
in defence spending this year, setting a course for a more
assertive military after years of neglect.
fields.body:
Russia's acting president Vladimir Putin today announced a 50% increase in defence spending this year, setting a course for a more assertive military after years of neglect.

"The army has been under-financed for several years which has entailed negative consequences for the nation's defence potential," Mr Putin said. "It has raised doubts about the very possibility for Russia to have a modern army equipped with state-of-the art weapons."

Mr Putin's remarks confirm that Russia is embarking on a major rethink of its military strategy. Earlier this month, Russia published a revamped national security concept that made clear Moscow had lowered the threshold for using nuclear weapons to counter what it sees as a growing external military threat.

Moscow lists the main military threats as Nato's eastward enlargement and new strategy, the possibility of military bases bordering Russia, a weaker role for the United Nations and a lack of integration among former Soviet states.

Restoring Russia's military credibility will strengthen Mr Putin's bid for the Russian presidency, although the timing of his announcement was less than diplomatic, coming as UN secretary general Kofi Annan arrived in Moscow for talks on the humanitarian crisis in Chechnya.

The unimpressive performance of Russian forces in the face of determined Chechen resistance can only have reinforced the need for a significant upgrade if Russia is to be taken seriously as a military power. But Mr Putin said: "The problem is a little deeper. For a few years the army has not been sufficiently financed." He said he believed it was necessary to form a programme to develop the defence industry and pledged to pay the government's debt to the industry by May of this year.

In graphic testimony of the dire state of the Russian military, government officials acknowledged that security forces are accepting bribes of up to $1,000 a day to take journalists to frontline positions in the battle for Grozny, the Chechen capital.

Antoine Gyori of the Sygma agency said: "I returned from Grozny three days ago. My journalist's accreditation was useless, but my hundred-dollar bills worked like a dream." He said the Chechens never asked him for money and Russian officials admitted that the behaviour of their security forces was shameful.
fields.bodyText: Russia's acting president Vladimir Putin today announced a 50% increase in defence spending this year, setting a course for a more assertive military after years of neglect. "The army has been under-financed for several years which has entailed negative consequences for the nation's defence potential," Mr Putin said. "It has raised doubts about the very possibility for Russia to have a modern army equipped with state-of-the art weapons." Mr Putin's remarks confirm that Russia is embarking on a major rethink of its military strategy. Earlier this month, Russia published a revamped national security concept that made clear Moscow had lowered the threshold for using nuclear weapons to counter what it sees as a growing external military threat. Moscow lists the main military threats as Nato's eastward enlargement and new strategy, the possibility of military bases bordering Russia, a weaker role for the United Nations and a lack of integration among former Soviet states. Restoring Russia's military credibility will strengthen Mr Putin's bid for the Russian presidency, although the timing of his announcement was less than diplomatic, coming as UN secretary general Kofi Annan arrived in Moscow for talks on the humanitarian crisis in Chechnya. The unimpressive performance of Russian forces in the face of determined Chechen resistance can only have reinforced the need for a significant upgrade if Russia is to be taken seriously as a military power. But Mr Putin said: "The problem is a little deeper. For a few years the army has not been sufficiently financed." He said he believed it was necessary to form a programme to develop the defence industry and pledged to pay the government's debt to the industry by May of this year. In graphic testimony of the dire state of the Russian military, government officials acknowledged that security forces are accepting bribes of up to $1,000 a day to take journalists to frontline positions in the battle for Grozny, the Chechen capital. Antoine Gyori of the Sygma agency said: "I returned from Grozny three days ago. My journalist's accreditation was useless, but my hundred-dollar bills worked like a dream." He said the Chechens never asked him for money and Russian officials admitted that the behaviour of their security forces was shameful.

fields.headline: The disappearance of Britishness
fields.standfirst:
Our lives are becoming hopelessly Americanised says professor

More about the ONS report and our interactive guide to the results
fields.trailText: Life in Britain can no longer be said to be uniquely British, a leading social scientist declares today as the government publishes the latest annual snapshot of the changing face of the nation.
fields.body:
Life in Britain can no longer be said to be uniquely British, a leading social scientist declares today as the government publishes the latest annual snapshot of the changing face of the nation.

Growing international homogeneity and the dominance of American culture mean that it is increasingly difficult to pinpoint Britishness, according to AH Halsey, former professor of social and administrative studies at Oxford university.

Writing in the 30th anniversary edition of Social Trends, the compendium of social statistics, Professor Halsey says that as recently as 1940, George Orwell could state that "when you come back to England from any foreign country, you have immediately the sensation of breathing different air".

It was doubtful that Orwell could make such an assertion today, the professor said. "What would strike him perhaps would be the rapidity of change from his death in 1950 and the degree of assimilation of life in Britain to that of the other advanced industrial countries in Europe and North America."

Prof Halsey, regarded as a founding father of comprehensive education and now emeritus fellow of Nuffield college, Oxford, told the Guardian that Britain was becoming "hopelessly Americanised" in everything from the decline of the high street to fixation with the individual and the free market.

"It seems to me that we have lost the old form of society that we had when I was a child. In terms of dress, in terms of sex, in terms of politics, we are much more like the rest of the world and we have lost a lot of that distinctiveness."

Stressing that people's lives had changed for the better in many respects, such as disposable income, life expectancy and health, Prof Halsey said he was not necessarily lamenting the passing of days of "warm beer and old ladies cycling to church", as conjured up by former Conservative leader John Major.

"There's a lot to be said for the way we have changed, but being like everybody else is just a bit dreary," he said.

Social Trends, published by the office for national statistics, highlights several aspects of the growing international ism of our working and domestic lives. It shows that almost 400,000 Britons now live in other EU states, with some 800,000 people from those countries living in Britain - although more than half are from Ireland.

After years of the gap narrowing, the number of holidays taken abroad has finally eclipsed the number taken in this country - although tourism chiefs point out that this applies to trips of four nights or more and that there is a boom in shorter breaks taken at home.

In an apparent return to habits of a past era, however, the number of adults living with their parents is rising. In the 20-24 age group, 56% of men and 38% of women are still in the family home. In 1977-78, the respective figures were 52% and 31%.

By age 30-34, 11% of men and 4% of women are still at home, compared with 9% and 3% respectively in 1977-78.

Jill Matheson, co-editor of Social Trends, said: "Some young people may be delaying leaving home because of difficulties entering the housing market. The later age of marriage may also be a factor."

Findings In Brief

 People on council estates say dogs are as much an irritant as noise. But crime is rated twice as big a problem as either of them.

 The number of special constables in England and Wales fell 10% in the 12 months to last March. The number of full-time police officers also dropped slightly, though police staffing overall remained 35% higher than in 1971.

 On average, people eat fresh fruit equivalent to six apples a week. In 1975, they ate the equivalent of only four. Fresh vegetable consumption has risen only marginally, however.

 Average expenditure on motoring has more than doubled in real terms since 1971. Four in 10 drivers say it would make no difference to their car use if petrol costs doubled over the next decade.

 Measured against local incomes, people in the north-east pay the highest council tax and those in Northern Ireland the lowest. Contrary to widespread belief, Londoners pay well below average.

 Twenty-three per cent of women, and 15% of men, say they have been assaulted by a current or former partner.

 People in Yorkshire and Humberside eat out the least, compared with the rest of England. Londoners eat out the most, but people in the north-east come only slightly behind.

 One in three men, and one in five women, never use sun cream. Rates of skin cancer have tripled since 1971

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Pat's ghost train
fields.body:
Pat's ghost train

Whenever John Prescott wants to persuade us of the virtues of public transport, he heaves himself out of his Jag and on to a (always near-empty) train for a photocall. Presumably, he is spared the experience of buying a ticket for his journey. Pat Proudfoot's endeavours to secure two seats from Carlisle to Glasgow took four weeks and 10 phone calls and highlight the interesting consequences of privatised rail.

On day one she rang National Rail Enquiries, five weeks before she wanted to travel, asked about train times and chose the 8:19am to Glasgow. She was told that a Virgin Value ticket at £15 was what she needed and that it should be booked a minimum of seven days in advance. So she rang Virgin to be told that train wasn't on the system yet. Two weeks later she tried them again and learned that the 8:19 was still unavailable. The following week she made a third attempt and was told the train still wasn't registering and the operator didn't know why.

Proudfoot then returned to National Rail Enquiries who assured her the phantom train did exist, so back to Virgin who were still mystified, then to National Rail who suggested that the Virgin Value offer possibly didn't apply after all. Five days later the same response from Virgin, but by this time National Rail had realised the train wasn't a Virgin operation after all and that she should have been ringing Northern Spirit. This she did and hit a snag; Northern Spirit couldn't find it on its system. This turned out to be because it wasn't a Northern Spirit train at all, but Scotrail and, what's more, there was no advanced booking and tickets were £20-£40 each.

Hell from Dell

Like so many readers before him Nick Hanika of London made the mistake of thinking his life's path would be smoothed by a computer. Accordingly he ordered two from Dell; two months on he's wishing he'd stuck with a Biro.

When the confirmation of his order arrived by fax he found Dell had substituted the address of the Nottingham branch of his company which had previously ordered a Dell computer. He immediately faxed back to point this out and rang the following day to ensure it had arrived. It hadn't. He repeated the correct details over the phone and faxed again for good measure. Three days later one computer was delivered to the Nottingham address and was immediately sent back. Another call brought the promise that he would receive the machine in London within three days. A week later, silence. Hanika rang to be told that Dell had attempted a delivery at an address in Worthing. Three more promises of immediate delivery proved worthless and eventually Hanika was told his order had been put on hold because of a credit card problem. His credit card company insisted his finances were in perfect working order but that, given the sums involved, Dell needed to call them to get authorisation. This little operation seemed beyond the technical giant, however. Hanika left two messages on a Dell voicemail and heard nothing more.

 Dell declares grandly that its "legions of satisfied customers" will benefit from the following explanation: the incorrect delivery was human error - its Nottingham branch had ordered a machine of confusingly similar specifications. Once the mistake was realised the computer was dispatched to the long-suffering Hanika. At the last count, Hanika was still awaiting the second computer and a pair of loudspeakers. Consumer's attempts to re-contact the friendly Dell spokesman ended in a recorded message declaring the call would be transferred to voicemail - only the recipient did not subscribe to this service.

Perhaps Hanika should heed the advice of John Davies of Lancaster who urges technophiles to avoid mail order and high-street suppliers and order their computers from a local firm who will assemble them near home. "Why," he wonders, "order one from an unknown, untried business on the other side of the country which uses possibly dodgy delivery firms and which you cannot visit if things go wrong?"

Pyjama game

Readers of last week's column should be experts on the pitfalls of shopping in cyberspace. Alas, ordering goods by that old-fashioned 20th century method, mail order, is not necessarily any safer. Untold numbers have complained to us over the months that their goods did not turn up, or that wrong ones did, or that they arrived in unwanted multiples along with a correspondingly exaggerated bill.

At the beginning of November, Sally Chadwick Pugh ordered goods from the Liverpool-based firm Pets Pyjamas, which promises next-day delivery or free goods if the wait is longer than three days. Five weeks later she had heard nothing. On her first follow-up call she was told a sudden influx of orders had led to a backlog; the second time that her goods were stuck in the despatch room for no obvious reason and she would be sent a £10 voucher; the third time that her order had never been received in the first place; the fourth that the items were out of stock and the fifth that a sudden influx of orders . . . Still neither the goods nor the voucher appeared and on impulse she rang the order line anonymously to be told goods would be delivered within three days and there was no backlog.

Consumer meets with similar coyness. Call number one elicits a customer service telephonist who declares she is not allowed to give out the number for head of office, or to tell me who she will be referring me to. Needless to say the promised call-back never happens. Call number two meets with the same response, but at least this time the company's PR is put in touch. Charles Fallon, managing director, explains the warehouse system was being changed when Pugh placed her order and that caused her goods to disappear. She has now received her goods free and a £15 voucher. "Solutions are now in place to ensure problems like this won't happen again," Fallon says enigmatically.

C&W: Calls still queueing

MJ Burton of Brighton signed up for cable television and telephone in September. The installation was supposed to take place in October, but since then all he has received from our old friends is a monthly bill for £00.00p. "The number they gave me reports as no longer connected and all the other lines remain busy for longer than the five minutes I am prepared to devote," he says.

Andrew Armstrong of London has been hanging on the line for up to 45 minutes over the past three months with no more success. He made his request for cable TV and telephone in October and was granted the former in November. Three months on he is still awaiting a telephone line, despite 15 exploratory phone calls. "They've come round six times, four of them without prior appointment," he says. "The last time they arrived unannounced at 8am, made a few calls on their mobiles for 45 minutes, then told me they needed to call an external contractor. This made me an hour late for my new job and when I got home I found a note from C&W telling me I'd have to wait another six to eight weeks!"

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: A bumper crop of idle gossip, harvested from today's papers and webpages.
fields.trailText: Teamtalk Zinedine Zidane has expressed interest in a move to Liverpool. "I would love to move to the Premiership with my gaffer being a fellow Frenchman," he told the Italian press. "I adore the coaching skills that he [Gerard Houllier] has shown for PSG, France, and most importantly, at the present for Liverpool."
fields.body:
Teamtalk Zinedine Zidane has expressed interest in a move to Liverpool. "I would love to move to the Premiership with my gaffer being a fellow Frenchman," he told the Italian press. "I adore the coaching skills that he [Gerard Houllier] has shown for PSG, France, and most importantly, at the present for Liverpool."

Daily Express Manchester United are planning a move for Real Madrid's Roberto Carlos. The Brazilian full-back is out of contract in the summer and has yet to agree a new deal at the Bernabeu. With Carlos said to be seeking a new challenge, Ferguson is ready to make the 26-year-old his replacement for the ageing Denis Irwin.

Prolific Brazilian striker Mario Jardel could be set for a move to Leeds in the summer. Jardel, who currently plays for Porto, is head and shoulders above the competition in the Portuguese league and has confessed his desire for a move. "I'm not going to lie and say that I don't have an ambition to play in a more competitive league," he said.

The Mirror Several of Manchester United's younger stars could be offloaded by the club. Mark Wilson, Jonathan Greening, Michael Clegg, and John Curtis have all been made available by Alex Ferguson as he looks to bring new faces to the club. Greening, in particular, is already attracting interest from Celtic.

Egil Olsen sees Nottingham Forest's Mark Crossley as the ideal replacement for Neil Sullivan in the Wimbledon goal. Sullivan is set to leave the Dons under the Bosman ruling this summer, and the 30-year-old Crossley is ready to sever his 13-year association with the City ground.

Daily Mail Manchester United are ready to make a move for unsettled Lazio defender Fernando Couto. Couto's agent has contacted several European clubs, advertising the Portuguese international's availability, following a training-ground fight with teammate Diego Simeone.

The Sun Huddersfield striker Marcus Stewart has been targeted by Ipswich as the man to shoot them into the Premiership. The Terriers' boss, Steve Bruce, has already turned down a £2.5m offer from Bradford for the 27-year-old, but a bid in the region of £2.8m could force his hand.

webTitle: 26 all out and the winning no-ball

fields.headline: 26 all out and the winning no-ball
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Can you give some details of the lowest Test innings - New Zealand's 26 all out? asks Andrew Brown
fields.body:
Can you give some details of the lowest Test innings - New Zealand's 26 all out? asks Andrew Brown

After overcoming Australia to retain the Ashes in 1954-55, Len Hutton's England team moved on to New Zealand for two Tests. In the second, at Auckland in March 1955, Hutton wouldn't have been pleased when his side were bowled out for 246 in reply to New Zealand's modest 200. He was much happier 106 minutes later, as NZ were bundled out for 26: Frank Tyson and Brian Statham, the new-ball pair who had demolished the Aussies, did the early damage, helped by the deceptive medium-pace of Yorkshire's Bob Appleyard. Here's the amazing scorecard:

B Sutcliffe b Wardle 11
JG Leggat c Hutton b Tyson 1
MB Poore b Tyson 0
JR Reid b Statham 1
SN McGregor c May b Appleyard 1
*GO Rabone lbw b Statham 7
HB Cave c Graveney b Appleyard 5
AR MacGibbon lbw b Appleyard 0
+IA Colquhoun c Graveney b Appleyard 0
AM Moir not out 0
JA Hayes b Statham 0
Extras 0 Total 26

Bowling: Tyson 7-2-10-2, Statham 9-3-9-3, Appleyard 6-3-7-4, Wardle 5-5-0-1

Fall: 1-6 2-8 3-9 4-14 5-14 6-22 7-22 8-22 9-26 10-26

Have there been any instances when a no-ball or a wide was the winning run in a Test? asks Winston Chow from Singapore

It does happen occasionally - sometimes deliberately. Perhaps the oddest instance in Test cricket came at Bridgetown in 1982-83, when West Indies needed only one run in their second innings to beat India. Syed Kirmani, the Indian wicketkeeper, came on to bowl for the first time in Test cricket, and his second delivery was a no-ball, which won the match for West Indies. Kirmani was left with the odd-looking bowling figures of 0.1-0-0-0 (no-balls didn't count against the bowler then).

In which other sport did WG Grace captain England? ask Chris and Liz Bateman

In his youth WG was an impressive allround athlete who excelled over the hurdles on the athletics track. He was also capable of throwing the cricket ball over 100 yards - with either hand. But it was at bowls that he captained England, after his cricket Test career was finished.

Who was voted Young Cricketer of the Year in 1963? asks Colin Herbert

The Cricket Writers' Club's Young Cricketer of the Year for 1963 was one Geoffrey Boycott, 22, who had just finished second in the national first-class averages with 1628 runs at 45.22 in his first full season for Yorkshire. He played the first of his 108 Test matches the following year. In those days there wasn't a worldwide award.

Is it true that a Test match was once left drawn because one team had to leave to catch the boat home? asks David Slater

It actually happened twice. The most famous occasion was the "Timeless Test" of 1938-39 at Durban, when England, set 696 to win by South Africa, had reached 654-5 on the tenth day when they had to leave to catch the train to Cape Town to meet the boat home. But it had also happened nine years before, in Jamaica. England batted first and made 849 (Andy Sandham 325, the first Test triple-century). West Indies then made 286, but England, 563 ahead, didn't enforce the follow-on: instead they batted again and made 272-9. The declaration left West Indies the little matter of 836 to win: by the end of the seventh day they had reached 408-5 (George Headley 223). Rain washed out the next two days, at which point England had to go home - so another "Timeless Test" was left drawn.

I am trying to complete a quiz and cannot verify one of my answers. The question is "Italian gypsy (or member of a cricket club)?" I know that "zingaro" is Italian for gypsy, but what's the link with cricket? asks Phil Heathcote

The link is the I Zingari Cricket Club, which was one of the first "wandering" club sides. It's nomadic nature - it has no home ground - probably led to the "gypsy" link. I Zingari was particularly strong at the end of the 19th century, when it played several first-class matches, and the club still exists today. For many years the secretary remained anonymous: the only way to contact him (or her) was to address a letter to "A.Secret, c/o Lord's Cricket Ground".

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly
fields.bodyText: Can you give some details of the lowest Test innings - New Zealand's 26 all out? asks Andrew Brown After overcoming Australia to retain the Ashes in 1954-55, Len Hutton's England team moved on to New Zealand for two Tests. In the second, at Auckland in March 1955, Hutton wouldn't have been pleased when his side were bowled out for 246 in reply to New Zealand's modest 200. He was much happier 106 minutes later, as NZ were bundled out for 26: Frank Tyson and Brian Statham, the new-ball pair who had demolished the Aussies, did the early damage, helped by the deceptive medium-pace of Yorkshire's Bob Appleyard. Here's the amazing scorecard: B Sutcliffe b Wardle 11 JG Leggat c Hutton b Tyson 1 MB Poore b Tyson 0 JR Reid b Statham 1 SN McGregor c May b Appleyard 1 *GO Rabone lbw b Statham 7 HB Cave c Graveney b Appleyard 5 AR MacGibbon lbw b Appleyard 0 +IA Colquhoun c Graveney b Appleyard 0 AM Moir not out 0 JA Hayes b Statham 0 Extras 0 Total 26 Bowling: Tyson 7-2-10-2, Statham 9-3-9-3, Appleyard 6-3-7-4, Wardle 5-5-0-1 Fall: 1-6 2-8 3-9 4-14 5-14 6-22 7-22 8-22 9-26 10-26 Have there been any instances when a no-ball or a wide was the winning run in a Test? asks Winston Chow from Singapore It does happen occasionally - sometimes deliberately. Perhaps the oddest instance in Test cricket came at Bridgetown in 1982-83, when West Indies needed only one run in their second innings to beat India. Syed Kirmani, the Indian wicketkeeper, came on to bowl for the first time in Test cricket, and his second delivery was a no-ball, which won the match for West Indies. Kirmani was left with the odd-looking bowling figures of 0.1-0-0-0 (no-balls didn't count against the bowler then). In which other sport did WG Grace captain England? ask Chris and Liz Bateman In his youth WG was an impressive allround athlete who excelled over the hurdles on the athletics track. He was also capable of throwing the cricket ball over 100 yards - with either hand. But it was at bowls that he captained England, after his cricket Test career was finished. Who was voted Young Cricketer of the Year in 1963? asks Colin Herbert The Cricket Writers' Club's Young Cricketer of the Year for 1963 was one Geoffrey Boycott, 22, who had just finished second in the national first-class averages with 1628 runs at 45.22 in his first full season for Yorkshire. He played the first of his 108 Test matches the following year. In those days there wasn't a worldwide award. Is it true that a Test match was once left drawn because one team had to leave to catch the boat home? asks David Slater It actually happened twice. The most famous occasion was the "Timeless Test" of 1938-39 at Durban, when England, set 696 to win by South Africa, had reached 654-5 on the tenth day when they had to leave to catch the train to Cape Town to meet the boat home. But it had also happened nine years before, in Jamaica. England batted first and made 849 (Andy Sandham 325, the first Test triple-century). West Indies then made 286, but England, 563 ahead, didn't enforce the follow-on: instead they batted again and made 272-9. The declaration left West Indies the little matter of 836 to win: by the end of the seventh day they had reached 408-5 (George Headley 223). Rain washed out the next two days, at which point England had to go home - so another "Timeless Test" was left drawn. I am trying to complete a quiz and cannot verify one of my answers. The question is "Italian gypsy (or member of a cricket club)?" I know that "zingaro" is Italian for gypsy, but what's the link with cricket? asks Phil Heathcote The link is the I Zingari Cricket Club, which was one of the first "wandering" club sides. It's nomadic nature - it has no home ground - probably led to the "gypsy" link. I Zingari was particularly strong at the end of the 19th century, when it played several first-class matches, and the club still exists today. fields.headline: Preferential treatment? We'd rather not
fields.standfirst: Jack Straw's late conversion to extending anti-discrimination laws does nothing to increase his credibility
fields.trailText: The war against racism in the public sector is over. It's official; we can all go home, or at least focus our energies elsewhere.
fields.body:
The war against racism in the public sector is over. It's official; we can all go home, or at least focus our energies elsewhere.

Last night, in the race relations (amendment) bill, Jack Straw announced that every part of the public sector will be subject to anti-discrimination laws. Not only will indirect discrimination no longer be tolerated but the public sector will be duty bound to promote equality among all races.

Everything from local council employment policies to police stop and search practices will have to be clearly thought through before being acted upon, and if they are found to discriminate against particular racial groups they risk expensive legal action.

According to Mr Straw, "the government has always been in favour of this principle, but has been concerned that the provisions were effective without leaving public bodies open to routine legal challenge where their policies were entirely proper." And there's the rub. Mr Straw is basically saying he is worried about an avalanche of legal challenges from litigious black people claiming institutional racism. In which case, why did he make the amendment in the first place?

The answer is simple. Only last week, 6 years after the murder of Stephen Lawrence and nearly a year on from Macpherson, Mr Straw was holding fast that there was no need to include institutional racism in the race relations law. It took the threat of a highly embarrassing revolt by the black and Asian Labour peers in the House of Lords to change his mind.

Mr Straw's concern about a rash of legal action pre-empts the cries of "political correctness gone mad" sure to emanate from the rightwing. Does he really think black and Asian people need to start making up racist incidents? If only.

Already this month both Neville Lawrence, father of Stephen, and John Sentamu, Anglican Bishop of Stepney and the only black member of the Lawrence inquiry, have been subject to what they described as humiliating stop and searches by the police.

And yet the police have been complaining that post-Macpherson has made them wary of using those powers. Obviously not wary enough.

The black and Asian communities will wait with bated breath to see if these laws really make a difference. In the meantime, worry not Mr Straw, we are not asking to be given preferential treatment. We won't start suing local authorities for allowing baa baa black sheep to be sung in schools. In fact, what we really want is for the preferential treatment to stop.

Special report

Race in Britain

fields.headline: Woody Allen: Broadway Danny Rose
fields.trailText: It is one of Allen's most perfect films... perhaps I like it so much because it lacks the ambition that besets Allen from time to time
fields.body:
Despite the often cruel strictures of many American critics, who seem to think him a bore, I couldn't contemplate a list of favourite films without one from Woody Allen. He is, after all, one of the most fluent directors in the US and certainly a funnier man than Jim Carrey, Steve Martin or Adam Sandler.

It may seem a little eccentric to choose Broadway Danny Rose for my Century of Films above the much-Oscared Annie Hall, or perhaps Manhattan. It is, however, one of Allen's most perfect films, a comedy about New York's legendary talent agent who gets hold of a washed up crooner and propels him back into near-stardom. Allen plays Danny not as the usual Woody character, full of self-doubt, but as a minor wizard who could make a piano-playing bird into a genuine celebrity. Enthusiasm is Danny's middle name.

Perhaps I like this film so much because it lacks the ambition that besets Allen from time to time, causing the kind of hollow copy of Bergman that was Interiors, or the cold proficiency of the admittedly very clever Zelig. Besides, it's an incredibly true portrayal of the lower reaches of showbiz - always more fascinating than the higher echelons (as John Osborne realised when he wrote The Entertainer). And if you're the sort of person who wants to hear what the loser has to say rather than the winner, then either Broadway Danny Rose or Radio Days come high on the list of unselfconscious but precisely observed Allen films.

Nick Apollo Forte is Lou Canova, a singer not of the first rank, and an alcoholic. He has both a long-suffering wife and a mistress who belongs to a Mafia hood. He's so good an actor that you wonder what became of him, just as you wonder what becomes of Lou when Danny finally has to give up on him. He and Woody are the centre of this celebration of a Broadway not too far from Damon Runyan. Around them are spread the out-of-work no hopers, the vicious and ungrateful success stories, the dumb showgirls and the even dumber gangsters we've come to know so well in lesser if much more portentous movies.

The film starts marvellously, with a group of comics sitting around a Carnegie Deli table trading stories about Danny and his exploits on behalf of his clients. Since Allen wrote the script, even the made-up tales are funny. Then we see how Danny gets Lou on the road again, riding the nostalgia boom of the time, booking him into Top 40 concerts and finally finding him a date at the Waldorf, with Milton Berle in the audience looking for guests for his TV special.

Lou trying to persuade Danny to take his girlfriend to the Waldorf so she won't get upset is another hilarious sequence. But if he's good - a drunken egotist with a heart of silver - so is Mia Farrow as the girl, a brassy Mafia blonde with a taste in hair and dress styles that might suit the fashion sense of a lowly henchman of Capone.

In all, this is a film which inhabits New York just as well as Annie Hall but looks at a different kind of instantly recognisable inhabitant. Perhaps it sails near caricature at times. But then so does the world we're observing. As for Danny Rose himself, this is one of Woody's most actorly performances. For once he forgets himself and plays someone else. This isn't to downgrade his other good films. Just to say that sometimes small is best.

fields.headline: Why the Discworld needs PCs
fields.standfirst: Terry Pratchett is the best-selling author of humorous fantasy books. He has a huge, devoted following for his Discworld series
fields.trailText: Terry Pratchett is the best-selling author of humorous fantasy books. He has a huge, devoted following for his Discworld series
fields.body:
How long have you been using computers? Since about 1982. I started with a Sinclair ZX81 which allowed me to do very primitive word processing. Next was an Amstrad CPC464 - the first model with an integral tape drive. It was actually not a bad little machine. I wrote a couple of books on it. Then I graduated to PC.

What are you running now? Because I have everything networked, defunct machines just become another node on the network. We have a couple of 400Mhz Pentium IIs - I work in two locations in my house, I have a study and a business office. I also have a couple of older Pentium machines because it costs very little to put a card in and add them to the network. I call one of them "the dog". Anything I'm a little uncertain of is tried out on "the dog" first when it's cut away from the network.

Could you envisage working without a computer again? Good heavens no! I used to word-process even in the days of my old Imperial 58 typewriter. I used lots of different coloured typing paper and literally cut and pasted. By the time I came to type what might be the fourth or fifth draft, the manuscript was a very strange looking thing about two inches thick and full of paper glued together.

Does it make writing easier? Yes. I was chairman of the Society of Authors for a while and there is a divide, even now, among authors, between those that won't touch a keyboard and those that, like me, almost go the other way with technology. I think the advantage is that everything is so mutable. You can spend your whole life changing sentences if you want. But, because editing is so easy, you can also write on auto-pilot. Sometimes it's a good thing to sit there pounding out the stuff straight from your subconscious but the important thing is that ,next day, you have to sit down and very carefully go through what you did. So you can use the word processor in several ways and adapt it to your way of working.

Are we over-impressed by technology? I think newspapers are. It seems general internet use is actually taking off and that's because people are now finding useful things to do with it. Yet the idea that the "e-world" was just around the corner has been peddled for about five or six years now. It wasn't the hype that did this, it's just that a critical mass has been reached. But it's not whether or not you can use a computer, it's whether your granny can use one that things then become interesting.

Any favourite places on the net? I think surfing the web is a dull thing. It's not proper surfing unless you're going to run into a 12 foot wall of coral. It's another one of those stupid terms we have to make sitting on your arse all evening sound exciting: "We're going to boot up the computer." No you're not, you're just going to switch it on. It's like getting excited about using a telephone! It's worth remembering, when we talk about Mr Gates's brave new world, that there are still people on the planet who have yet to make their first phone call - and they're probably in the majority.

fields.headline: Obituary: Frank MacShane
fields.standfirst: A mission to reclaim lost literary reputations
fields.trailText: Frank MacShane, who has died aged 72, wrote resurrectionist biographies of Ford Madox Ford, Raymond Chandler, John O'Hara and James Jones between 1965 and 1985. MacShane was seeking to reclaim the reputation of writers who had once enjoyed status or sales, but had either failed to be taken seriously, or whose later careers had gone awry.
fields.body:
Frank MacShane, who has died aged 72, wrote resurrectionist biographies of Ford Madox Ford, Raymond Chandler, John O'Hara and James Jones between 1965 and 1985. MacShane was seeking to reclaim the reputation of writers who had once enjoyed status or sales, but had either failed to be taken seriously, or whose later careers had gone awry.

Apart from Ford, his subjects were a trio of hard-drinking, self-destructive men, troubled and unhappy in their dealings with women. And it was the women who seemed to bring coherence to MacShane as a biographer. When he wrote of Cissy Chandler, desperately trying to hide the 20-year difference in age between herself and her husband Raymond, or of Gloria Mosolino, the gorgeous, tough-talking, brash blonde who met James Jones while she was working on The Seven Year Itch as a stand-in for Marilyn Monroe, MacShane's pages come alive.

There was never a hint of Kitty Kelleyism about his work. Always reasonable, competent, decent, and earnest, one regrets the absence of malice or edge. MacShane's work was criticised for its lack of "critical acuity" and for the simplistic and platitudinous quality of his critical judgments.

MacShane grew up in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, the son of a journalist who became the publisher of the New York Journal-American, flagship of the Hearst newspaper chain. He graduated from Harvard in 1949, received a master's degree at Yale, and was awarded a DPhil at Oxford in 1955. He taught at McGill University in Montreal for two years, was a visiting lecturer in English at Vassar College in 1958-59, and then was appointed an associate professor at the University of California at Berkeley.

By that time MacShane had begun his Ford biography. Though he interviewed many people who had known Ford, his is essentially a story told from published sources. Though warmly received, subsequent biographies of Ford have a stronger claim on our attention.

"If you want to know what California is like, read Raymond Chandler." MacShane received this advice not long after he moved to Berkeley. When his Chandler biography appeared in 1976, the novelist had begun to receive enthusiastic critical attention. MacShane presented him as a major writer who "rose from the blank anonymity of America". Overcoming a "tortured and lonely life," Chandler became a writer whose vision of America has grown in persuasive power. The Life Of Raymond Chandler was MacShane's book most likely to endure.

His plea to take the life and perceptions of O'Hara seriously was a harder sell. By praising O'Hara's precinct cop who picks up a phone and asks "Wukkan I do fya?" MacShane put his finger on what was least authentic in the writer's documentation of American life.

MacShane taught at Williams College from 1965-67, then went to Columbia University. There he founded the graduate writing division and taught creative writing. He published translations of Miguel Serrano, co-edited Borges On Writing, and edited two volumes of American travel writing.

He remained an enthusiastic and dedicated teacher until Alzheimer's disease ended his academic career in 1992.

He is survived by his son Nicholas.

 Frank MacShane, biographer, born October 19 1927; died November 15 1999

fields.headline: Gas chambers 'that never were'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the David Irving libel trial
fields.trailText: Witness evidence of gas chambers at Auschwitz was "totally demolished" because there were no holes in the roof through which to insert poison, the historian David Irving told the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
Witness evidence of gas chambers at Auschwitz was "totally demolished" because there were no holes in the roof through which to insert poison, the historian David Irving told the high court yesterday.

Mr Irving, the 62-year-old author of Hitler's War, who is seeking libel damages for being called a "Holocaust denier" and a "falsifier of history", said that his theory "blows holes in the whole gas chambers story".

"Revisionist" researchers had entered the ruins of crematorium two at Auschwitz, in which Holocaust historians say 500,000 died, and photographed the collapsed underside of the roof - but found no holes.

"I do not accept that the Nazis in the last frantic days of the camp, when they were in a blue funk, would have gone around with buckets of cement filling the holes that they were going to dynamite."

Mr Irving, who is representing himself, was cross-examining Robert van Pelt, who has said that there was a "massive amount of evidence" of the camp's use for mass extermination.

Prof van Pelt has said that the gas chambers were dismantled and then dynamited when the gassing stopped in November 1944 as the Russians advanced.

Giving evidence for the American academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books, who are fighting Mr Irving's action, he says the evidence for gassing included witness accounts, photographs and drawings from memory of a sonderkommando - a Jewish inmate selected to work in the crematoria.

He referred Mr Justice Gray to a photograph taken by an SS man in February 1943 which showed openings above ground on the newly completed roof of crematorium two with a cover on top of them. The defence case is that these projections were from four introduction columns through which Zyklon B pellets were passed.

Mr Irving, who says that the gas chambers were only used to de-louse corpses, claimed the picture was taken in December 1942 during building works and that the objects were drums of sealant.

Prof van Pelt also relied on an aerial photograph taken by the Americans in the summer of 1944 which showed "four dots" on the roof of crematorium two. He said that this showed clearly that there were "introduction devices" on top of the building.

Mr Irving questioned the authenticity of the photograph and said the dots were too big for the purpose put forward by the defence.

The hearing was adjourned until tomorrow.

He said that this showed clearly that there were "introduction devices" on top of the building. webTitle: A head of her time:  Face of Saxon girl rebuilt

fields.headline: A head of her time:  Face of Saxon girl rebuilt
fields.standfirst: See the face
fields.trailText: The face of a Saxon girl who died about a thousand years ago has been reconstructed from her skull. The remains of the child, who died after a short life of pain and disease, were excavated last summer from a burial ground in Buckinghamshire.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The face of a Saxon girl who died about a thousand years ago has been reconstructed from her skull. The remains of the child, who died after a short life of pain and disease, were excavated last summer from a burial ground in Buckinghamshire.

Caroline Wilkinson, of the team at Manchester university which has become world leaders in the science of facial reconstruction, recreated the head. Thousands of measurements were logged on computer of adult measurements, but none were known for children, whose bone and tissue structure differ from adults. Ms Wilkinson measured dozens of living children, some from the school within 100 yards of where the Saxon child was buried.

The science of facial reconstruction developed from forensic medicine, to produce recognisable images of unidentified corpses.

Archaeologist Julian Richards, of BBC 2's Meet the Ancestors, which commissioned the head, said children are rarely involved in such cases, so there was no data. The skull was found in an archaeological survey of a site in the village of Wing in Buckinghamshire, now a commuter suburb of London, but in Saxon times a remote agricultural holding wealthy enough to build a stone church.

Planning permission had been given for a new house on the site of the demolished Victorian village school, on the edge of the church graveyard.

Records showed no evidence of earlier use of the site, but the Saxon graveyard was more than twice the size of the medieval graveyard, when the population would generally be expected to be larger.

Dr Richards said: "We found no evidence of plague or any disaster." The skull was chosen for reconstruction because the skeleton, found in the same grave as an adult skeleton which proved to be a century older, was exceptionally well preserved. It has been dated to the end of the 9th century. DNA evidence from the teeth proved the child was 11 or 12 rather than seven or eight as first thought. Her bones and pitted teeth showed signs of a life of pain, weakness and repeated serious illness.

The crypt of the church is one of the oldest in the country, and may have had a shrine containing relics of a saint.

Dr Richards and local historians believe the child could have been brought to the shrine in hope of a cure.

Lost Souls, part of the Meet the Ancestors archaeology series, will be shown on BBC 2 tonight.

fields.headline: Byers sets out euro timetable
fields.trailText: A re-elected Labour government would assess "early in the next parliament" whether Britain was ready to join the European single currency, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers indicated today.
fields.body:
A re-elected Labour government would assess "early in the next parliament" whether Britain was ready to join the European single currency, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers indicated today.

In a speech to the pro-single currency Britain in Europe group, Mr Byers, seen as one of the cabinet members most enthusiastic about the euro, sketched out a rough timetable for possible British entry.

His speech to an audience in the City of London came after what has been seen as a cooling of the government's attitude towards the euro. Several ministers have sounded more sceptical in recent speeches, leading to speculation that the government would delay a decision. But in this afternoon's speech, Mr Byers insisted that the government's position was consistent. In principle, the government favoured joining the euro, he said.

But the series of steps - including a referendum - which would precede British entry, could be triggered only by the fulfilment of the five economic tests laid out by the chancellor Gordon Brown in October 1997.

 monetary union must create better investment conditions in the UK
 the euro must not harm the country's financial service industry
 business cycles and economic structures in the UK and Europe must be compatible
 the euro must provide flexibility
 the single currency must help to promote higher growth, more jobs and economic stability.

Mr Byers promised that, if Labour was returned to office at the next election, it would assess whether the conditions of those tests had been met shortly afterwards.

"Britain should be part of a successful single currency provided the economic conditions have been met and the people give their consent in a referendum. But the five economic tests have to be met," he told the audience.

"We will consider if the five tests have been met early in the next parliament. If the economic tests are satisfied then we could join a successful single currency if that is what the government, parliament and the people decide," he said.

But Mr Byers emphasised that the commitment to make an assessment on the economic conditions early in the next parliament did not mean that the government would arrange a referendum immediately after the general election.

"It would be wrong for any government to bounce the British people into a referendum on the euro in the immediate aftermath of the next general election. A clear distinction must be drawn between the two."

Mr Byers's speech came after Europe's leading companies were warned that they needed to take "dramatic action" to protect their profits in the face of the change-over to the euro.

A report by KPMG Consulting, based on a Europe-wide survey of 300 large companies, said it was "astonishing" that firms had shown little urgency in tackling the threats posed by the new business climate.

But it added that the average bill faced by large firms, employing more than 5,000 staff, for converting to European monetary union was more than £34 million.

Shadow chancellor Francis Maude warned that Britain's economy was currently incompatible with that of continental Europe.

"Britain's economy, in its fundamentals, in its interest rates cycle and business cycle, is much more closely aligned with North America than it is with the continent of Europe," said Mr Maude.

webTitle: £100bn cost put on switch to euro

fields.headline: £100bn cost put on switch to euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The government's struggle to convince voters of the benefits of the single currency received a fresh setback today when the cost of converting British business to the euro was put at up to £100bn.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson, Larry Elliott  and Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
The government's struggle to convince voters of the benefits of the single currency received a fresh setback today when the cost of converting British business to the euro was put at up to £100bn.

On the day that the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, was due to rally support for a more positive approach to Europe, a leading firm of City management consultants said the bill for joining the monetary union would be five times the £20bn spent in the nationwide effort to beat the millennium bug.

KPMG consulting said the huge outlay on new IT systems and the impact of lower prices would cost big companies an average of £34.2m and could put at jeopardy investment in new technologies designed to make them competitive in the growing e-commerce sector.

The report, which ironically was released to coincide with a keynote speech on Europe by Mr Byers at KPMG, was seized on by the Conservatives, who demanded that the government scrap its national changeover plan.

Although the government is sticking by its "prepare and decide" strategy, new evidence of the costs of conversion will strengthen the hand of those cabinet ministers - led by the chancellor, Gordon Brown - who are arguing for a low-key approach to the issue in the run-up to the election.

Although KPMG stressed that there could be long-term benefits from monetary union for consumers and companies, the findings are likely to discomfort Mr Byers, who has cited pressure from big business as a reason for the government to be more upbeat about the euro.

Mr Byers recently stretched the government's cautious stance on euro - that a referendum will only be held once a series of economic conditions have been met - by saying that foreign investors, especially those from Japan, are eager for Britain to sign up.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has also adopted a more aggressive pro-euro stance in recent months, arguing that Britain risks being isolated in Europe unless it makes its mind up on EMU membership quickly.

Mr Brown wants Labour's election campaign to focus on his successful management of the economy and on bread and butter policies such as the working families tax credit.

Francis Maude, the shadow chancellor, said: "These figures are an embarrassment to the government which is determined to conduct the debate on the euro without ever publishing a figure for what it would actually cost British business and the taxpayer. With polls showing the public becoming increasingly opposed to joining the single currency, the government should scrap their national changeover plan which was launched last year before a single vote has been cast in a referendum."

Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, the anti-euro lobby group, said: "The simple costs of changing to the euro are astronomical and rising. On top of that, there's all the other disadvantages of EMU such as the euro economies' bankrupt pensions systems."

Simon Buckby, campaign director of Britain in Europe, said: "This survey demonstrates that the single currency is already having an effect on price levels in the euro-zone. That is good news for consumers. Falling prices are one of the major potential benefits of joining a successful single currency."

fields.headline: American Beauty
fields.trailText: Xan Brooks: It may short-change Bening, but it covers Spacey in glory. Because what this flawed but compelling picture provides Spacey with is the opportunity to create a bona-fide American icon
fields.body:
Lester Burnham begins American Beauty masturbating in the family shower. He finishes it with a gun to his head. In between, this frustrated fortysomething - disliked by his wife, scorned by his daughter, humiliated by his colleagues - undergoes a startling metamorphosis. On the face of it, of course, Burnham is hardly the stuff of legend. But the real triumph of Sam Mendes' biting, bracing drama is the way it gives the everyman his due. Burnham's mid-life crisis is played as a suburban rejig of The Odyssey; a heroic mythic journey set down amid the strip-malls and side-streets of middle-class USA.

So Burnham (brilliantly embodied by Kevin Spacey) starts off a loser - twitchy, pallid, diminished - and winds up victorious. Except that it's never quite as simple as that. On the one hand it is even possible to view the man's rejuvenation as just another symptom of his decline. Burnham's life change is signalled by body building in his garage, blaring Pink Floyd from his flash new convertible, smoking grass outside a stuffy works party and a lusty pursuit of his daughter's cheerleader classmate (Mena Suvari). And yet what starts out as a middle-aged fantasy eventually blossoms into something more, the means by which its hero comes to terms with his predicament. In acting the teenager, Lester Burnham belatedly grows up.

Spacey dominates American Beauty with such a pointed, rigorous intensity that it's fitting that the film as a whole should parallel his character so closely. Thus American Beauty starts off in second gear - a caricatured cartoon of suburban hell that's neatly marshalled, but nothing new. For its first half, the psychology is a tad lazy, the satirical barbs a bit over-obvious. But with Burnham's transformation, Mendes's picture abruptly moves to a different level, rich and rounded and graceful. The plot moves with a smooth, hard trajectory. The sub-plot involving Burnham's daughter (Thora Birch) and the angsty kid across the road (Wes Bentley) gains weight and depth. Only Annette Bening is left stranded as American Beauty moves up through the gears. Throughout it all, she's constrained by a thankless role as the brittle, bitchy wife; an uptight Nurse Ratched figure the rebelling Lester can kick against.

American Beauty may short-change Bening, but it covers Spacey in glory. Because what this flawed but compelling picture provides Spacey with is the opportunity to create a bona-fide American icon. File Burnham alongside the likes of Gatsby or Norman Bates or Willy Loman - a fictional character who resonates beyond the immediate confines of his story. Not much to look at, Spacey's protagonist eventually emerges as a man of real significance. "I'm 42 years old, and in less than a year I'll be dead," he tells us in the opening scene. In between the little man grows in stature; a doomed hero come dazzlingly to life.

fields.headline: Scandal shifts to Schröder's party
fields.trailText: The spotlight on Germany's scandal-ridden politics yesterday swung to cast an uncomfortable glare on Gerhard Schröder's ruling Social Democrats.
fields.body:
The spotlight on Germany's scandal-ridden politics yesterday swung to cast an uncomfortable glare on Gerhard Schröder's ruling Social Democrats. The shift provided the opposition Christian Democrats with a brief respite from media attention and injected a whiff of sex scandal into the already heady atmosphere.

The Social Democrats' finance minister in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia was last night under pressure to resign after he confessed to having lied about accepting free flights for a woman companion. The SPD-led administration faces re-election in Germany's biggest state in May, in what is seen as a crucial test for both parties.

Heinz Schleusser, a long-standing member of the administration in North Rhine-Westphalia, is accused of accepting 49 free flights on a jet provided by a bank partly owned by the regional authorities. Local Christian Democrats yesterday joined an influential section of the press in demanding he step down.

Mr Schleusser, who is married, went back on an earlier denial that on two of the flights - to Croatia in 1990 and 1991 - he was accompanied by a woman friend. He apologised, and said he had lied to protect his family.

Bild newspaper reported that his companion was a telephonist at the trade union IG Metall. It said she was also the registered owner of a yacht valued at £85,000.

The affair once again highlighted the deep reluctance of German politicians to leave office, even when shown to be guilty of wrongdoing. The former chancellor Helmut Kohl, who has admitted failing to disclose some £680,000 in party contributions, remains an MP. His successor as head of the Christian Democrats, Wolfgang Schäuble, has refused to step down, despite confessing that he took a cash donation of £340,000 which he had omitted to mention in a statement to parliament.

A committee of MPs in North Rhine-Westphalia has been investigating whether senior SPD politicians benefited personally from flights paid for by the bank. It has already cleared Germany's president, Johannes Rau.

One of only two political bigwigs winkled from power recently is Gerhard Glogowski, a Social Democrat and former regional premier in Lower Saxony. He resigned last year after it was reported that local firms had paid for his wedding reception and honeymoon.

Yesterday, the state parliament voted to set up an inquiry into whether Mr Glogowski took financial advantage of his position.
