webTitle: Bountiful bosses race to give it away

fields.headline: Bountiful bosses race to give it away
fields.standfirst: Top hi-tech entrepreneurs are donating billions to charity. But is it really all magnanimous? HREF="http://www.newsunlimited.co.uk/efinance">E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It is the multi-billion dollar question that Bill Gates, Paul Allen, Jim Clark, Michael Dell and the growing bank of super-rich e-entrepreneurs are trying to answer. What, when you have bought every holiday home, car, yacht and private jet that you could ever possibly want, do you do with the billions of dollars in change you still have lying around? Increasingly the answer is: give it away.
fields.body:
It is the multi-billion dollar question that Bill Gates, Paul Allen, Jim Clark, Michael Dell and the growing bank of super-rich e-entrepreneurs are trying to answer. What, when you have bought every holiday home, car, yacht and private jet that you could ever possibly want, do you do with the billions of dollars in change you still have lying around? Increasingly the answer is: give it away.

Do a little bit for charity, something for mankind. Go down in history as something more than a brilliantly successful techno-geek. The race to give it away dot.com style has started, prompting one of the heaviest periods of charitable giving in history. "These guys are a new breed of businessmen who are giving away more money and at a younger age than the Carnegies and Rockefellers of generations before," said Stacy Palmer, editor of the Chronicle of Philanthropy in Washington DC. "This is just the beginning of what could be an extraordinary period of giving."

Endowed

Mr Gates has already said that he plans to give almost all of his $100bn (£62bn) fortune away and when earlier this week he and his wife Melinda gave a further $5bn to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, it surpassed Britain's Wellcome Trust as the most impressively-endowed foundation in the world.

The $21.8bn Mr Gates' foundation has at its disposal dwarfs those of any other new-technology philanthropists but the donations his colleagues and rivals have made are far from insignificant. Education, health and technological development are usually the causes of choice.

Netscape's Jim Clark recently gave Stanford University a cheque for $150m, Jim Barksdale - the man Mr Clark brought in to run Netscape - has pledged $100m to a literacy programme at the University of Mississippi. Mr Dell and his wife Sue have put aside $114m in Dell stock to promote arts and innovation in Central Texas plus children's health and education around the world.

Tim Gill, founder of Quark software, plans to give away his $1.1bn fortune. Most of it will go to helping gay and lesbian causes, he said.

Mr Gates' foundation, which is managed by his father, has spread its funds widely. In August it teamed up with media mogul Ted Turner to donate $78m towards a United Nations-World Health Organisation initiative to eradicate polio.

Vaccines

It has since committed $50m to the prevention of cervical cancer and $750m to a global children's vaccination programme.

"The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will continue to focus on helping to improve people's lives, primarily through health and learning," said Patty Stonesifer, the foundation's co-chair.

"Particular attention will go towards accelerating the development and distribution of life-saving vaccines. Other major efforts include extending unprecedented opportunities for learning by bringing computers with Internet access to every eligible public library in the US and Canada, and providing scholarships to academically talented minority students with severe financial need through the Gates Millennium Scholars Program."

Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, has six charitable foundations whose interests range from music to biotechnology. Investments include a national museum for rock 'n' roll in Seattle, numerous grants to protect local forests and rivers, and an Aids prevention charity in Los Angeles.

He has also bought his local NFL football team and the NBA basketball franchise for a combined fee of around $500m. "If people remembered me as someone who had fun working with people to develop new technologies, who tried to do positive things for the community, I would be satisfied," Mr Allen told reporters.

The Dells' spokeswoman, Tricia Knox, said their latest $100m donation was prompted by the couple's desire to "extend the charitable giving they have done in the past, and the foundation is a vehicle for them to do that a little bit further."

For cash-starved charities, health care projects and welfare initiatives in the United States - which lacks a European-style, government-funded welfare safety net - the private philanthropy is manna from heaven. However, some causes have failed to register in the radar. "President Clinton called a conference at the White House recently to tell hi-tech philanthropists to direct more of their resources towards the poor and needy homelessness and foodbanks," Ms Palmer said.

But some commentators suggest the "helping others" mantra many of the internet-rich preach is actually a cover for a "help thyself" approach. Mr Gates has been subjected to the most sniping. Many American columnists have questioned whether the recent acceleration in his charitable donations has anything to do with the pending judicial decision on the government filed anti-competition suit that Microsoft is fighting. They conclude, of course, that there is no connection.

fields.headline: Pearson spend rises by £250m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Pearson yesterday raised £250m to accelerate its investment in its internet-based businesses, including its relaunched flagship ft.com.
fields.body:
Pearson yesterday raised £250m to accelerate its investment in its internet-based businesses, including its relaunched flagship ft.com.

The media group, which publishes the Financial Times and the Economist, is planning a swath of new web services including an online education network and a push into the Spanish and Portuguese-speaking markets.

Pearson's finance director, John Makinson, said the cash would fund investments for up to two years focusing on the relaunch of ft.com, the company's online version of the FT, and other financial information sites during 2000.

Ft.com will relaunch in the next few weeks and has been showing compound growth of 20% a month in site visits. In January, the website had some 1.2m unique users compared to 200,000 a year ago.

"The message is that we are stepping up our rate of investment because it is beginning to pay off. We are emboldened particularly by the success of ft.com," Mr Makinson said.

Pearson was not about to ape its arch rival, the Wall Street Journal, by introducing online subscription fees. "The secret is to build and generate traffic to support substantial advertising and e-commerce revenues," he said.

"The $64,000 question is making money, but if you believe the internet will change the way people access financial information and that the FT brand has resonance, then we should be successful."

The funds were raised by placing 11.5m shares at £22 each. Pearson shares were marked down 62p at £22.60 in response to the new issue but analysts backed the strategy, describing the fall as only a short term reaction.

Marjorie Scardino, Pearson's chief executive, said: "Content and brands count more than ever in this world.

"It's not whether we are in old or new media, or online or offline that matters; it's how we use our content across all channels that will really count."

Pearson, which is one of the leading educational publishers in the world, hopes to exploit its market position via the launch of a network of educational websites linking students, parents and teachers.

Mr Makinson said Pearson was seeking a distribution partner to invest in the business and had already begun talks.

webTitle: Barclay boy joins the board at JellyWorks

fields.headline: Barclay boy joins the board at JellyWorks
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Barclay family, whose business interests include the Ritz hotel and Scotsman newspaper, have emerged as backers of fledgling internet investment group JellyWorks.
fields.body:
The Barclay family, whose business interests include the Ritz hotel and Scotsman newspaper, have emerged as backers of fledgling internet investment group JellyWorks.

Jonathan Rowland, the 24-year-old chief executive of Aim-listed JellyWorks, said yesterday that Howard Barclay, the son of David Barclay and nephew of Frederick, was joining the JellyWorks board as a non-executive director after investing £3m in cash.

"Joining the board of a public company is a major change of tack for the Barclays and illustrates how serious a stance they are taking with this whole new area," a spokesman for the Barclays said.

Mr Rowland said the move was the result of a long-term family friendship and business partnership between his father David "Spotty" Rowland and the Barclays.

"The Rowland and Barclay families have agreed to combine their skills to back JellyWorks, bringing together formidable track records and contacts," he said.

The two families had been friends and business associates for more than 30 years working on numerous deals "most of them before my time", Mr Rowland said.

Both families are now based in the Channel Islands and Mr Rowland emphasised that the cash injection has been made by Howard Barclay not his father or uncle.

Howard Barclay's only other directorship within the past five years was with Ellerman Investments, a former shipping line that now acts as the holding company for the Ritz and Howard hotels. He has recently been working closely with brother Aidan, the public face of the Barclay empire.

"Howard brings a whole new raft of networks and experience to JellyWorks. We will be speaking together about the business most days," Mr Rowland said.

Shares in JellyWorks have risen twenty-fold from their December placing price as investors have bet on Mr Rowland's ability to pick which of the myriad of unproven internet start-ups will become the technology stars of the future.

Last night shares in JellyWorks closed up 5% at 108p after it announced that it had paid £21.5m for a 20% stake in VMR, a German corporate finance house which has previously advised the Rowland family.

webTitle: Warning to GPs on anti-flu drug

fields.headline: Warning to GPs on anti-flu drug
fields.standfirst: Flu epidemic: special report
fields.trailText: The makers of Relenza, the anti-flu drug that was at the centre of a rationing row after it was rejected for use in the NHS this winter, have been forced to send out letters to all GPs warning of side-effects in people with asthma and other lung conditions.
fields.body:
The makers of Relenza, the anti-flu drug that was at the centre of a rationing row after it was rejected for use in the NHS this winter, have been forced to send out letters to all GPs warning of side-effects in people with asthma and other lung conditions.

Problems have arisen in some patients at most risk from influenza - those with asthma or chronic pulmonary disease. About one in 1,000 have suffered from tightness in the chest, bronchospasm or difficulty in breathing.

In letters to GPs, the manufacturer, Glaxo Wellcome, is stressing that patients with underlying lung problems should have a fast-acting bronchodilator (inhaler) to hand. If they are asthmatics who use inhalers regularly, they should use them before taking Relenza, a powder which is also inhaled.

Concerns about the side-effects in vulnerable patents were first voiced by the US food and drugs administration, but have since been taken up by the European regulatory authorities, who asked the manufacturers to warn doctors.

Relenza is a licensed drug but fell foul of the national institute for clinical excellence, set up last year by government. In its first decision last autumn, the institute advised that GPs should not prescribe Relenza on the NHS, although the ruling is not binding on them.

Nice's objection was that Glaxo Wellcome had done insufficient trials on the group of patients most at risk from influenza - the elderly and the frail.

If there are doubts over the suitability of the flu drug for asthmatics and people with lung conditions, it will prove even harder for Glaxo Wellcome - and Roche, which has developed a similar drug - to satisfy the institute when these come up for a full appraisal in the autumn.

Worldwide, around 500,000 prescriptions for Relenza have been written, over half in the US.

In the UK, there have only been around 8,000, the vast majority private.

fields.headline: Journalists' incentive
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Pearson is working on an innovative options package for journalists working in its web-based businesses as a means of combating the drain of talent to net start-ups.
fields.body:
Pearson is working on an innovative options package for journalists working in its web-based businesses as a means of combating the drain of talent to net start-ups.

The media group said yesterday it had come up with an "internet-style" rewards package after rejecting plans to either float off the web businesses or issue a tracking stock. The plans will be presented to staff in the next few weeks.

The Financial Times in particular has been hit by high level defections to start-ups. Most notable was the Lex columnist, Hugo Dixon, who took colleague Jonathan Ford with him to Breakingviews.com.

Finance director John Makinson said Pearson was aware of the growing clamour for equity. "We are having to be creative. This is a very interesting challenge facing every media company, and so far there is no perfect answer."

The options packages will centre on Pearson shares but, Mr Makinson said, will try to replicate the features of net start-ups. He said the "two rules of thumb in the internet market" are that the scheme should be very simple and that individuals should be able to exercise the options very quickly.

FT.com - which has recruited a large number of journalists in recent months - has found it difficult to recruit senior people, and writers on the paper frequently find themselves writing across both media.

webTitle: Fed chief claims US has lead in cyberspace race

fields.headline: Fed chief claims US has lead in cyberspace race
fields.trailText: American companies have stolen a lead over their European counterparts in the race for cyberspace because US business is unencumbered by rigid labour laws, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Alan Greenspan said last night.
fields.body:
American companies have stolen a lead over their European counterparts in the race for cyberspace because US business is unencumbered by rigid labour laws, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Alan Greenspan said last night.

Using unusually critical language at a hearing of the senate banking committee, Mr Greenspan said technology was not being applied as fully in Europe as in the United States, in part because labour laws made it hard for firms to sack workers and take advantage of technology-driven productivity gains.

"They end up with double-digit unemployment... and they also end up with a level of capital stock which is much lower than ours," Mr Greenspan said. "The technologies which now exist in the United States... are not being applied to the extent that they are in the United States, and therefore the growth and the underlying improvement is less than it is in the United States."

But Mr Greenspan also said attitudes were changing. "They are beginning to sense that that is wrong and you are beginning to see countervailing forces emerging in Europe which will gradually bring down a lot of the dirigiste attitudes on the part of a number of government officials in Europe," he said.

The Fed chairman cited the European Union's efforts to drag its businesses into the internet age. "The European Union is going to increasingly seek a type of technology that we have in the United States and that process almost invariably will open up markets."

The words will be music to the ears of Erkki Liikanen, EU commissioner for industry and information society, who is launching a modernising agenda for e-commerce in Europe. He says he wants Europe to learn from the experience of the US, where internet-related companies today account for 2.3m direct jobs - not count ing the considerable indirect employment. The legislation should be completed but the end of the year.

The US government has long urged European countries to make labour laws more flexible, but the Fed has usually been somewhat more restrained. Mr Greenspan also raised concerns about the recent increase in margin debt or borrowing to buy shares in US markets.

Charles Schumer, a Democrat senator from New York, said margin debt had increased 62% in the past year - the fastest pace in 16 years - and margin debt rose 13.2% in November and 10.8% in December.

"It is certainly the case that the numbers that you cite - especially for November and December - have caught our attention. They have moved up at a pace which has created a good deal of evaluation on our part," Mr Greenspan said. There had been "considerable discussions" among financial regulators in Washington on the topic. He said the Fed was "obviously" worried about this.

fields.headline: Right note
fields.standfirst:
Chandra bids for Ronnie Wood's net music interests Groovetech
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood and his manager, the entertainment lawyer Nick Cowan, have received a takeover approach for their American internet dance music company from cash-shell Chandra.
fields.body:
Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood and his manager, the entertainment lawyer Nick Cowan, have received a takeover approach for their American internet dance music company from cash-shell Chandra.

Aim-listed Chandra has approached Seattle-based Groovetech to accept an all-share, reverse takeover to form the first part of a wider stock market listed music, entertainment and media group. A spokesman for Chandra refused to comment, however.

Mr Cowan holds the majority of shares in Groovetech, which he set up in 1995 while working on the west coast of the United States and now plans to expand into Britain. Mr Wood owns a stake of around 4%. The duo are also original shareholders in Sports Internet Group, owner of the Planetfootball websites.

Groovetech webcasts live sets from cult DJs such as Paul Oakenfold and aims to become a global on-line community for underground music. It owns two web-driven radio stations in Seattle and San Francisco.

British director Tintin Chambers was a major figure in the Acid House rave culture of the 1980s. Chandra is chaired by Nigel Drummond, brother of Virtual Internet chief executive Jason Drummond. Earlier this month it confirmed it was in advanced talks on its first acquisition after a rise in its share price. Last night's closing price of 251.5p values the company at £13m.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:
• Accessing millions

Chris Matthews who set up an internet company with £16,800, has become a multi-millionaire after it was sold for a reported sum of more than £250m to a big Dutch company.
fields.body:
 Accessing millions

Chris Matthews who set up an internet company with £16,800, has become a multi-millionaire after it was sold for a reported sum of more than £250m to a big Dutch company.

He sold free internet access company Telinco Networks to World Online in a deal that also makes millionaires of a handful of staff who shared 20% of the firm, based in Northwich, Cheshire. Telinco was set up in August 1997 and has an annual turnover of about £25m.

 Loyalty bonus
WebRewards has expanded its online loyalty and rewards programme into Britain by signing a deal with Value-Direct . webTitle: Sharif trial begins as judges quit in protest

fields.headline: Sharif trial begins as judges quit in protest
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: The trial of Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan's former prime minister, opened yesterday amid growing fears that the military regime that overthrew him is trying to undermine the independence of the judiciary.
fields.body:
The trial of Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan's former prime minister, opened yesterday amid growing fears that the military regime that overthrew him is trying to undermine the independence of the judiciary.

The trial started hours after the chief justice and five other senior judges left their posts rather than take an oath that would have banned them from challenging the decisions of General Pervez Musharraf, the self-appointed chief executive of Pakistan, or senior officers of his government.

Gen Musharraf ordered all 13 supreme court judges to swear allegiance to a "provisional constitutional order" which he had passed immediately after taking power last October. Six, including the chief justice, Said-uz Zaman Siddiqi, refused.

Fifteen of the more than 100 judges throughout Pakistan who were asked to take the oath are believed to have refused, and have thus effectively resigned.

"I have not resigned. I have refused to take oath," Mr Siddiqi told reporters yesterday. "I will work under the constitution, [but] not under the provisional constitution."

The judges' show of defiance is a serious embarrassment for the army which is sensitive to charges that its rule lacks legitimacy. Gen Musharraf has consistently refused to indicate when he plans to return Pakistan to democracy, provoking widespread condemnation overseas.

Mr Siddiqi and several of the judges who refused to take the oath were due to hear a legal petition next week that challenged the constitutional basis of the current regime. The petition, which has been made by Mr Sharif's supporters, will still be heard, though the results of the case are a foregone conclusion, observers believe.

Mr Sharif's lawyers had earlier asked for a postponement of his trial until the supreme court had heard the petition. But after hearing legal arguments, judge Rehmat Hussein Jaffri ordered that the trial continue.

Ammanullah Choudry, the former director of the civil aviation authority, was the first witness for the prosecution. The prosecution hopes that his evidence will be key in convicting Mr Sharif and six co-defendants on charges of hijacking, kidnapping, attempted murder and terrorism.

The charges, which carry the death penalty, relate to events on the day of the army takeover, when the prime minister and his aides are alleged to have tried to force a plane carrying Gen Musharraf and 200 other passengers to crash.

Mr Sharif has pleaded not guilty to all the charges.

Yesterday Mr Choudry told the court that he had been ordered to prevent the aircraft from landing anywhere in Pakistan. The order is alleged to have been given by Mr Sharif in the knowledge that the plane was running out of fuel.

Though the law says the trial must finish within seven days, it is likely to drag on for weeks.

There has been growing friction between the courts and Pakistan's military rulers. Not only have a number of courts at provincial and national level agreed to hear petitions challenging the legitimacy of the military takeover, but the sharia court - which enforces Islamic law in Pakistan - recently ruled that the country's banking system is "un-Islamic", and ordered the military regime to impose a new system where interest is not charged on loans.

Earlier this month a judge refused to hear the case against Mr Sharif in protest at the presence of intelligence agents and paramilitary soldiers in the courtroom. Another judge had to take over.

Many are worried that Gen Musharraf is following the example of General Zia-ul Haq, the dictator who ruled for most of the 1980s. In 1981 Zia asked judges to take a similar oath.

"It does not exactly fill you with confidence about the army's belief in democratic institutions," said a senior analyst with an Islamabad think-tank. "They are still thinking like soldiers, not as governors of a civil state. They are not used to disobedience and any dissent is seen as a threat."

The judiciary has an unhappy history of politicisation and corruption. Government investigators have recently revealed how Mr Sharif bought off at least one judge with a diplomatic passport. However there have been moments where judges have shown considerable independence. A showdown with the chief justice in 1997 nearly resulted in an early end to Mr Sharif's administration.

Asma Jehangir, a Pakistani lawyer and a United Nations rapporteur on human rights, praised the judges who yesterday showed defiance. "The military rulers are doing their best to erode the independence of the judiciary," she said. "I salute those judges who refused to take the oath."

fields.headline: Dancer's £8m court action
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Dancer Kerstin Parkin, whose career ended after she suffered brain damage during the birth of her first child, began an £8m damages claim against an NHS trust yesterday.
fields.body:
Dancer Kerstin Parkin, whose career ended after she suffered brain damage during the birth of her first child, began an £8m damages claim against an NHS trust yesterday.

In the high court, Mr Justice Buckley was shown a video of Kerstin dancing with her husband Mark when they were leaders in Latin American dance competitions, followed by footage of her being treated in a hospital bed.

She must now spend the rest of her life in a wheelchair or bed, cannot talk, and has to have 24-hour care.

Her husband, who gave up his career to look after her, has settled his £800,000 claim for post-traumatic stress against Bromley Hospitals NHS Trust for an undisclosed sum.

John Grace QC, representing the pair, said the event that "devastated their lives" came when Kerstin was 27 and in labour during the birth of her first child at Farnborough hospital, near Orpington, Kent.

Mr Grace said the pair danced professionally and her husband was for eight years ranked among the top six in his field in the world.

Their son, Dylan, now three, is being looked after by family, friends and nannies at a cost so far of £25,000. Kerstin is now at a rehabilitation unit in Godalming, Surrey, the court heard.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Patient left critical after wrong kidney is removed

fields.headline: Patient left critical after wrong kidney is removed
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A pensioner was in a critical condition yesterday after surgeons at a Welsh hospital mistakenly removed his one healthy kidney instead of the diseased one.
fields.body:
A pensioner was in a critical condition yesterday after surgeons at a Welsh hospital mistakenly removed his one healthy kidney instead of the diseased one.

An inquiry was launched by Carmarthenshire NHS trust after an operation to remove the 69-year-old man's right kidney went disastrously wrong at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli on Monday.

The patient is now in intensive care and similar operations there have been suspended pending the inquiry and the surgical team involved has been restricted to "minor operations" a hospital spokesman said.

It is understood that the man's family has contacted a solicitor with a view to legal action.

Mike Jones, chief executive of the trust, said: "Regrettably, a wrong kidney was removed during an operation on Monday. We do not know what went wrong and we will apply any lessons learned.

"The patient has been transferred to Morrison hospital in Swansea where I understand his condition is critical. Our feelings and thoughts are with the patient and relatives at the moment," he added.

"We are also concerned for the staff involved, who are extremely distressed. This hospital has a good record in terms of clinical risk management."

Hugh Beynon, the hospital manager, confirmed that an investigation was under way into what he called an "adverse incident."

"Representatives of the Trust have informed the family of the sequence of events and will continue to be in contact through the investigation," he said.

A friend of the patient's family said: "One of his kidneys was diseased and was going to be removed. Unfortunately, they have taken out the healthy kidney and left in the diseased one - he has been left with a kidney that is already failing. It is almost unbelievable that they operated on the wrong one."

One theory floated yesterday was that the patient had been rolled over before the operation confusing the surgeons as to which kidney was to be removed.

The health secretary for the Welsh assembly, Jane Hutt, called for an urgent report into the incident and has asked the trust to keep her fully informed. She said she had been assured that appropriate action was being taken.

"I was devastated to hear about this case," she said last night. "This causes me extreme concern and I will be making a statement on the case to the assembly's health and social services committee tomorrow."

Medical negligence experts in south Wales said compensation payments arising from the incident could run into hundreds of thousands of pounds, depending on the level of long-term care required by the patient.

Any need for long-term nursing care would send payments "through the roof," one leading firm said last night.

In addition, payments for pain and suffering, at present relatively low in this country, are due to be reviewed at a court of appeal hearing next month.

Yesterday the patient was moved into an intensive care unit after his condition deteriorated. Doctors are discussing the possibility of matching a relative willing to donate one of their kidneys. It is not unusual for people with only one kidney to live perfectly healthy lives.

Helen Mary Jones, the Plaid Cymru assembly member for Llanelli, said the "devastating" incident was totally out of character for a hospital with a high record of care standards.

"One can only imagine how the patient and his family must be feeling. It is deeply shocking," she said.

webTitle: Trust may lift ban on stag hunting

fields.headline: Trust may lift ban on stag hunting
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The National Trust will today consider lifting its ban on stag hunting with hounds on the day Lord Burns's independent inquiry goes on a fact-finding mission to watch its first fox hunt in Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
The National Trust will today consider lifting its ban on stag hunting with hounds on the day Lord Burns's independent inquiry goes on a fact-finding mission to watch its first fox hunt in Oxfordshire.

Confidential papers to be put before the National Trust's council meeting show it will be asked to look again at the scientific controversy over whether stag hunting is cruel.

The scientific row is between Lord Soulsby of Swaffham Prior - a member of Lord Burns's team - and Patrick Bateson, provost of King's college, Cambridge, whose original research led to the ban on stag hunting in 1998.

The appointment of Lord Soulsby, a vet who is an expert on parasites in domestic animals, to Lord Burns's inquiry into how to implement the hunting ban and what effect it will have on the rural economy has already attracted criticism from anti-hunting groups because of the evidence he gave to the National Trust saying deer hunting was not cruel.

Today he will be backed by Roger Harris, who, in a report commissioned by the Countryside Alliance, has argued that Lord Soulsby's analysis is right and that it is not a cruel activity.

But 12 scientists have submitted evidence backing Professor Bateson and attacking the analysis submitted by Pro fessor Harris. There is no dispute over the evidence or data used by either camp, and the row is over interpretation of the evidence.

Scientists backing Prof Bateson include John Krebs, best known for heading the government-funded study into badgers and TB, and one of Britain's foremost zoologists, Sir Richard Southwood.

All of them stress that the joint universities study by Prof Harris, which the hunters claimed invalidated much of Prof Bateson's research, did in fact mirror many of his scientific findings as to levels of stress and muscle damage caused to animals as they are chased for miles.

The main row is over how deer react after being chased by hunters and whether they die suffering unnecessary cruelty. The scientists who say hunting is not cruel argue that the deer is not suffering any more than someone playing in a football game. Opponents argue this is naive and cynical.

Knut Schmidt-Nielsen, a member of the US national academy of sciences, told the National Trust: "Human athletes are self-motivated, and the pursued deer is frightened to death."

A spokeswoman for the National Trust said yesterday that the 57 members of the council had already looked at a summary of the report and decided not to change their mind. She could not predict the decision today.

webTitle: Double horror bill: the night of the living dead and the day of the deadly boring

fields.headline: Double horror bill: the night of the living dead and the day of the deadly boring
fields.trailText: I popped into the Commons chamber at 3pm for prime minister's questions. I was just in time to hear Martin Bell thunder: "May I ask what purpose is being served by the prolongation of these pointless and lamentable proceedings?"
fields.body:
I popped into the Commons chamber at 3pm for prime minister's questions. I was just in time to hear Martin Bell thunder: "May I ask what purpose is being served by the prolongation of these pointless and lamentable proceedings?"

Good question, I thought. Pity more people don't ask it while prime minister's questions are rambling aimlessly on, with their mixture of puerile trivia, sycophancy and offensive drivel. Yesterday promised an especially futile argument about Labour's first 1,000 days.

But there was something missing. It turned out to be the prime minister. Apart from a single haggard home office minister, the government front bench was empty.

The reason, it turned out, was a filibuster, one of the longest in Commons history. The house has been debating the disqualification bill, which would allow members of the Irish parliament to be elected here too. It's a tiny sop to the Fenians.

The Tories don't like it, and saw a perfect chance to delay it and perhaps wreck more government business. By tradition, debate on constitutional bills can't be cut short, and there are complicated procedural problems too. So there was nothing to stop the Tories waffling as long as they wanted, which they did, throughout the night.

In the small hours, I gather, Labour MPs could be seen wandering round like the undead, moaning softly and pleading with the whips to be allowed a cup of tea and a shower.

By another arcane tradition, Commons sittings are named after the day they start, so that the whole of yesterday was known to the cognoscenti as "Tuesday". In the British parliament, every day can be groundhog day.

This can have some curious effects. For example, Andrew Mackay, the Tory Ulster spokesman, was speaking at exactly the same time as his wife made a speech in the second chamber, Westminster Hall. Yet technically they were talking 24 hours apart, which one day might make a plot for a Jeffrey Archer short story about adultery.

I felt sorry for members of the public who look forward to coming in for prime minister's questions. One old gent seemed hurt and bewildered, as kindly attendants explained the situation and pointed him towards the exit. But I'm sure Ted Heath will get over it.

The chamber was littered with weary, unkempt members, some sprawled along the seats, many barely awake.

Another tradition says that you cannot filibuster during a filibuster. Everything an MP says must, however distantly, have to do with the topic in hand. So a large part of each rambling speech was devoted to explaining how, in spite of appearances, it was completely relevant.

Golly, it was tedious. Every intervention led to an interruption, which brought a deputy speaker's ruling, which evoked a further point of order.

Labour MPs complained the Tories were going on too long. The Tories said there would be no need to go on so long if only ministers would give some straight answers.

"Conservatives members are deliberately prolonging these proceedings!" said David Winnick. "Disgraceful!" shouted the Tories, in mock outrage.

I'll explain what it was like. Imagine that on your death you are sent to purgatory, only for a few aeons, before being upgraded following the expiation of your sins.

"It's not so bad here," says an old-timer, "they pipe Radio 4 in all the time."

"That's great," you reply.

"Yes," he muses, "we can listen to Just A Minute, round the clock."

"Aaarrgggh!" you reply thoughtfully. "Do you think hell is full yet?"

fields.headline: Mother of all controversies
fields.trailText: Angela Phillips (Not guilty, baby, January 25) fails to mention the starting point of Panorama's programme, Back to the kitchen sink, which was that a third of full-time working mothers are giving up their jobs.
fields.body:
Angela Phillips (Not guilty, baby, January 25) fails to mention the starting point of Panorama's programme, Back to the kitchen sink, which was that a third of full-time working mothers are giving up their jobs. This is a legitimate subject for Panorama to tackle but one which is completely overshadowed in Phillips' eyes by our reporting of the fact that new academic research shows a negative relationship between mothers working in the pre-school years and academic qualifications later on.

Phillips may not like it, but this is a significant finding and one that both we and the academics responsible for the research agreed should be broadcast. No one wants to make working mothers like Phillips, or me, feel guilty but, as a current affairs programme, it is our job to ensure that important information that has wide currency in the academic world and is relevant to the lives of many families is shared with our audience.

And, contrary to the impression left by Dr Tony Munton (Letters, January 26), Panorama did not ignore important new research that somehow contradicted the evidence on child outcomes presented in the programme. Dr Munton mentions American research from the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. But he conveniently forgets to mention that the most recent evidence from this study finds that "more hours of childcare predicted less maternal sensitivity and less positive child engagement".

This finding is entirely in keeping with the research from the Institute of Education, as explained on Panorama.

Is Dr Munton's reluctance to engage seriously with the most significant piece of British research on child outcomes to date, which has been carried out by a highly respected academic and is based on a huge data set of 9,000 children, simply a sign that this area of research is, for some, too hot to handle?
Sarah Powell
Panorama

 Two or three years ago I asked my employer about setting up a creche or subsidising local childcare provision and holiday play schemes. I was told we didn't have enough women employees to justify this kind of thing. A high proportion of my colleagues were men with pre-school and primary-school-aged children; many had partners who had returned to work and a fair few had "non-traditional" family arrangements. webTitle: A rat with a rationale? Or perhaps a mouse with a message

fields.headline: A rat with a rationale? Or perhaps a mouse with a message
fields.trailText: Members of parliament, distraught that the press no longer reports them, often ask what they need to do to rekindle the public's interest. The answer to that was revealed in the Commons on Tuesday: let a rat come among them. Because of the rat, several newspapers found room yesterday morning to report the speech by Graham Brady (Conservative, Altrincham and Sale) which it interrupted. Eric Martlew (Labour, Carlisle), not normally known as a headline-grabber, also found his name thrust in front of constituents for attempting to corner the creature.
fields.body:
Members of parliament, distraught that the press no longer reports them, often ask what they need to do to rekindle the public's interest. The answer to that was revealed in the Commons on Tuesday: let a rat come among them. Because of the rat, several newspapers found room yesterday morning to report the speech by Graham Brady (Conservative, Altrincham and Sale) which it interrupted. Eric Martlew (Labour, Carlisle), not normally known as a headline-grabber, also found his name thrust in front of constituents for attempting to corner the creature.

To some, this was simply a case of a rat coming up from the Thames and straying into the chamber. For others, it seemed emblematic. Some saw the way it crossed the floor as a kind of satirical re-enactment of Shaun Woodward's switch to Labour. Others, plumbing the well of metaphor to its scuppers, may incite William Hague to use it in a forthcoming speech as a symbol of the sinking ship that is Labour. Still others may say it is no concidence that this outrage should have occurred just when the office of director-general of the BBC was being entrusted to the creator of Roland Rat. Fortunately the Commons is nowadays largely free from the kind of procedural pedant who would once have raised the rat as a point of order, complaining to the speaker that moving across the floor when a member is speaking is the height of parliamentary ill manners and would never have happened in Gladstone's day.

We say rat, since that is what reporters called it. Commons officials have sought to suggest it was only a mouse. Treat this guidance with caution. A parliamentary convention used to insist that members never died in the precincts, but only outside, on their way to hospital. It may be a similar convention that rodents found on the floor of the House must be mice rather than rats. Maybe too some will say that today's House of Commons houses more mice than rats. We would, of course, never say that ourselves.

fields.headline: Profits before ethics
fields.standfirst: This is the sharpest possible test case of New Labour's concern about international environmental standards.
fields.trailText: How depressing to read that the ministry of defence is advising that any attempt to impose ethical criteria on the export credit guarantee department would be a pointless handicap to British commercial interests (Whitehall leaks reveal ethics row, January 26).
fields.body:
How depressing to read that the ministry of defence is advising that any attempt to impose ethical criteria on the export credit guarantee department would be a pointless handicap to British commercial interests (Whitehall leaks reveal ethics row, January 26). Even more depressing is the information that Tony Blair has ordered the final go-ahead for the Ilisu dam. The ECGD will give a £200m guarantee to Balfour Beatty for the project, despite the appalling environmental and social damage it will wreak in the Kurdish region of Turkey.
Tony Juniper
Policy director Friends of the Earth

 The gun runners at the ministry of defence say that if we don't sell arms, then someone else will. Using the same logic, can we now look forward to the export credit guarantee department financing the sale of child pornography and heroin to dodgy customers as well?
Bryony Cobain
Cambridge

fields.headline: It is news
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen's was wrong to state in his piece about my forthcoming biography of Jimmy Donahue (January 26), that Donahue's affair with the Duchess of Windsor has been written about before. Others have remarked on the closeness of their friendship; nothing more.
fields.body:
Francis Wheen's was wrong to state in his piece about my forthcoming biography of Jimmy Donahue (January 26), that Donahue's affair with the Duchess of Windsor has been written about before. Others have remarked on the closeness of their friendship; nothing more.

The fact that Donahue was homosexual confused historians and it was a subject they preferred to sidestep. My evidence proves that the man who gave up throne and empire "for the woman I love" was cuckolded by a homosexual.
Christopher Wilson
Swallowcliffe, Salisbury

webTitle: Unholy rows: Section 28 and marrying divorcees

fields.headline: Unholy rows: Section 28 and marrying divorcees
fields.trailText: A point that seems to have been missed in the reporting of Cardinal Winning's campaign against the repeal of section 28 is that the Catholic church in Scotland is facing numerous claims for compensation by those who suffered physical and sexual abuse as children at the hands of priests etc (Blair bid to clam gay sex dispute, January 25).
fields.body:
A point that seems to have been missed in the reporting of Cardinal Winning's campaign against the repeal of section 28 is that the Catholic church in Scotland is facing numerous claims for compensation by those who suffered physical and sexual abuse as children at the hands of priests etc (Blair bid to clam gay sex dispute, January 25).

The issue is going to be stirred up still more by a new book written by a serving Catholic priest detailing the institutionalised abuse he suffered as a child at a junior seminary. This campaign could well be an attempt to distract attention from the crimes of Cardinal Winning's own priests.
SC Chumbley
London
chatham@duckworth-publishers.co.uk

 It is ironic that church leaders opposing the repeal of section 28 should warn against putting homosexual relations on a par with marriage in the same week as they accept remarriage after divorce, resisted for many years on the same grounds. It is also disingenuous that they give the impression this is the view of the church when it does not have a common mind on issues of sexuality.

What is important is that teachers are encouraged to create a safe and informative environment where young people can discuss the range of issues to do with their emotional, sexual and moral development. I hope this will be uppermost in the minds of members of parliament.
Rev Ian Stubbs
Oldham
ian@denshaw.freeserve.co.uk

 I hope I am among the awfully nice people described in your leader (January 26), but I do not conduct marriage services for divorcees. I did in a previous appointment (in the Middle East) but quickly found it impertinent to judge between cases.

I do offer an upbeat blessing after a civil marriage, and explain to couples that in no way am I setting myself up as judge over them - I am almost certainly far deeper in sin than they are. I say, however, that whatever other clergy may do, some of us still believe that the church has a responsibility to uphold the institution of life-long marriage being about more than choices for individuals, but every bit as much for the sake of children growing up with both their natural parents. I find few couples unhappy with this explanation, and together we make the service more meaningful than pretending that the previous marriage never happened.
Rev Ray Skinner
Morden, Surrey

 You seem to think that church equals pulpit equals telling people what to do. The bishops have produced a discussion document which takes seriously people's real lives and changes in social practice. The attempt to engage theology with pastoral practice is surely a holistic one. Surely the notion that an institution might legitimately expect people who use its services to allow it a certain integrity and substance does not stretch credulity too far?
Rev Nick Baines
Leicester

fields.headline: Scot fee outrage
fields.trailText: I am a BSC math student at Brighton University. Like many of my fellows starting undergraduate studies last year, I accepted in good faith that public finances could no longer fully underwrite the cost, and therefore it was right and proper that I pay annual tuition fees as I progress in my studies (Blunkett aims to deflect student fees backlash, January 26).
fields.body:
I am a BSC math student at Brighton University. Like many of my fellows starting undergraduate studies last year, I accepted in good faith that public finances could no longer fully underwrite the cost, and therefore it was right and proper that I pay annual tuition fees as I progress in my studies (Blunkett aims to deflect student fees backlash, January 26).

If Labour has now accepted the principle that university tuition fees should only be payable by Scottish students after graduation and upon the securing of paid employment, then there is no good reason why the same principle should not be extended to all UK students and institutions. Labour, by not doing so, will merely confirm the conviction that the "new deal" in Scotland was nothing other than a grubby, back-door deal arrived at for no other reason than it was the price to be paid for the preservation of the Lib-Lab coalition in the Scottish "parliament".
J R Hulland
Lancing, W Sussex

 Next September, as the parent of an English student at an English university, I will be expected to write a cheque for £1,000+. At the same time, I am paying taxes at a rate which allows public expenditure per head to be 20% higher in Scotland. In addition, were the issue of fees for English students to come to parliament, Scottish MPs would be whipped to defeat it. I therefore propose that a campaign of direct action should be mounted. Instead of paying next year's fees, all English parents and students should send the bill to the Scottish parliament as we have already paid our fees in taxes to support the Scots.
Chris Mackay
Eardisley, Hereford

fields.headline: Whitbread's dry choice
fields.trailText: I think it a great shame Harry Potter did not win the Whitbread book of the year prize (Heaney pips Harry Potter, January 26). There will probably never be another chance that a children's book will challenge for the title and I fear we confirm the perception of others that we are a snotty, toffee-nosed culture who are unable to reward something because it is popular. Dickens would never have won.

webTitle: A free vote is a cop-out

fields.headline: A free vote is a cop-out
fields.standfirst: Labour has a duty to get rid of section 28
fields.trailText: Section 28 of the 1988 local government act, which forbids councils to "promote" homosexuality, was and remains a prime example of Margaret Thatcher's legislative style, overweening, prejudiced and ineffective. With minimum consultation, scant regard for changing sensibilities, exaggerated fear of the local authorities she had not abolished or terrorised, a domineering administration wrote a set of vague injunctions into the public law.
fields.body:
Section 28 of the 1988 local government act, which forbids councils to "promote" homosexuality, was and remains a prime example of Margaret Thatcher's legislative style, overweening, prejudiced and ineffective. With minimum consultation, scant regard for changing sensibilities, exaggerated fear of the local authorities she had not abolished or terrorised, a domineering administration wrote a set of vague injunctions into the public law.

There was of course no evidence to underpin the reform, no "problem" demanding solution. It was only in the inflamed imaginations of some Tory MPs that gangs of seductive gays were importuning the nation's schoolchildren into taking up a particular life style - not in real life.

Labour promised repeal and until the past few days looked set to deliver. But now No 10 says it is "not impossible" that Labour MPs will be given a free vote, apparently because it is rattled by Cardinal Winning and the Scottish agitation. It is as if devolution had not happened. The cardinal and his monstrous regiment of moral absolutists are firing at the Scottish parliament, which will shortly deal with repeal north of the border; the Labour and Liberal Democrat majority in Edinburgh, if they care to muster their forces, will see off their opposition with ease. As for England, all we have seen so far extends little further than the intestines of the Tory party (see Ivan Massow on page 19) and religious groups which have more need to look to their own minorities and intolerances than to preach where they long ago ceased to lead or represent.

Cynics may say a free vote on repeal makes no difference: the massed ranks will do the right thing. But taking repeal off the list of official policies would reveal this government as rattled and cowardly. This is not, nor is it likely to become, an issue to convulse the (English and Welsh) nations. Most parents, all employers and most of the population at large care about school attainment, not the sexual orientation of teachers. Section 28 is not "conscience law", as freakishly claimed by the Labour MP Stuart Bell. This is a policy rooted in Tebbitian homophobia that has nothing to do with the real conditions in which children ought to confront their identities or learn about the evolving society around them. If its removal is not part of the "modernisation" of Britain promised by Tony Blair, what on earth is?

fields.headline: The days dwindle down
fields.standfirst:
A deadline that imperils the peace process

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: It is crunch time again in Northern Ireland. The focus this time is on February 12, when the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, will go before his party's ruling council. Last time it met, Mr Trimble promised that if the IRA had handed over no weapons by the end of January 2000, he would resign, effectively triggering the collapse of Northern Ireland's new, devolved government and of the peace process that brought it about.
fields.body:
It is crunch time again in Northern Ireland. The focus this time is on February 12, when the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, will go before his party's ruling council. Last time it met, Mr Trimble promised that if the IRA had handed over no weapons by the end of January 2000, he would resign, effectively triggering the collapse of Northern Ireland's new, devolved government and of the peace process that brought it about.

He even wrote out his letter of resignation, placing it in a sealed envelope ready to be opened in case of dire emergency. In other words, if the IRA guns are not brought out soon, then the painstaking work of the autumn of 1999 will unravel. Repairing it will not be easy. The cynicism will be intense, not least among the Unionists who gave David Trimble one last chance when, against their own instincts, they allowed him to set up an executive with two ministries for Sinn Fein, before the IRA had handed over a single bullet. "The provos have proved they cannot be trusted," the hardliners will say, vowing never to repeat that mistake.

The obvious response is surely to demand that the IRA now fulfil their side of the 1999 bargain. Enough of stalling, it's time to hand over the guns. Republicans have had plenty out of the peace process - those two ministries for Sinn Fein, the wholesale restructuring of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, a role for Dublin in the governance of Northern Ireland - now, surely, it's payback time. Why right now? Because David Trimble has promised this timetable to his own people: had he not done so, last year's compromise would never have got off the ground. That is an appealing case, but it is a shade too simple. For one thing, the rhetoric which says the IRA has been all take and no give is misleading. Besides a cessation of violence which surely counts as the peace process's most tangible achievement, republicans have also made the most profound ideological shift: they have finally accepted the legitimacy of Irish partition, sitting in a partitionist assembly and executive. It is untrue and self-defeating to pretend that republicanism has yielded nothing: it has yielded much. Moreover, the January deadline is questionable. As even Mr Trimble's team admit, it was never put in writing during last year's intense negotiations with George Mitchell, nor even stated explicitly. "It was understood by all sides," they say. Perhaps. But it was not an explicit part of the final plan brokered by the talks chairman and former US senator George Mitchell. Sinn Fein are not wholly duplicitious in insisting on the original Mitchell timetable, which calls for IRA decommissioning by May. That is the true payback time.

The key problem is the symbolism of the deadline. which David Trimble set under understandable pressure. To republicans, it smacks of a Unionist order: if we say jump, you jump. It is precisely that brand of decommissioning, with its connotations of surrender, which the IRA will never countenance - and which Senator Mitchell so skilfully avoided. The genius of his plan was to allow the IRA to end its war on its own terms. But the damage has been done: Mr Trimble has issued his demand. The best hope for a solution now lies in the hands of John de Chastelain, the Canadian general who is supervising the decommissioning process. If his interim report due on Monday can convey satisfaction at the rate of progress, as some observers still believe it might, then Mr Trimble may have just enough to pacify his ruling council. Then both sides can get back on the track to peace, the one laid out by the wise American - and no other.
fields.bodyText: It is crunch time again in Northern Ireland. The focus this time is on February 12, when the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, will go before his party's ruling council. Last time it met, Mr Trimble promised that if the IRA had handed over no weapons by the end of January 2000, he would resign, effectively triggering the collapse of Northern Ireland's new, devolved government and of the peace process that brought it about. He even wrote out his letter of resignation, placing it in a sealed envelope ready to be opened in case of dire emergency. In other words, if the IRA guns are not brought out soon, then the painstaking work of the autumn of 1999 will unravel. Repairing it will not be easy. The cynicism will be intense, not least among the Unionists who gave David Trimble one last chance when, against their own instincts, they allowed him to set up an executive with two ministries for Sinn Fein, before the IRA had handed over a single bullet. "The provos have proved they cannot be trusted," the hardliners will say, vowing never to repeat that mistake. The obvious response is surely to demand that the IRA now fulfil their side of the 1999 bargain. Enough of stalling, it's time to hand over the guns. Republicans have had plenty out of the peace process - those two ministries for Sinn Fein, the wholesale restructuring of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, a role for Dublin in the governance of Northern Ireland - now, surely, it's payback time. Why right now? Because David Trimble has promised this timetable to his own people: had he not done so, last year's compromise would never have got off the ground. That is an appealing case, but it is a shade too simple. For one thing, the rhetoric which says the IRA has been all take and no give is misleading. Besides a cessation of violence which surely counts as the peace process's most tangible achievement, republicans have also made the most profound ideological shift: they have finally accepted the legitimacy of Irish partition, sitting in a partitionist assembly and executive. It is untrue and self-defeating to pretend that republicanism has yielded nothing: it has yielded much. Moreover, the January deadline is questionable. As even Mr Trimble's team admit, it was never put in writing during last year's intense negotiations with George Mitchell, nor even stated explicitly. "It was understood by all sides," they say. Perhaps. But it was not an explicit part of the final plan brokered by the talks chairman and former US senator George Mitchell. Sinn Fein are not wholly duplicitious in insisting on the original Mitchell timetable, which calls for IRA decommissioning by May. That is the true payback time. The key problem is the symbolism of the deadline. which David Trimble set under understandable pressure. To republicans, it smacks of a Unionist order: if we say jump, you jump. It is precisely that brand of decommissioning, with its connotations of surrender, which the IRA will never countenance - and which Senator Mitchell so skilfully avoided. The genius of his plan was to allow the IRA to end its war on its own terms. But the damage has been done: Mr Trimble has issued his demand. The best hope for a solution now lies in the hands of John de Chastelain, the Canadian general who is supervising the decommissioning process. If his interim report due on Monday can convey satisfaction at the rate of progress, as some observers still believe it might, then Mr Trimble may have just enough to pacify his ruling council. Then both sides can get back on the track to peace, the one laid out by the wise American - and no other.

webTitle: Prodi signals end to UK veto on EU votes

fields.headline: Prodi signals end to UK veto on EU votes
fields.standfirst:
Choice is between majority decisions or 'paralysis'
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi and the European commission threw down a new challenge to Tony Blair and other EU leaders yesterday, by insisting that national vetoes must be reduced.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi and the European commission threw down a new challenge to Tony Blair and other EU leaders yesterday, by insisting that national vetoes must be reduced.

In an approach that set alarm bells ringing in Britain, the commission president said tax matters linked to the cross-border single market should be decided by majority vote rather than unanimity.

This could include the unresolved issue of the proposed withholding of tax on savings - on which the chancellor Gordon Brown is at odds with most EU partners in defence of the City of London's lucrative Eurobond market.

Mr Prodi also returned to the old idea of a two-speed Europe in which some countries could integrate faster than others, leaving Britain - already looking increasingly unlikely to join the single currency - in the slow lane.

Proposals to strip Britain and four other large countries of their right to an EU commissioner were angrily condemned by Conservative MEPs, who accused Labour colleagues of complicity in promoting a centralised European superstate.

But the government, which wants only a modest reform agenda, reacted frostily to the long-trailed proposals.

Britain has already said it would sacrifice one of its two commissioners - currently Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten - for the sake of reform. But one Prodi idea is for a rotation of commissioners to allow all member states to have a go.

Mr Prodi's proposals for reform, to be discussed in a year-long intergovernmental conference (IGC) starting next month, are unlikely to be accepted, but his ambitious approach, backed by Portugal, the current holder of the rotating presidency, may influence future bargaining.

Change is urgent because the EU, set up by six members in 1957, now has 15, and could in the next few years admit as many as 13 new members from eastern and southern Europe.

This would make it virtually impossible to reach agreement under current arrangements.

EU leaders decided at last month's summit in Finland that the reform agenda should be limited to avoid setting goals that cannot be achieved before enlargement starts in three years.

Mr Prodi told the European parliament: "We know from experience that unanimity already means either paralysis or reducing decisions to their lowest common denominator.

"At 27 or 28 members, there is no way round a radical approach. Qualified majority voting must be the general rule."

Mr Prodi, the former Italian prime minister, made it clear he was not calling for the harmonisation of national tax systems, but the commissioner in charge of the IGC, Frenchman Michel Barnier, said: "All subjects linked to the proper functioning of the single market should be open to qualified majority voting."

John Maples, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "The European commission has yet again let the tax harmonisation cat out of the bag, and has blown out of the water Tony Blair's claims that this year's IGC will not be far-reaching."

Conservative spokesman Christopher Beazely MEP said: "The commission should not present changes to qualified majority voting as a fait accompli, in particular for taxation matters."

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: "Women love to watch men who feel safe. It's the same reason boy bands are popular with young girls - it's the hint of sex without having a penis"
fields.body:
"Women love to watch men who feel safe. It's the same reason boy bands are popular with young girls - it's the hint of sex without having a penis"

Queer As Folk producer Nicky Schindler on why the series is so popular with women, Elle.

"It's not the leaving that women object to, it's the fact that it's always in one direction, which suggests it isn't always personality, mutual hobbies and love of children that has clinched the decision"

Shane Watson on why we all hate a man who leaves his wife for a younger woman, Evening Standard.

"Labour's 'whingeing wimminist' tendency are moaning and groaning again. The 'sisters' are worried because New Labour is likely to lose seats at the next election and many of those MPs most at risk of defeat are women. It is hard to think it will matter much ... There has been a palpable failure by them to speak out on issues which are the concerns of women generally. Much attention has been devoted to the Blair Babe lifestyle: clothes, babies, social life and - most common of all - how sexist the Commons is and what a hard time they have at work, poor dears. This whinger wing of Labour feminism should stop moaning. The truth is that there are not many other jobs which would allow them flexibility and long holidays, good pay, social status, travel and an agreeable working environment ... Labour's support among women voters is slipping. It could be won back by concentrating on issues such as proper NHS funding, but not by a moaning wimminist agenda"

Ann Carlton on how "Blair's Babes have betrayed their own sex", Daily Mail.

"The honeymoon Labour has enjoyed with women is coming to an end. Women have begun to note the abyss between Blair's poses and the reality of his government. They have seen that the people with real power are still men. Make no mistake about it, this is the way Blair wants it. He is in control. It is no accident that Mo Mowlam and Margaret Beckett and Harriet Harman were booted out. Perhaps Blair believes that the voters, poor saps, don't really notice whether women have any power in this government. But he's wrong. Voters do notice ... It's hard to see how the masculine stranglehold over politics will be broken. But, equally, it's hard to see why women should support a party that has so little interest in their presence and their priorities"

Natasha Walter on how Blair's Babes have been betrayed by New Labour, Independent.

fields.headline: Talkin' 'bout my generation
fields.standfirst: Last year, fortysomething Isabella Rossellini launched her own range of cosmetics. This week, fiftysomething Mick Jagger has followed suit. Is old the new gold?  Yvonne Roberts reports on the power of the grey pound
fields.trailText: Is grey really about to become the nation's new navy blue? Will life lived adagio appear as cool as hip yoof? More importantly, can the hitherto invisible older woman finally come of age in the public arena - with her wrinkles and her self-respect intact?
fields.body:
Suddenly, the F-word appears to be on everybody's lips. "F" as in fortysomething or even (truly heady territory, this) fiftysomething consumers who allegedly have lashings of leisure time and, most important of all, loads of loot. Or so the evidence suggests.

It was revealed this week that Mick Jagger, 56, has registered his name as a trademark for a range of beauty products and clothes - and presumably we're not talking walk-in baths and medical trusses here. A new ad agency opens for business next month, focusing only on the "mature" pound. Five women's magazines are directing their attention at the coyly labelled "grown-up woman". And Isabella Rossellini, 48, dumped by Lancome six years ago because she was too old, is back with a new cosmetic range called Manifesto, insisting that slap is serious business.

So is grey really about to become the nation's new navy blue? Will life lived adagio appear as cool as hip yoof? More importantly, can the hitherto invisible older woman finally come of age in the public arena - with her wrinkles and her self-respect intact?

The baby boomers are, of course, to blame. Those postwar offspring who, as anthropologist Helen Fisher puts it, "travel through society like a guinea pig moving through a python ... changing culture as they grow older". They invented the teenager, discovered sex and drugs and rock 'n' roll, played with revolution, collapsed into suburbia and now, according to the theoreticians, are about to enjoy an extended bout of affluenza. They are spending well-earned and inherited money as if - or rather because - there is no tomorrow.

As we all know, cash in the bank is the only reason in the western world why maturity may now be accorded time, attention and respect, and at first glance, the potential for profit is impressive. UK disposable income of "seniors" is said to be a massive £166 billion and likely to grow. The Henley Centre for Forecasting estimates that the over-45s are responsible for 30% of consumer spending.

This has been boosted by the number of women moving into full-time work after the age of 40 - up 21% in five years. Simultaneously, an unprecedented one in five women will remain childfree: no babies, more cash. Women in this post-40 economy have never had it so good - but it's still not exactly the Klondike. According to government figures, middle-aged women have a higher disposable income than younger age groups, but that still amounts to only 45% of the average income of men. A manual female employee will earn around £11,000 and a non-manual worker around £17,000; half the population has less than £750 in savings and investments, and female pensioners are particularly poor. Nevertheless, the trend is for an increasing proportion of qualified women to take home fatter pay packets. Yet still, in spite of this booty, 95% of ads are aimed at those under 30. And therein lies the first hurdle to a belated recognition of the older generation.

Twenty-five years ago, economist Rosemary Brown wrote The Female Consumer. She was among the first to criticise advertisers for viewing women with "a male eye", using "smug and ignorant preconceptions that alienated the customer, instead of wooing her to buy". Brown accused the industry of stereotyping the customer as housewife/mother/lover.

Two decades later, the stereotypes are limping but not yet buried, and more have been added. For example, women buy 40% of cars, so who is used to advertise one model? Claudia Schiffer doing a striptease. Any woman over 30 is relegated to the walking dead, unless of course she can be portrayed as housewife/mother/lover, possibly with a briefcase.

Sue Phipps, publishing director of Sainsbury's Magazine, points out that crossing the age bridge takes a leap of imagination not made easier by the equation that post-menopausal means dreary and de-sexed. "I was 44 last Saturday and next year I'll be in a different socio-economic group, 45-54," she points out. "I used to think that meant dull. Of course I'm thinking differently now it includes me."

Even if advertisers set aside the veneration of youth, another hurdle for those seeking to encourage the older woman to part with her perfumed pound is deciding who exactly she is. The married woman at home has long been catered for by magazines such as Woman's Weekly, but what of the less easily pigeonholed?

Lindsay Nicholson has for six months been editor of Good Housekeeping magazine, now undergoing a revamp. She has, she says, hung a sign in the office to remind staff that a woman in her 40s may be single, have grown-up children, be about to give birth or may already be a grandmother. She may also go to rock concerts. In short, life cycles are no longer what they once were.

"This generation is unique in history," Nicholson explains. "We are in uncharted territories, with aspirations and options that our mothers never had. That's what I'm trying to reflect."

In April, Eve Pollard is launching a rival magazine to Good Housekeeping. Her template, she says, is honesty. Honesty about the "real" lives older women live, alone and with men; about the finances they control, the humour they enjoy. "We want the magazine to be as funny and challenging and banal as the conversation one woman might have with another," she explains.

Both formats appear attractive enough and have been tried in varying mixes before. So why, then, the earlier failure of magazines aiming at the same target? Chic, for instance, catering for the woman "who wasn't born yesterday"? Perhaps it's because, no matter what the editorial intention, the overriding impression is that the 40-plus woman is still viewed through male eyes as a figure defined mainly by her lack of youth.

Yes, of course, we buy the creams that promise a new face in a fortnight (miracles do happen) but do we also have to accept a popular culture that offers Joan Collins as a role model, frozen at 39? Instead of divas, where is the diversity of lifestyles and faces that is the true benchmark of maturity? And why does the language have to be so patronising? "She looks good ... considering." And, come to that, why are the assumptions about the process of ageing often so asinine and sentimentalised? Post-menopausal women are said to be "comfortable in their own skin". Not if their life has been one cock-up after another.

A mature woman's often trumpeted years of experience may well be the negative result of decades of brainwashing. In Look Me In The Eye, Cynthia Rich argues that the obsession with "passing" as middle youth adds to the denigration of the process of growing older. It overlooks the value of caring less what others think, of having more time to engage with the less acquisitive, more spiritual world beyond work and family, of acting dangerously, since there ain't much left to lose. How often is that reflected in magazines, newspapers, television and cinema? (Older women like sex, too - but does it always have to be with a 20-year-old?)

"Passing" also prevents us treasuring the slower pace of the grey zone. A pace that, according to the writer Allegra Taylor, "creates the possibility for the unexpected to slip in between your heart beats". The older woman may be about to come in from the cold - but how many of us will recognise her as somebody we would like to know?

fields.headline: How we've changed
fields.standfirst: The 2000 social trends survey
fields.trailText: Population: there are more of us, but we're older
fields.body:
Population: there are more of us, but we're older

Population grew fastest in the first decade of the twentieth century when the population grew by an estimated 385,000 a year. Today the population is 59.2m - the 18th largest in the world. However, it is an aging population: in 1901 one person in 20 was aged 65 or over but one in six by 1998. One in 15 of the population is from an ethnic minority.

Families and household: we live in more houses and marry less

The average household size halved in the last century: before 1900 the average size was 4.6 people but now it is 2.4. In fact, while the population grew by just under a half in the twentieth century the number of households tripled. Just under one in three of us now live alone.

The popularity of marriage fell throughout the decades, and the 310,000 couples who married in 1996 were part of the smallest group ever. The proportion of non-married women aged 18 to 49 who were cohabiting more than doubled between 1979 and 1999 to 29%. Four in 10 births take place out of marriage.

Expenditure: we spend more

Total household expenditure more than tripled in real terms between 1951 and 1998. In 1998 around £5 per person was spent on eating out.

Health: not so good

In 1998-99, 20% of adults said they had a long standing illness compared to 15% in 1975 and around a quarter of men and women aged 16-24 were overweight or obese compared with three quarters of men aged 55 to 64 and two thirds of women the same age.

Fresh fruit consumption is on the up: in 1998 the average person ate 700g of fresh fruit each week at home compared to 500g in 1975. Smoking was also down to 27% of the population compared to nearer 50% in the early 1970s. Life expectancy is 75 years for males and 80 years for females: in 1911 it was just 50 years for men and 54 years for women.

Crime: more drugs, more men in prison

There were seven times more drugs seizures in the United Kingdom in 1997 than 1981. In 1998, 95% of the prison population was male.

Education and training: we're learning

The number of school pupils rose from 4.7m in 1946/47 to 8.4m in 1975/76. The figure fell in the 1980s as the birth rate dropped but picked up in the 1990s though it is still below its 1970s peak. The proportion of 16-18 year olds in full time education rose from 35% in 1988 to 55% in 1998.

In 1998, 54% of Indian pupils and 61% of "other Asian" pupils in England and Wales achieved five or more A-C GCSE grades compared to 47% of white pupils. The proportion of young women achieving two or more A levels has doubled since the mid-1970s to 25%.

Labour market: less years but more hours

In 1901 around 10% of 10-14 year old boys were in employment and 40% of men aged 75 or over were still working. Both these figures dropped but the proportion of working women rose to 72% in 1998, and in 1996-97 over three fifths of couples with dependent children had both parties in employment compared to around half in 1979/80.

By 1998 the proportion of the labour force had more than doubled to 40% from the 18% desk bound in 1901. The numbers working in agriculture fell from 12% to 2% over the same period. In spring 1999, around 24% of female and 15% of male full-time employees worked some form of flexible working pattern. We also work the longest hours in Europe at 45.7 hours for men and 40.7 hours for women.

Income and wealth: men still earning more

Men's incomes outstripped those of women at all ages in 1996-97, with men earning nearly twice that of women in their late forties peak earning period. In the 1990s the growth in average earnings outpaced the growth in retail prices and the inequality in the distribution of household disposable incomes that grew so sharply in the 1980s receded in the last decade.

Environment: it's getting hotter

In 1996-97, 51% of adults said they had regularly taken paper to a paper bank for recycling. Globally, seven out of the 10 hottest years on records have been in the 1990s.
