Today the population is 59.2m - the 18th largest in the world. However, it is an aging population: in 1901 one person in 20 was aged 65 or over but one in six by 1998. One in 15 of the population is from an ethnic minority. Families and household: we live in more houses and marry less The average household size halved in the last century: before 1900 the average size was 4.6 people but now it is 2.4. In fact, while the population grew by just under a half in the twentieth century the number of households tripled. Just under one in three of us now live alone. The popularity of marriage fell throughout the decades, and the 310,000 couples who married in 1996 were part of the smallest group ever. The proportion of non-married women aged 18 to 49 who were cohabiting more than doubled between 1979 and 1999 to 29%. Four in 10 births take place out of marriage. Expenditure: we spend more Total household expenditure more than tripled in real terms between 1951 and 1998. In 1998 around £5 per person was spent on eating out. Health: not so good In 1998-99, 20% of adults said they had a long standing illness compared to 15% in 1975 and around a quarter of men and women aged 16-24 were overweight or obese compared with three quarters of men aged 55 to 64 and two thirds of women the same age. Fresh fruit consumption is on the up: in 1998 the average person ate 700g of fresh fruit each week at home compared to 500g in 1975. Smoking was also down to 27% of the population compared to nearer 50% in the early 1970s. Life expectancy is 75 years for males and 80 years for females: in 1911 it was just 50 years for men and 54 years for women. Crime: more drugs, more men in prison There were seven times more drugs seizures in the United Kingdom in 1997 than 1981. In 1998, 95% of the prison population was male. Education and training: we're learning The number of school pupils rose from 4.7m in 1946/47 to 8.4m in 1975/76. The figure fell in the 1980s as the birth rate dropped but picked up in the 1990s though it is still below its 1970s peak. The proportion of 16-18 year olds in full time education rose from 35% in 1988 to 55% in 1998. In 1998, 54% of Indian pupils and 61% of "other Asian" pupils in England and Wales achieved five or more A-C GCSE grades compared to 47% of white pupils. The proportion of young women achieving two or more A levels has doubled since the mid-1970s to 25%. Labour market: less years but more hours In 1901 around 10% of 10-14 year old boys were in employment and 40% of men aged 75 or over were still working. Both these figures dropped but the proportion of working women rose to 72% in 1998, and in 1996-97 over three fifths of couples with dependent children had both parties in employment compared to around half in 1979/80. By 1998 the proportion of the labour force had more than doubled to 40% from the 18% desk bound in 1901. The numbers working in agriculture fell from 12% to 2% over the same period. In spring 1999, around 24% of female and 15% of male full-time employees worked some form of flexible working pattern. We also work the longest hours in Europe at 45.7 hours for men and 40.7 hours for women. Income and wealth: men still earning more Men's incomes outstripped those of women at all ages in 1996-97, with men earning nearly twice that of women in their late forties peak earning period. In the 1990s the growth in average earnings outpaced the growth in retail prices and the inequality in the distribution of household disposable incomes that grew so sharply in the 1980s receded in the last decade. Environment: it's getting hotter In 1996-97, 51% of adults said they had regularly taken paper to a paper bank for recycling. Globally, seven out of the 10 hottest years on records have been in the 1990s.

fields.headline: Basin bombshell
fields.standfirst: Paddington gives up secret from the deep
fields.trailText: The underbelly of one of the murkiest parts of London lay exposed yesterday, for the first time in a century.
fields.body:
The underbelly of one of the murkiest parts of London lay exposed yesterday, for the first time in a century.

Archaeologists, scrap metal dealers and the police were expecting dramatic revelations as the water seeped out of Paddington Basin, the first time it has been fully drained since 1909 - but not the secret given up by the sludge.

Hours before the arrival of waterways minister, Lord Whitty, and VIP guests from the property company promising a £300m transformation of the area, the British Waterways regional manager, Mark Bensted, was told a bomb had been found at the bottom of the basin where it had been scraped by passing boats. "It was only a tiddler, but it was a real bomb and we had to evacuate the whole site."

The bomb squad reported that 50 years of filthy water had done their job for them: the bomb was neutralised.

Only two original buildings survive around the 200-year-old canal basin, built to link the Grand Union to Limehouse dock, allowing freight from cargo ships to be transferred to barges and shipped to Birmingham and Manchester.

The area, behind Paddington station was heavily bombed. Most of the buildings are post-war warehouses, which will be demolished for an 80-acre complex of offices, shops, cafes and flats.

webTitle: New food watchdog backs GM labelling

fields.headline: New food watchdog backs GM labelling
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The chairman of the new food standards agency clashed with the industry yesterday when he backed the campaign for more detailed labelling of all ingredients derived from genetically modified organisms.
fields.body:
The chairman of the new food standards agency clashed with the industry yesterday when he backed the campaign for more detailed labelling of all ingredients derived from genetically modified organisms.

Sir John Krebs said consumers needed the extra information to make their own choices about what they ate but the manufacturers made clear they would fight any further rules - and would not agree to any voluntary codes.

The Food and Drink Federation said : "You might end up with labelling the size of a bus on a can of vegetables".

The row centres on emulsifiers and processed oils present in many foods. These are derived from GM sources but have been refined to such an extent any GM material is undetectable. European Union law on GM labelling covers basic ingredients, and will soon cover detectable additives, but Brussels has resisted the clamour for other derivatives because the rules would, it is said, be impossible to police.

Britain has made manufacturers and restaurants liable to fines up to £5,000 for failing to obey the present labelling regime and the ministry of agriculture has invited public debate about tougher standards even though the EU would ultimately have to approve changes.

Sir John - whose agency does not start work until April - said his views on derivatives were personal. "I think consumers do have the right , if they are concernend about about the origin of products which are GM-derived, to make a choice on that basis."

Labelling and proper traceability of food to its sources were key issues, he said although one could not make "sweeping general statements" about the safety of GM foods. They had to be looked at case by case. The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson and the chief scientist Sir Robert May had concluded that British protocols for assessing safety were as good as anywhere in the world and GM products like soya, maize and tomato paste as safe as non-GM counterparts.

The food federation said the derivatives did not constitute GM material. Additional information would only be developed if regulation demanded it. "The issue of consumer labelling is already fraught. There is an enormous difference between what is sensible and useful for the consumer and the enormous range of interest groups calling for their hobby horse to feature on the label." Friends of the Earth, which would prefer a ban on GM food pending further research, said it would like to see "a fully comprehensive and properly policed labelling scheme". The government's GM unit said any labelling "has got to be workable. The problem with derivatives is how do you know it [GM material] is there because there is no DNA present."

Sir John, a zoologist and Oxford professor, made his remarks as chairman of international conference on the safety of GM food to be held in Edinburgh next month. The government is meeting the £400,000 cost of the OECD conference, with results designed to feed into the G8 summit of industrialised nations in Japan in July. He insisted the conference would not be a "soft soap" meeting of the already GM-converted but would include a spectrum of views from the "gung-ho to the agnositic to the worrier".

"We need to move away from people sniping at each other to a global debate." Britain and other EU countries were "in a state of agnosticism, almost through to rejection" he suggested.

fields.headline: 'Nogo' area offers medical hope
fields.trailText: Three teams of scientists - in Britain, Switzerland and the US - have found the gene that stops nerve cells growing again.
fields.body:
Three teams of scientists - in Britain, Switzerland and the US - have found the gene that stops nerve cells growing again.

The body makes new flesh and blood and bone to repair wounds. But severed neurons do not recover, so spinal injuries can put sufferers into wheelchairs for life, and many never recover properly from strokes and other head wounds.

But Frank Walsh of Smith Kline Beecham in Harlow, Essex, Martin Schwab of the brain research institute in Geneva, and Stephen Strittmatter of Yale school of medicine in New Haven, Connecticut, report in separate papers in Nature today that they have found, in rats and humans, a gene called nogo which stops neurons from regrowing.

Most researchers were convinced there would be such a factor, and they were sure it would be found to do its work in myelin, the fatty sheath that protects nerves.

The discovery opens up the tantalising possibility that there might be a way of bypassing the "nogo" factor.

Dr Walsh said: "Laboratory experiments have now suggested that injured neurons can restore themselves if certain inhibitory influences are removed."

Damage to neurons in the brain or spinal cord leads to severe disability and death. But researchers have felt for years that the damage need not be permanent. In laboratory experiments, they have tested ways of stimulating re-growth in the nerves of damaged rats. Their suspicion has been that a protein produced in the myelin sheath blocks the process.

They were right. They knew of a similar gene in cows, and combed the genetic databases for something very like it in humans and rats. They put the gene into cell cultures to make it produce the protein.

"We can thus assess the importance of nogo in growth inhibition relative to other natural inhibitors in the central nervous system," said Dr Walsh.

Two other neurobiologists, commenting on the studies in Nature, said that much work needed to be done before the discovery could help patients. But they called it a "landmark step on the long road towards new treatments for many neurological conditions."

webTitle: Home alone girl, 3, dies from burns

fields.headline: Home alone girl, 3, dies from burns
fields.trailText: The three-year-old girl who was terribly burned by a gas fire after she was left at home with her toddler brother has died in hospital with her parents at her bedside.
fields.body:
The three-year-old girl who was terribly burned by a gas fire after she was left at home with her toddler brother has died in hospital with her parents at her bedside.

Farah Kauser never regained consciousness after suffering 80% burns at her home in Ravensthorpe, West Yorkshire, while her mother collected an older child from the local primary school.

Police are not expected to question the child's distraught family for some days and detectives have suggested that charges are unlikely, although leaving such young children alone is illegal. An inquest will be opened later this week into the tragedy, which saw two builders working locally break into the house and try to revive Farah before paramedics arrived.

fields.headline: Rolls denies war record 'censored'
fields.trailText: Management at Rolls-Royce Motors yesterday denied suggestions that it had "censored" the war record of staff at its Crewe headquarters to appease the company's German owners.
fields.body:
Management at Rolls-Royce Motors yesterday denied suggestions that it had "censored" the war record of staff at its Crewe headquarters to appease the company's German owners.

Gwyneth Dunwoody, Labour MP for Crewe and Nantwich, said workers were furious that a new potted history of the Volkswagen-owned firm makes no mention of the 17 staff killed when the Crewe factory was bombed in 1941.

It also glosses over the company's development of the Merlin engine used in Spitfire and Hurricane aircraft during the second world war.

She said: "If this is an attempt at political correctness it is unwise, unwarranted and ill-judged.

"It is very disappointing that a difficult but vital period in the life of Rolls-Royce, which cost the lives of several workers, should have been omitted."

A spokesman for Rolls-Royce said he was "absolutely bemused" by the fuss.

"The history was written for Voice, our internal magazine, and was not meant to be taken out of context. The problem is one of our retired employees who has never been in favour of German ownership. He has been moaning to the media."

He added: "One of the first things you see when you enter our Crewe plant is a painting of a British aircraft shooting down a German one.

"And there is a Merlin engine on display right in the middle of the factory."

"I have spoken to VW and they are absolutely puzzled by the suggestion that they censored the article.This is a witch hunt of the worst kind."

Conservative MEP Jaqueline Foster said: "People who work at the Crewe factory are proud to do so. They are very upset that not even a mention has been given to the bombing. They feel it could have been handled better."

Philip Hall, chief executive of the Henry Royce Foundation, said that the Crewe factory's role in the Battle of Britain was a vital one.

"The whole purpose of the factory was originally to build Merlin engines for the war effort. It is certainly no understatement to say that this country owes its freedom to the Merlin engine."

A spokesman for Vokswagen said the company would never want to hide any part of Rolls-Royce history.

fields.headline: Ruling on sterilisation questioned
fields.trailText: The official solicitor is to ask the court of appeal to veto a hysterectomy for a 28-year-old mentally handicapped woman after a high court judge ruled that it would be in her best interests for the operation to go ahead.
fields.body:
The official solicitor is to ask the court of appeal to veto a hysterectomy for a 28-year-old mentally handicapped woman after a high court judge ruled that it would be in her best interests for the operation to go ahead.

Laurence Oates, who acts for those unable to look after their own legal interests, believes the woman should not have to undergo such an invasive procedure but should be fitted with a contraceptive coil to prevent pregnancy and deal with heavy periods.

Mr Oates said: "Clearly it is an issue which we feel needs to be considered by the court of appeal as soon as possible. The issue is whether a less invasive method of treatment is in her best interests. It is right for the court of appeal to give us guidelines."

The woman's 54-year-old mother, a widow, fears her daughter could become pregnant when she moves into a residential home, either through forming an emotional attachment with another resident, or through somebody "taking advantage" of her or raping her.

She wanted her daughter to have a hysterectomy because this would not only protect her from pregnancy but put a stop to her periods altogether. But the official solicitor argued that a Mirena coil would be a simpler, easier and less invasive option.

Last Monday Mr Justice Wall held that the operation could go ahead. The judge said that the daughter, identified only by the initial S, though an "extremely attractive young woman", was incapable of managing and administering her own affairs. She lives with her mother and attends a day centre five days a week. But the mother finds coping increasingly difficult and hopes that within 12 months S will get a permanent placement in a home.

The judge said it was common ground amongst all who had examined or come into contact with S that pregnancy would be disastrous for her.

"She would have no understanding of what was happening to her."

webTitle: Men more ruffled by bad hair

fields.headline: Men more ruffled by bad hair
fields.trailText: Men are more likely than women to suffer poor self-esteem if they are having a bad hair day, according to US researchers.
fields.body:
Men are more likely than women to suffer poor self-esteem if they are having a bad hair day, according to US researchers.

Academics at Yale university who studied the psychology of bad hair days found that people felt less smart, more embarrassed and less sociable if their hair was sticking out or badly cut. The men who took part in the tests were the worst affected.

Marianne LaFrance, the Yale professor who conducted the study, said: "The cultural truism is men are not affected by their appearance. This is not just the domain of women."

Having an unruly haircut did not hold back Albert Einstein, and Rod Stewart is still sporting the same flyaway style he had in the 1970s. But a Boots spokeswoman said sales of men's grooming products were on the increase.

For the study, which was paid for by shampoo maker Procter and Gamble, researchers questioned 60 men and 60 women aged 17 to 30. Most were Yale students.

Edinburgh-based social psychologist Halla Beloff said: "This study shows men are suddenly realising what women have known for a long time, that appearance does have an impact.

"Clearly people are more preoccupied with their appearance when they are younger. But you are more likely to be worried about a so-called bad hair day if you are worried anyway. It could be because you are feeling insecure that you look at your hair and think it's bad."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Trial date set for manager
fields.body:
Trial date set for manager

Liverpool crown court yesterday set November 27 as the trial date for Southampton FC manager Dave Jones, who is charged with 13 child abuse offences.

Jones, a father of four, faces six indecent assault charges, six of assault and a further charge relating to a serious sexual offence on a boy aged 16 or under.

The 43-year-old former Everton defender was given conditional bail.

The case was adjourned for a further plea and directions hearing.

No Shipman verdict yet

The jury in the Harold Shipman trial at Preston crown court was yesterday sent home for a third night without returning any verdicts on the 15 murder charges against him.

The seven men and five women have spent a total of just over 17 hours considering their verdicts.

Boy lands DJ in trouble

The broadcasting standards commission yesterday reprimanded a DJ who encouraged a schoolboy to make offensive remarks about his teacher.

Kev Seed was hosting a feature, Throw your teacher to the sharks, on Liverpool's Radio City FM when the teenager fired off a string of personal insults against his teacher, Stephanie Schofield. Seed gave him a prize for bravery.

Union pulls out of animal lab

The shopworkers' union, Usdaw, is to dispose of investments in a firm which carries out vivisection experiments on animals.

Usdaw said yesterday it had discovered it had holdings in Huntingdon Life Sciences, a frequent target for animal rights protests, after disclosures that Labour's staff pension fund had shares in the firm.

Child killer freed

A woman jailed at the age of 15 for stabbing to death a fellow teenager in a Glasgow school attack eight years ago was yesterday released on life licence.

Barbara Glover, 23, was sentenced to be detained without limit for murdering Diane Watson, 16.

fields.headline: Fury at £60,000 for bomb victim
fields.standfirst: Unionist dismay at second award to republican
fields.trailText: A Belfast republican once accused in the Commons of masterminding the Shankill Road bomb atrocity was awarded £60,000 yesterday after he was seriously injured in a loyalist car bomb attack four years ago.
fields.body:
A Belfast republican once accused in the Commons of masterminding the Shankill Road bomb atrocity was awarded £60,000 yesterday after he was seriously injured in a loyalist car bomb attack four years ago.

Lawyers for Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, failed to block Eddie Copeland's claim for compensation at Belfast recorder's court. They had argued that he was engaged in IRA terrorism and was thus ineligible for compensation.

Mr Copeland, 29, suffered leg and arm injuries when the Ulster Freedom Fighters tried to murder him at his Belfast home in December 1996.

Judge Harte said he was not satisfied Mr Copeland was entirely truthful in explaining how he had been injured.

Kelly is due to be freed in July, along with all remaining prisoners at the Maze. He will have served less than seven years.

Kelly was one of 250 IRA prisoners who shared £76,000 compensation last year. The payout was for belongings damaged when prison officers mounted a search of the Maze following the discovery of an escape tunnel.

webTitle: 'Danger to foetus' in glass of wine

fields.headline: 'Danger to foetus' in glass of wine
fields.trailText: Drinking even the occasional glass of wine in pregnancy could damage the unborn child, according to new research which challenges government guidance.
fields.body:
Drinking even the occasional glass of wine in pregnancy could damage the unborn child, according to new research which challenges government guidance.

Jennifer Little, a research fellow at Belfast university, is now advocating complete abstinence for pregnant women following her study which concluded that drinking small quantities of alcohol could be harmful to the baby.

She and her colleagues carried out tests on 120 foetuses at 25 weeks of pregnancy to test their response times and behavioural development. At that stage, most babies should react and jump in the womb when a buzzer is sounded on the mother's abdomen.

But even among those women who drank four units a week, which the government says is harmless, significantly fewer babies passed the test than among those whose mothers did not drink at all. Five months after the children were born, follow-up tests confirmed the slower development.

Dr Little concludes that the alcohol may have an effect on the functioning of the central nervous system. "I didn't really expect lower levels of alcohol to have as great an impact on the behaviour of the foetus. I did expect foetuses of heavier drinkers, or possibly even binge drinkers, to have more deviant behaviour, but the fact that we found these differences in foetuses of mothers who weren't actually drinking that much alcohol was quite significant.

"It's worrying because current recommendations generally say that some alcohol during pregnancy is OK. However, the results would suggest that women shouldn't drink any alcohol during pregnancy. Even low amounts may have an effect on their foetus."

Dr Little's findings will be detailed on ITV's programme Tonight with Trevor McDonald this evening.

They are already disputed by the department of health, which advises that up to four units of alcohol spread over a week will not harm the baby. "The overwhelming body of evidence suggests that moderate drinking is not harmful, and most pregnant women drink below the levels we advise," a spokeswoman said.

webTitle: Drivers on cannabis are put to the test

fields.headline: Drivers on cannabis are put to the test
fields.standfirst:
Drugs problem on the roads prompts official trials

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Sixteen people have been chosen by the government to test drive cars legally after smoking cannabis as part of the first research into the impact of drug taking on motorists.
fields.body:
Sixteen people have been chosen by the government to test drive cars legally after smoking cannabis as part of the first research into the impact of drug taking on motorists.

Their names and backgrounds are to be kept secret by the transport research laboratory at Bracknell, Berkshire, which is carrying out the investigation on behalf of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

The laboratory would not say how the 16 had been chosen, but they are being given cannabis, told to drive immediately afterwards, and then tested on their reactions.

A source involved in the experiment said the guinea pigs had not been chosen at random. "We know that drug taking is an increasing problem on the roads, and we need evidence to show what impact it has on the motorist." The results are expected to be published later this year.

The investigation follows surveys showing a large rise in the number of fatal accident victims who had driven with drugs in their system.

The department of transport said the drugs in the tests were being supplied under licence to the participants. The issuing was not illegal because the 16 were taking part in a controlled scientific experiment.

The RAC is calling for a warning system on over-the-counter medicines so consumers know which pose a driving hazard. A green rating would mean the drug was safe. An amber sign would advise that it could have a minor effect, while a red would signal severe adverse effects which would dangerously impair driving.

An RAC survey showed that over a 12 month period 800,000 people had been in a car in which the driver was high on cannabis, 280,000 in which the driver was on amphetamines, and 140,000 in which the driver was on ecstasy, cocaine or heroin.

Edmund King, executive director of the RAC Foundation, said: "The government has spent millions on effective campaigns addressing the problems of drink-driving, and now is the time to highlight the dangers of drugs and driving. It is alarming that drug-driving is overtaking drink-driving as the biggest danger on our roads."

Rob Tunbridge, head of impairment studies at the transport research laboratory, said: "All of the tests that have been done in other countries suggest that cannabis has a completely different effect to alcohol. Rather than giving you dutch courage and confidence, it actually makes you much more cautious in your approach to driving. That doesn't necessarily mean, of course, that it will improve your driving."

fields.headline: Muted welcome for mortgage reforms
fields.standfirst: Mortgage mis-selling explained
fields.trailText: New rules for mortgages announced by the government yesterday risk leaving millions of homebuyers confused and unprotected against bad advice from salespeople, consumer groups claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
New rules for mortgages announced by the government yesterday risk leaving millions of homebuyers confused and unprotected against bad advice from salespeople, consumer groups claimed yesterday.

The treasury said rip-off home loans will become a thing of the past under its shake-up of the £115bn-a-year industry, which will see mortgages subjected to statutory regulation for the first time.

With banks and building societies coming under fire in recent months for allegedly penalising customers with unfair terms and hidden charges, ministers unveiled rules which will give homebuyers legal protection against bad practices.

But the reforms were attacked by consumer groups for failing to address the problem of poor quality and misleading advice given by salespeople.

Under the rules, which will come in next summer, mortgages will be policed by the financial services authority, the City's new "super-watchdog". All lenders will have to apply to the FSA for authorisation to sell mortgages, and the watch dog will regulate advertising and insist that information lenders give about loans is "clear, comparable and comprehensive".

The FSA is being given a range of new powers for dealing with companies that break the rules. It will be able to impose fines, force firms to pay compensation, and even strip them of the ability to sell mortgages.

The treasury economic secretary Melanie Johnson also announced minimum standards for mortgages aimed at outlawing misleading terms and hidden penalties.

To win the official seal of approval, a mortgage will have to meet a range of conditions covering charges, flexibility and clarity. However, the standards, which take effect from April this year, will be voluntary.

The new regulatory regime means that for the first time mortgages will be subjected to the same level of scrutiny as personal pensions, endowments and other investments. At present, mortgage lending is regulated by a voluntary code of conduct, policed by the industry and viewed by many as easy to sidestep.

While all lenders will be covered by the regime, the government surprised many observers by deciding not directly to regulate mortgage brokers, one of the sectors that has prompted most concern.

The harshest criticism was directed at the decision not to regulate mortgage advice.

The strongest warning came from the financial services consumer panel, which was set up by the FSA in 1998 to advise it on consumer issues. It said the regime "won't touch the most serious problems which involve the advice process and questions of suitability."

The Consumers' Association echoed these comments.

The minimum standards for fixed rate, capped and variable rate home loans received a warmer welcome. To win the mark of quality, a variable rate mortgage must have an interest rate no higher than 2% above the Bank of England base rate, and there must be no penalties for paying it off early. With fixed and capped rate mortgages, early redemption penalties must not extend beyond the end of the offer period.

At the moment, many of Britain's biggest lenders, including Halifax, NatWest and Barclays, would not be able to offer a mortgage that meets the minimum standards. This is because they calculate interest annually. One of the requirements is that interest must be calculated daily.

webTitle: Straw plan to tag more ex-inmates

fields.headline: Straw plan to tag more ex-inmates
fields.trailText: A shake-up in sentencing so that middle-ranking criminals no longer just walk out of prison and back into crime was last night proposed by the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
A shake-up in sentencing so that middle-ranking criminals no longer just walk out of prison and back into crime was last night proposed by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

Encouraged by the initial success of electronic tagging, Mr Straw said he was looking at plans for a "seamless sentence" which meant many more offenders leaving prison would be tagged and forced to attend courses in anger management, drug and alcohol addiction, or sex therapy.

His plan is expected to be underpinned by a demand by the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, today for the courts to be given powers to order violent and sex offenders to have treatment while they are in jail. Those who refused would face longer sentences.

This would be a significant change for the criminal justice system, and would end the situation where, for example, Gary Glitter could be jailed for four months for child porn offences but receive no treatment in prison.

The prison population is a record 68,000-plus and is forecast to rise by a further 4,000.

Mr Straw told an international probation conference in London: "We need to think about ways of joining up custodial and community penalties, so that we can deal more effectively both with those who in the first instance do not necessarily need a prison sentence, and those who do need such a sentence but who might also need more targeted intervention on release.

"Some have suggested a seamless sentence served partly in custody and partly in the community under strict licence conditions - aided by new technology, such as tagging. It must make sense that if an offender is undergoing a programme designed to help him control his anger he should be able to continue that programme whether he is in custody or in the community". Those who failed to attend the compulsory courses would face a swift return to jail.

Mr Straw did not specify which type of offenders would be affected by this new sentence. But many more prisoners would be involved than the 16,000 who have been tagged and released a few weeks early under the home detention curfew scheme.

Mr Straw also defended his proposal to rename the probation service as the community punishment and rehabilitation service after the change was attacked in the Lords on Monday. The former Tory home secretary, Lord Hurd, said the name change had provoked ridicule and resentment.

But Mr Straw said the service deserved a title which ensured that everybody was clear as to what its business really was.

fields.headline: Oxford scientist suspended
fields.trailText: One of Britain's most distinguished zoologists and BSE researchers has been suspended from his job after a complaint by a woman colleague, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
One of Britain's most distinguished zoologists and BSE researchers has been suspended from his job after a complaint by a woman colleague, it emerged yesterday.

Roy Anderson, 52, director and co-founder of the Wellcome Trust's new, multi-million-pound centre for the epidemiology of infectious diseases at Oxford university, has been suspended on full pay. He will face an internal inquiry.

Last night the university said the suspension was a neutral decision. It did not in any way imply that the complaint against Professor Anderson was true.

The complaint has been lodged by epidemiologist and novelist Sunetra Gupta. She was appointed as reader in epidemiology at Oxford late last year.

The science journal Nature reported yesterday that she objected to "allegations by Anderson on the means by which she had obtained her appointment" and allegations about her "relationship" with Paul Harvey.

Professor Harvey, 53, is Prof Anderson's successor as head of the zoology department. Told of the report last night, he said to the Guardian: "I have never had a relationship with Dr Gupta, who is married with two children. I would consider that suggestion libellous. Nature has produced an inaccurate article."

Later Prof Anderson's lawyers, Olswang, said his suspension followed allegations about an appointments committee meeting in November: "He wholly denies any wrongdoing in relation to that meeting. He intends vigorously to dispute both his current suspension and - should they occur - any future disciplinary proceedings".

Prof Anderson's role in setting up the Oxford Wellcome centre was a new stage in a career which has brought him five medals for scientific work.

A Fellow of the Royal Society and member of the government's BSE advisory committee, he is a former chairman of the advisory standing committee on the environment and former head of the biology department at Imperial college, London.

Author of numerous papers on the spread and control of infectious diseases, he became a Wellcome Foundation trustee in 1991. Two years later he was appointed zoology department head and professor at Oxford. This inspired the founding of the centre. In 1994 it drew five major Wellcome Trust grants. Its brief includes the Aids virus, BSE, drug-resistant bacteria and malarial parasites.

Dr Gupta's novels include Glassblowers' Breath and Moonlight into Marzipan.

fields.headline: Belgium attacked for 'diatribe' over Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Lawyers for the home secretary yesterday attacked the Belgian government over its claims that he had acted "unlawfully and irrationally" by not releasing the medical reports that found the former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet, 84, was unfit to stand trial.
fields.body:
Lawyers for the home secretary yesterday attacked the Belgian government over its claims that he had acted "unlawfully and irrationally" by not releasing the medical reports that found the former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet, 84, was unfit to stand trial.

On the first day of a high court hearing in which the Belgian authorities and human rights groups are seeking a judicial review of the procedures the home secretary has adopted in making the decision that he is "minded" to return the general to Chile, Jonathan Sumption QC, accused the Belgian government of launching a "diatribe" against Mr Straw in a letter to the home office.

"I must be careful what I say in this court about a friendly foreign government.

"But there are aspects of this letter of request that are surprising," he told a packed court two.

"This is either a collateral process to get confidential material [the medical reports] for use in the UK, or the Belgians have not thought it through."

The extradition to Spain of General Pinochet to face charges of torture was becoming a "symbol of a commitment to human rights" rather than a legal matter which had to be properly weighed up.

Rejecting claims of unfairness, he told Mr Justice Maurice Kay: "In a difficult situation the secretary of state has got the balance exactly right and there is absolutely no basis in these applications for supposing his conclusion was perverse or in any other way unlawful."

Earlier Presiley Baxendale QC, for the Belgian government, said that it was a "breach of natural justice" for Mr Straw not to disclose the medical reports.

Without seeing the medical records - which Mr Straw has declined to disclose claiming they are covered by medical confidentiality rules - the Belgian government was unable to make meaningful representations.

"It was irrational because at one and the same time the secretary of state was asking Belgium to make representations and refusing to disclose the details of the report," she told the court.

By halting extradition proceedings the home secretary was in danger of breaching international law and conventions under which signatories undertook to provide each other with the widest measure of "mutual assurance" in extradition proceedings .

Richard Drabble QC, for Amnesty and other human rights groups, said their representations were mere "shadow boxing" without access to the medical reports.

If Mr Straw did not have the power to force Pinochet to undergo further medical tests, he could use his discretion to push the general towards more medical tests or greater openness by threatening to continue the extradition proceedings and allowing the Spanish courts to rule on the matter.

The suggestion was roundly rejected by Mr Sumption who insisted that the laws of the country invested the authority for sanctioning extradition with the home secretary.

Faced with conclusive medical evidence Mr Straw was legally obliged to release a fugitive.

He attacked the human rights groups for bringing the proceedings, claiming the campaigners had no legal right to be heard in extradition matters.

Mr Straw had taken an "exceptional step" in allowing them the opportunity to make representations at all.

The general had been examined by four highly eminent medical experts.

While it was possible there was a factual error in the report, it was not a strong enough possibility to outweigh the duty of confidentiality owed to the former Chilean dictator.

The hearing continues today.

"I must be careful what I say in this court about a friendly foreign government. "But there are aspects of this letter of request that are surprising," he told a packed court two. "This is either a collateral process to get confidential material [the medical reports] for use in the UK, or the Belgians have not thought it through." The extradition to Spain of General Pinochet to face charges of torture was becoming a "symbol of a commitment to human rights" rather than a legal matter which had to be properly weighed up. Rejecting claims of unfairness, he told Mr Justice Maurice Kay: "In a difficult situation the secretary of state has got the balance exactly right and there is absolutely no basis in these applications for supposing his conclusion was perverse or in any other way unlawful." Earlier Presiley Baxendale QC, for the Belgian government, said that it was a "breach of natural justice" for Mr Straw not to disclose the medical reports. Without seeing the medical records - which Mr Straw has declined to disclose claiming they are covered by medical confidentiality rules - the Belgian government was unable to make meaningful representations. "It was irrational because at one and the same time the secretary of state was asking Belgium to make representations and refusing to disclose the details of the report," she told the court. By halting extradition proceedings the home secretary was in danger of breaching international law and conventions under which signatories undertook to provide each other with the widest measure of "mutual assurance" in extradition proceedings . Richard Drabble QC, for Amnesty and other human rights groups, said their representations were mere "shadow boxing" without access to the medical reports. If Mr Straw did not have the power to force Pinochet to undergo further medical tests, he could use his discretion to push the general towards more medical tests or greater openness by threatening to continue the extradition proceedings and allowing the Spanish courts to rule on the matter. The suggestion was roundly rejected by Mr Sumption who insisted that the laws of the country invested the authority for sanctioning extradition with the home secretary. Faced with conclusive medical evidence Mr Straw was legally obliged to release a fugitive. He attacked the human rights groups for bringing the proceedings, claiming the campaigners had no legal right to be heard in extradition matters. Mr Straw had taken an "exceptional step" in allowing them the opportunity to make representations at all. The general had been examined by four highly eminent medical experts. While it was possible there was a factual error in the report, it was not a strong enough possibility to outweigh the duty of confidentiality owed to the former Chilean dictator. The hearing continues today.

webTitle: DJ rebuked over attack on teacher

fields.headline: DJ rebuked over attack on teacher
fields.trailText: The broadcasting standards commission has criticised a breakfast show DJ who allowed a schoolboy to make offensive remarks about his teacher live on air.
fields.body:
The broadcasting standards commission has criticised a breakfast show DJ who allowed a schoolboy to make offensive remarks about his teacher live on air.

Liverpool's Radio City FM DJ, Kev Seed, hosting a feature called "throw your teacher to the sharks", encouraged a schoolboy to hurl a string of insults against his teacher on the programme.

The boy was then rewarded with a prize for doing so.

The teacher, Stephanie Schofield, lodged a complaint with the commission, the authority responsible for policing TV and radio broadcasts.

The commission said the broadcaster had made "a serious error" in allowing the teacher and school to be named on air.

The station had treated the teacher unfairly and invaded her privacy.

The commission's report said: "The remarks made by the boy were extremely personally offensive."

Although the broadcaster said that the presenters of the programme were embarrassed by the boy's unexpected remarks, they commended his bravery and then awarded him a prize.

"In the circumstances, the commission found that the item was unfair to Mrs Schofield and unwarrantably infringed her privacy."

Sean Harley, a spokesman for Radio City, said the station would not argue against the watchdog's findings.

Mr Harley said: "We accept the finding of the BSC, and Mr Seed fully understands the situation. It was intended to be light-hearted."

fields.headline: Mothers can stop paternity testing
fields.trailText: Men who want to find out whether they fathered a child born to a former lover are in legal limbo after a high court judgment this week, unless parliament acts to change the law.
fields.body:
Men who want to find out whether they fathered a child born to a former lover are in legal limbo after a high court judgment this week, unless parliament acts to change the law.

One of the country's senior family judges has ruled that DNA blood tests cannot be taken from a child to determine the child's paternity unless the mother consents.

The ruling means that fathers hoping to win court orders for contact with children born out of wedlock may be unable to go ahead, if the mother denies the child is their's.

Mr Justice Wall said that he was bound to reach that conclusion by the wording of the family law reform act 1969, although he found the proposition "unattractive". He took the view the court had no jurisdiction to compel either of the mothers in the two cases before him to allow blood samples to be taken from their children.

Only parliament could change the law, he said. "If parliament does not implement reform, the law in this area will continue not to serve the best interests of children."

The judge said he thought the law might breach the human rights act, due to come into force next October. The case is certain to go to the court of appeal, but until the appeal court delivers its judg ment, judges around the country are expected to put applications for paternity rulings on hold.

When the act was passed in 1969, its aim was to set out a method for pinning paternity on reluctant fathers so they could be made to pay for the child's upkeep. It was fathers who regularly refused to be tested, but the court would draw inferences from their refusal and declare them to be the father.

At the time, paternity testing required blood from father, mother and child, but new advances allow accurate results from just the father and child's blood.

The act states that blood can be taken from a child under 16 if the person with "care and control" of the child consents - in most cases the mother.

One of the two men was keen to play an active part in the child's life and wanted to apply for an order for contact and to share parental responsibility with the mother. In the other case, the man first wanted to learn whether he was the child's father before deciding what further steps he wished to take.

The question which arose was: what, if any, order or orders may the court make to enforce the direction that a sample of blood be taken from a child? said the judge.

In a complex, 35-page judgment, he held that the mothers were within their legal rights to refuse.

webTitle: Blair wary as TransTec pressure grows

fields.headline: Blair wary as TransTec pressure grows
fields.standfirst:
Tories demand inquiry into Northern Ireland grants
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night put distance between himself and Geoffrey Robinson as pressure grew in Westminster for official investigations into TransTec to include huge grants awarded in Northern Ireland to the collapsed engineering group founded by the former treasury minister.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night put distance between himself and Geoffrey Robinson as pressure grew in Westminster for official investigations into TransTec to include huge grants awarded in Northern Ireland to the collapsed engineering group founded by the former treasury minister.

The Conservative treasury spokesman, David Heathcoat-Amory, tabled a Commons question, asking the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, to list all payments from his department to TransTec since 1991.

Because the Tories believe ministers like Mr Mandelson have not been sufficiently sensitive to the risk of conflict of interest over Mr Robinson's complex affairs, they are pressing behind the scenes for a full examination of subsidies to TransTec in Northern Ireland, to be carried out by either the Northern Ireland Office or the devolved government in Belfast.

Mr Blair's spokesman insisted yesterday that the multi-millionaire who helped fund Labour's pre-election campaigning was not a "pariah." Interviewed last night, the prime minister himself was wary - not disowning Mr Robinson, but not being as fulsome as in previous skirmishes.

"There are allegations made about him. They are mainly made by the Conservative party and all of them are being investigated. The ones investigated so far have failed to prove anything," said Mr Blair.

He was referring to the department of trade and industry (DTI) inquiry into Hollis, the engineering company once chaired by Mr Robinson.

The inquiry was terminated before Christmas. Earlier yesterday, Mr Robinson, speaking on Radio 4's Today programme, said: "I am sure I could talk to the prime minister whenever I want to. I see him in the lobby often enough."

In fact he has barely seen him since he left office 13 months ago as a result of disclosures of a private loan to Mr Mandelson, then at the DTI.

On Tuesday night, Mr Mandelson's successor, Stephen Byers, ordered officials to investigate applications from TransTec for subsidies totalling £1.3m between 1987 and 1997. Allegations, relating to DTI grants, were rejected by Mr Robinson during yesterday's interview.

Later, his accuser, TransTec's former accountant Max Ayriss, stood by his claim that, between 1986 and 1988, invoices were inflated to support claims for DTI funding. "Nothing's changed," he said. "This story is about the truth and integrity of Geoffrey Robinson."

Grants from Northern Ireland's industrial development board (IDB) total at least £6.9m, the sum related to development of the component plant at Campsie that made parts for car group Ford.

Late deliveries from Campsie triggered a £12m claim from Ford - submitted after Mr Robinson left TransTec to take government office in May 1997 - that was subsequently concealed in the accounts. Once this claim was uncovered, just before Christmas, TransTec went into receivership.

Last night the IDB said that, were it to receive allegations of any impropriety in applications for subsidies, it would "take a close look" at those applications. But the board said such allegations would have to relate specifically to IDB grants and no such suggestion has been received.

The IDB is being transferred under devolution from the oversight of the Northern Ireland office to that of the new department of enterprise, trade and investment, under Stormont minister Sir Reg Empey, who could not be reached for comment yesterday .

Tory sources said yesterday that it made little sense to investigate payments totalling £1.3m while ignoring the much larger £6.9m, paid in stages by the IDB from 1994, simply because the latter sum came from a different ministry.

The Tories still scent blood and Angela Browning, their DTI spokeswoman, last night tabled more detailed questions about who knew what and when in the DTI.

fields.headline: Brigadier quits over gay troops
fields.trailText: An army brigadier has resigned over the government's decision to allow gays into the forces, citing his "strongly held moral and military convictions" as his reasons for wanting to leave.
fields.body:
An army brigadier has resigned over the government's decision to allow gays into the forces, citing his "strongly held moral and military convictions" as his reasons for wanting to leave.

Brigadier Pat Lawless, 44, who joined the Army Air Corps in 1976, said he was "very sad to leave", but could not reconcile his beliefs with the government's actions.

In a statement, following a report in the Sun, he said: "On January 10 2000 I applied to leave the army on the grounds that I could not reconcile my strongly held moral and military convictions as a soldier and a citizen with the government's decision to lift the ban on homosexuals serving in the armed services."

Brig Lawless, who is married with two children, was recently made deputy commander of the new tri-service joint helicopter command, based at Wilton, Wiltshire.

A spokesman for the ministry of defence said last night: "It is very much a personal matter for Brig Lawless, and we obviously respect that. As far as the policy change is concerned, it is something we were required to put through once the European Court [of Human Rights] ruled against our previous stance. Service chiefs have made it clear that they are committed to making the new policy work."

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said: "When next in government, the Conservatives remain committed to letting the armed forces review the policy and assess whether or not it works."

fields.headline: Path opened to repairing nerves
fields.trailText: Three teams of scientists - in Britain, Switzerland and the US - have found the gene that stops nerve cells growing again.
fields.body:
Three teams of scientists - in Britain, Switzerland and the US - have found the gene that stops nerve cells growing again.

The body makes new flesh and blood and bone to repair wounds. But severed neurons do not recover, so spinal injuries can put sufferers into wheelchairs for life, and many people never recover properly from strokes and other head wounds.

But Frank Walsh of Smith-Kline Beecham in Harlow, Essex, Martin Schwab of the brain research institute in Geneva, and Stephen Strittmatter of Yale school of medicine in New Haven, Connecticut, report in separate papers in Nature today that they have found, in rats and humans, a gene called nogo which stops neurons from regrowing.

Most researchers were con vinced there would be such a factor, and they were sure it would be found to do its work in myelin, the fatty sheath that protects nerves.

The discovery opens up the tantalising possibility that there might be a way of bypassing the "nogo" factor.

Dr Walsh said: "Laboratory experiments have now suggested that injured neurons can restore themselves if certain inhibitory influences are removed."

Damage to neurons in the brain or spinal cord leads to severe disability and death. But researchers have felt for years that the damage need not be permanent.

In laboratory experiments, they have tested ways of stimulating regrowth in the nerves of damaged rats. Their suspicion has been that a protein produced in the myelin sheath blocks the process.

They were right. They knew of a similar gene in cows, and combed the genetic databases for something very like it in humans and rats. They put the gene into cell cultures to make it produce the protein.

"We can thus assess the importance of nogo in growth inhibition relative to other natural inhibitors in the central nervous system," said Dr Walsh.

Two other neurobiologists, commenting on the studies in Nature, said that much work needed to be done before the discovery could help patients. But they called it a "landmark step on the long road towards new treatments for many neurological conditions".

fields.headline: Anti-monarchist firebrand dies
fields.trailText: Willie Hamilton, the firebrand former Labour MP best known for his staunch anti-monarchist outbursts and headline grabbing insults, has died, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Willie Hamilton, the firebrand former Labour MP best known for his staunch anti-monarchist outbursts and headline grabbing insults, has died, it emerged last night.

Mr Hamilton, 82, was MP for the then Fife Central constituency from 1951 to 1987, when he retired, and was a constant scourge of the royal family.

He died at the County hospital in Lincoln in the early hours of January 23.

Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, said last night: "I am very sorry to hear this news. Willie Hamilton was a great character and much liked.

"A doughty fighter, he won his seat from the Communist party in the 1940s and represented his part of Fife and its mining communities with energy."

The Scottish secretary, John Reid, said: "Willie Hamilton was a man of principle, style and humour. He had a razor-sharp principled tongue that could wound without hurting.

"He will of course be remembered for his espousal of republican opinions which he did not trim in the face of criticism."

Henry McLeish, MP for the seat now known as Central Fife, also paid tribute to Mr Hamilton: "I think everybody will be very saddened in the constituency of Central Fife. Willie was an excellent constituency MP and he enjoyed parliament and its traditions.

"He was famed for his comments about the monarchy but that was only one part of him and he will be remembered as well as a great parliamentar ian and a great constituency MP."

Mr Hamilton began his attacks on the royal family almost as soon as he became an MP in 1950, and continued them throughout his career, often angering not only constituents but also the Labour leadership.

He once described the Queen as "a middle-aged woman of limited intellect who should be ditched in the Channel", and was no less scathing about her children.

He said Prince Charles was "a nitwit and a gentle parasite, but at least he's not as rude as his sister", while of Prince Edward's academic achievements he said: "Edward's qualifications wouldn't get Joe Soap's son into the local polytechnic."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Helen Weinstein kicks off the new season of Document (8.0pm, Radio 4) with a long talk to the Soviet defector Vasili Nikitich Mitrokhin. It was he who blew the whistle on Melita Norwood as Britain's least probable atomic spy. As a senior officer in the KGB's highly sensitive archive section, Mitrokhin managed to make detailed copies of hundreds of its files. When he finally jumped ship he startled his Western hosts by arriving with this amazing hoard.

It was he who blew the whistle on Melita Norwood as Britain's least probable atomic spy. As a senior officer in the KGB's highly sensitive archive section, Mitrokhin managed to make detailed copies of hundreds of its files. When he finally jumped ship he startled his Western hosts by arriving with this amazing hoard.

The closing period of the 20th century could be dubbed The Twanging Years, notable for the vibration of high-tension steel. Guitarist Rick Parfitt, (pictured) who contributed his share as a member of Status Quo, looks back on it all in Electrifying - The History Of The Electric Guitar (10.0pm, Radio 2). It seems several lifetimes since Les Paul launched the trend. His multi-track recordings were originally made to publicise his modernisation of what was once a rather genteel instrument.

fields.headline: Rebels ruin day 1000 showdown
fields.standfirst:
Question time battle between Blair and Hague cancelled because of Tory-Unionist wrecking tactics
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's 1,000th day in power was last night marked by squabbling and parliamentary spoiling tactics by MPs after hardline Unionist and Tory critics of the Good Friday agreement talked through the night and most of yesterday - wrecking William Hague's plans to nail the prime minister at question time.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's 1,000th day in power was last night marked by squabbling and parliamentary spoiling tactics by MPs after hardline Unionist and Tory critics of the Good Friday agreement talked through the night and most of yesterday - wrecking William Hague's plans to nail the prime minister at question time.

The outburst of old-fashioned guerrilla tactics in the Commons, which caught both frontbenches off guard, prompted a bizarre exchange of faxed letters between the two party leaders in which Mr Hague, in effect, asked Mr Blair to use his 178-seat Commons majority to stop the Tory-Unionist filibuster.

Though both men had thoroughly prepared for their symbolic 1,000th day exchanges across the dispatch box in order to impress television news audiences, Mr Hague emerged the bigger loser because the weekly question time is the only chance he gets to corner his rival. Mr Blair promptly gave radio and television interviews instead.

It was the first time since 1986 that the ritual exchange, held every Wednesday at 3pm, had been lost because the previous day's business had not ended in time. The last time a full day's Commons business was lost in this way was in 1988.

"Just like the good old days," older MPs on both sides murmured after their sleepless night. As the sitting dragged on into its second unbroken night it came close to equalling the post-war record.

In his faxed letter Mr Hague told the prime minister that he was "disappointed that on your 1,000th day in office you have chosen not to preserve today's question time."

Mr Hague added: "We now both have a free half-hour. Will you join me live on TV for a debate?" Mr Blair replied to the handwritten note: "I have just received your ill-judged letter. The idea that we should use our Commons majority to discipline your backbenchers, because you are unable to discipline them yourself, is extraordinary. It is high time you took a grip of your party and led it properly."

The squabble, which saw official spokesmen accusing each other of "juvenile nonsense" and of "running away", overshadowed the legislation which prompted it: the disqualifications bill, which is part of the "normalisation" of Anglo-Irish relations by letting Irish MPs stand for the Westminster parliament.

Though the shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe had promised a "fair passage" to the brief bill as recently as Monday - and did not oppose its second reading that day - Unionists like Willie Ross MP and the maverick Tory rightwinger, Eric Forth, a formidable backbench operator, led a filibuster against the clause-by-clause examination that started on Tuesday afternoon.

As the Tory frontbench struggled to catch up - "the tail wagging the Tory dog", said Labour MPs - the rebels argued that the situation has changed because the IRA shows no signs of decommissioning weapons.

Even the Liberal Democrats agreed that the bill is being pushed through parliament too fast with no reason. The party's home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes said it was "an abuse of the house".

Faced with the filibuster, Labour whips had three options: they could give up on the bill for now and merely "report progress"; use Labour's huge majority to force a "closure" vote to end debate on the disputed clauses, one at a time, itself a lengthy procedure; or go with the flow and let Mr Hague shoot himself in the foot. They chose the latter.

Mr Hague's 1,000th day speech was also overshadowed by the row. It had been designed to tell voters why Britain needs the "common sense revolution" he promised last October.

Taunting Mr Blair as a "cheque in the post prime minister" the Tory leader said: "I warn you that a second Blair term will turn Britain into a second rate economy, with third rate public services, where more and more decisions are taken beyond democratic control."

webTitle: Blair may backtrack on gay clause vote

fields.headline: Blair may backtrack on gay clause vote
fields.standfirst: MPs likely to be told to toe party line after protests
fields.trailText: Labour MPs are expected to be told to back plans to repeal the controversial section 28 law on homosexuality, it emerged yesterday, following strong protests from backbenchers at hints that the government might allow a free vote.
fields.body:
Labour MPs are expected to be told to back plans to repeal the controversial section 28 law on homosexuality, it emerged yesterday, following strong protests from backbenchers at hints that the government might allow a free vote.

A day after Downing Street, attempting to defuse a growing row over the clause, indicated that MPs could be allowed to vote as they chose in deference to a handful of opponents, Tony Blair seemed to have bowed to pressure from an angry parliamentary party for a whipped vote.

Protesters, including Ben Bradshaw, the gay MP for Exeter, and leftwinger Alice Mahon, spoke out at yesterday's meeting of the parliamentary party, making clear they wanted the government to resist a "conscience vote".

Downing Street floated the option of a free vote on Tuesday. It followed a warning from Labour MP Stuart Bell, a church estates commissioner, that failure to allow MPs a conscience vote could lead to a rebellion in the Commons.

But at yesterday's meeting, Mr Bradshaw told colleagues that there was anger among some Labour backbenchers when news of the possible strategy emerged.

He warned that failure to make the issue a whipped vote would be a "terrible tactical and moral mistake".

Following yesterday's parliamentary committee meeting with the prime minister, the PLP chairman, Clive Soley, said he was optimistic that Labour MPs would be whipped for the vote.

He said: "The decision on the section 28 vote hasn't been made yet, because it is a whipping decision which is always made closer to the vote. But I am optimistic it will be a whipped vote."

Despite Mr Bell's claims, there is no doubt that Labour opposition to repealing clause 28 would have been minimal, just as the vast majority of the parliamentary party earlier backed a reduction in the gay age of consent to 16.

However, Mr Bradshaw and others argue that the party should direct its MPs to support the measure as a symbolic gesture since Labour has consistently opposed the clause as a matter of policy.

They also say that, while the age of consent is an issue of conscience dealing with the behaviour of individuals, section 28 is a matter of public policy, since its bar on the "promotion" of homsexuality in schools relates to the powers and freedoms of local authorities.

William Hague, the Tory leader, writing in the Daily Mail after sustained pressure from the paper calling on him to speak out in defence of the clause, also argued the matter was a party issue. He emphasised that his MPs would face a whipped vote. "A party such as ours that believes in small government, and further believes in free institutions such as marriage and the family, has a responsibility to take a party line."

But Mr Blair insisted that repealing clause 28 was sensible. "The reason for it is that many of the organisations that deal with children said to us that this law is inhibiting people and sometimes teachers from doing their jobs properly in explaining to children the facts of life."

fields.headline: The worst possible taste
fields.standfirst: You've read the book, watched the programme, now buy the cuff-links. Has television merchandising got out of control?  Meg Carter  investigates
fields.trailText: You've read the book, watched the programme, now buy the cuff-links. Has television merchandising got out of control?
fields.body:
See the TV programme, buy the video, read the book. But would you buy the jewellery? The BBC certainly hopes viewers of its latest star-studded TV drama Gormenghast will be tempted. But is this commercial opportunism, or wishful thinking?

The Gormenghast product range, if you've not already had the pleasure, includes hand-crafted pendants, cufflinks and earrings using the Celtic motif from the cloak worn by the character played by Ian Richardson, Lord Groan. No, I can't say I remember the detailing either, although the overall look of the series is certainly striking. Other products planned include fine art prints and china figurines.

"Gormenghast is a huge investment and an important and prestigious production for the BBC. With its rich costume designs and strong visual style we identified clear (merchandising) potential", says Richard Hollis, deputy director of licensing at BBC Worldwide.

While dramas are notoriously difficult to merchandise beyond conventional books or videos, he adds, Gormenghast's potential for broadcast repeats, internal sales and a video release, combined with the chance to develop merchandise not just associated with the BBC production but also incorporating author Mervyn Peake's original illustrations, proved irresistible.

So, the BBC struck a deal with a jewellery firm called Alcami to develop its designs. Negotiations are currently underway with another company, called Footprint, which is likely to produce the series of prints.

Generating additional revenue to supplement the funds available to programme makers through the BBC licence fee is Auntie's main motivation, Hollis says. The challenge, then, is to maximise the commercial potential of BBC programmes while maintaining editorial integrity and following the BBC Charter, which states that the broadcaster cannot endorse or promote commercial products.

Typically, licensed merchandise is developed around children's programmes - and very profitable it can be, too. Last year, merchandise linked to BBC TV programmes generated £340 million in worldwide retail sales. With growing competition, however, the potential to introduce successful and profitable kids TV merchandise is declining - despite the phenomenal success of Teletubbies, which generated £32 million in spin-off marketing activities for BBC worldwide in the last financial year.

Despite what it says in the Charter, the BBC is allowed - through its commercial arm, BBC Worldwide - to licence manufacturers to produce products associated with selected programmes, or to allow characters, logos or related programme themes to be used on more familiar products, like yoghurts or stationery. Which is where the second reason for TV merchandising comes in: publicity.

Few could deny that so far the BBC has done this effectively. Other broadcasters have tried - there's been Emmerdale cheese and Coronation Street bitter - but none as successfully.

But with TV merchandising activity growing fast - recent additions have included Ready Steady Cook paper towels and coasters and Alan Titchmarsh-branded gardening implements - do broadcasters risk demeaning their golden goose?

While BBC executives and their contemporaries at commercial channels insist a programme's off-air commercial potential is never allowed to dictate whether a new programme gets made or not, it's not uncommon for marketing people to be assigned to a programme in development even before the commissioning editors give it the green light.

Can merchandise potential really be ignored in the decision-making process in every case, observers ask. Others question consumer interest in many of the items now going on sale.

The prospects for Gormenghast seem encouraging. The BBC's move is in keeping with a current fad for gifts associated with fantasy and sci-fi themes, says Claire Atherton, managing director of CPL Ltd, which handles licensing for properties including TV series Stargate and Barbie.

"The UK is a nation of collectors," she explains. "And when we like something, we want to get into it - in a big way." We are also a more discerning market than the US, apparently. "Here our tastes extend beyond T-shirts. We have a greater desire for higher-priced merchandise with higher perceived value." Which, it seems, is where items like the Gormenghast jewellery fits in.

But not everyone shares the BBC's confidence in the potential for spinning-off merchandise from Gormenghast and other grown-up fare.

"Does your average TV viewer really want to be seen wearing products to do with a particular TV drama? I'm not so sure," says Claire Derry, chief executive of character licensing specialist Link Licensing. "It makes sense where there's a link - between a homestyle show and household items. But where the synergy's less obvious, well, I'd be surprised."

Don't hold your breath, then, for Wives And Daughters: The Aftershave. Or, for that matter, the Eastenders Guide To Marital Success. But watch this space for future developments - all done, of course, in the best possible taste.

fields.headline: In the land of plod
fields.trailText: The hunt for the Yorkshire Ripper has been described as "a textbook example of how not to run a murder investigation", but the strength of This Is Personal (ITV) is the way it doesn't appear to be driving the viewer towards a pre-ordained point of view. Instead, writer Neil McKay and director David Richards have painstakingly traced the long search for the killer, with all its dead ends, blunders and personal rivalries, and left the audience to draw its own conclusions. Of course, their choices of what to include and what to omit must shape an audience's responses, but you can't see the joins. The savage violence of the Ripper killings is depicted mostly in sober verbal reports, there's a minimum of background music, and the frequently run-down locations in Yorkshire and Lancashire are filmed with a resigned restraint which speaks for itself.
fields.body:
The hunt for the Yorkshire Ripper has been described as "a textbook example of how not to run a murder investigation", but the strength of This Is Personal (ITV) is the way it doesn't appear to be driving the viewer towards a pre-ordained point of view. Instead, writer Neil McKay and director David Richards have painstakingly traced the long search for the killer, with all its dead ends, blunders and personal rivalries, and left the audience to draw its own conclusions. Of course, their choices of what to include and what to omit must shape an audience's responses, but you can't see the joins. The savage violence of the Ripper killings is depicted mostly in sober verbal reports, there's a minimum of background music, and the frequently run-down locations in Yorkshire and Lancashire are filmed with a resigned restraint which speaks for itself.

At the core is Alun Armstrong's brooding performance as Assistant Chief Constable George Oldfield, the officer in charge of the inquiry. He pursued it so relentlessly that it ultimately destroyed both his career and his personal life. Armstrong plays him as a dogged but decent officer whose determination to catch the killer isn't matched by his skills in detection, nor by the quality of the men under his command. As much as anything, This Is Personal is a portrayal of the state of policing in the 1970s, and if there's plenty of room for improvement in the constabulary at the start of the 21st century, you can watch this and boggle at how it used to be.

Again, it is the matter-of-factness with which it has been handled which lends credibility. The Ripper inci dent room in Millgarth, Leeds is a microcosm of casual chauvinism, terrible haircuts and beery rugby-playing blokeishness, where officers plod through their assigned tasks with no imagination and no enthusiasm, except for when it's time to tot up their mounting overtime payments. Even when a computer is brought in to check vehicle registrations, the investigating team is hair-tearingly slow at joining the dots. Meanwhile, inter-force rivalries, media criticism and political pressure begin to bear down crushingly on Armstrong's already stooped shoulders.

Nobody can tell how much more successful a comparable investigation would be today, although a cynic might look at the Jill Dando case and conclude "none". This Is Personal hasn't attempted to reconstruct the entire national life of 20 years ago, though its tan-coloured Morris Marinas and Ford Granadas in two-tone brown are hideous flashbacks to the nightmare past of the British motor industry, while scenes of groups of terrified prostitutes haranguing the police for their incompetence impart an atmosphere of quasi-medieval superstition. This is television likely to linger in the imagination.

The X Files (BBC1) may turn out to be the only decent thing Chris Carter ever did, but the venerable franchise is proving that it still has the knack of self-renewal. The 'Files has finally dragged itself free from the quagmire of impenetrable conspiracies which was coming close to earning it a special "Avoid!" sticker in the TV listings. Instead, it has rediscovered the virtues of inventive sci-fi plots allied to nuances of characterisation, and not just in the Mulder/Scully relationship.

Last night's feature-length episode revisited the mysteri ous Area 51, where everybody knows the US develops captured UFO technology. A gravity-drive fault caused Mulder to swap bodies with covert spook Morris Fletcher (played by Spinal Tap's Michael McKean), throwing him into a paradigm of dysfunctional American family life that was far more bizarre than his encounters with shape-shifting assassins and alien viruses. "I know for sure that I'm not the man you married", explained Mulder to his new "wife". She immediately concluded that he needed a course of Viagra.

Fletcher, meanwhile, exploited his temporary Mulder-ness to kiss ass with the FBI brass and grope the office secretaries. A witty, satirical script said more about Mulder, Scully and their fraught relationship with authority than a dozen past episodes. Mulder's comic turn with Fletcher, where the pair mimicked each other in a mirror, was almost worthy of the Marx Brothers.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: • Endgame
fields.body:
 Endgame

6pm, Discovery

On December 13, 1996, 14 members of the Peruvian revolutionary group MRTA stormed a party at the Japanese ambassador's residence and took 72 hostages. Four months later, Peruvian armed forces stormed the building and the terrorists, with the loss of one hostage and two soldiers. This film examines the planning behind the assault, which involved building a tunnel under the compound and an exact replica of the house. What it doesn't consider is the political context - or indeed the possibility of a peaceful conclusion.

 Bullets Over Broadway

(Woody Allen, 1994)

9pm, UK Arena

Witty Woody back in the roaring 20s, with a case of don't shoot me, I'm only the playwright. John Cusack is a struggling writer given a Broadway spot by the Mob on condition his show stars gangster's moll Jennifer Tilly. But it's her bodyguard, Chazz Palminteri, who has the talent: he's as good with a pen as he is with a gun. A viciously funny attack on theatrical foibles, with Dianne Wiest (pictured) stealing the show and grabbing an Oscar as grand Broadway dame Helen Sinclair.

 The Waterdance

(Neal Jimenez, Michael Steinberg, 1992)

11pm, FilmFour

Co-director Jimenez also wrote this, from bitter experience after being paralysed for life by a fall. Playing him on screen, Eric Stoltz struggles to overcome bitterness and frustration with the help of fellow paraplegics in a rehabilitation ward. Helen Hunt is his married girlfriend, William Forsythe a racist biker and Wesley Snipes plays a sad dreamer.

 The End Of Violence

(Wim Wenders, 1997)

1.10am, Sky MovieMax

One of Wenders's stylish and enthralling American sojourns. Bill Pullman's shlock movie producer goes into hiding with a Mexican family after narrowly escaping an assassination attempt. The plot drifts from the devious to downright muddled, but there are lots of plusses: an engaging, oddball collection of characters, including an armed and dangerous Andie MacDowell
