fields.headline: Willie Hamilton
fields.standfirst: MP who was an outspoken critic of the royal family
fields.trailText: Willie Hamilton, who has died aged 82, was the MP for Fife for 37 years, and was the first Labour MP to be publicly critical of the Royal Family. He even pegged his two memoirs on that fame: My Queen And I (1974) and Blood On The Wall: The Memoirs Of An Anti-Royalist (1992).
fields.body:
Willie Hamilton, who has died aged 82, was the MP for Fife for 37 years, and was the first Labour MP to be publicly critical of the Royal Family. He even pegged his two memoirs on that fame: My Queen And I (1974) and Blood On The Wall: The Memoirs Of An Anti-Royalist (1992).

As a lean 32-year-old with carrot-coloured hair, he found his initial fame unnerving. He entered parliament in 1950, on his second try for West Fife, by ending the 15-year-long parliamentary career of the last Communist MP, Willie Gallacher. When Hamilton arrived at the Commons, instead of being treated as a conquering hero, he was shunned by Gallacher's many personal friends on the left.

Prime Minister Attlee's deputy, Herbert Morrison, tried to compensate by inviting him to the members' dining room, to be seen with him. "And then he walked away leaving me with a whopping bill," Hamilton complained to me. "I didn't have a bean. I had had to give up my teaching job to fight the election, and I hadn't yet received my first pay cheque as an MP."

This experience and his basic radical puritanism may have predisposed him to become a charter member of the Commons awkward squad, aptly describing himself as bloody-minded. At home he was against the establishment, the royals and patronage. But abroad he was a pro-Nato, anti-Communist, early pro-European.

This may have come from a mixture of family background and wartime experience. He was born in Durham, the son of a militantly left miner and devout churchman. Willie attended Puddock Stile elementary school in Newbottle, where he experienced at nine his first twinges of republicanism after having to wait for two hours in the cold to cheer a royal. He then went on to Washington grammar school and Sheffield university, where he joined the Labour party in 1936 and received a BA and a diploma in education.

Initially a conscientious objector, he joined the army in 1941 and wound up a captain in the Middle East. It was as such he contested West Fife in 1945. But his Communist opponent, Willie Gallacher, could then still harvest Scottish working class enthusiasm for the victorious Red Army. By 1950, the cold war had changed all that and - with the help of the local Catholic Action - Gallacher wound up in third place. Hamilton had spent the waiting years teaching history and geography in Huddersfield, teaching Workers Education Association and National Council of Labour Colleges classes in the evenings. In 1944 he had married nurse Joan Cullow; they had a son and a daughter.

As a loner with a hectoring tone, Hamilton did not win many friends initially among Labour MPs, partly because of his active anti-Communism. On one occasion he lined up with an anti-Communist Tory MP to attack the "treacherous activities" of the Daily Worker correspondent in Korea. He was furious at Britain's 1956 invasion of Egypt, favouring strikes, if necessary, to end it. He hailed the Hungarian uprising as an "overwhelming defeat for the Soviet Union". He was always on the side of those who wanted to expel leftwing rebels.

Curiously enough, Ted Heath's enthusiasm for the European Economic Community helped him. In the wake of boundary changes, he found it easier to be adopted for the new Central Fife seat after he told activists he would support EEC entry, admitting "I'm a (Roy) Jenkins man". He served as an appointed member of the European Assembly 1975-79. But, as a Durham man, he was no Scottish devolutionist, declaring in 1976 that it was a "a big step" down the road to separatism.

His attacks on the knighthood for Anthony Eden and birthday celebrations for Winston Churchill were hardly noticed; but he hit paydirt in 1971 when he described Princess Margaret as "this expensive kept woman" for her £82,000 allowance. He then said of the Queen Mother, "It is obscene that this House should be spending its time giving an old lady like that £95,000." In 1981 he demanded that the Windsors and the Spencers pay for the "disgusting display of conspicuous wealth" - the wedding of the Prince of Wales and Lady Diana - instead of the taxpayer. He introduced a bill to abolish hereditary peerages. In 1983 he said the Queen should have her inflation-geared overpayment clawed back like that of old-age pensioners.

That this royal-baiting was publicity-driven was indicated by the fact that he and his royalist second wife had met the Queen and Prince Philip the year before at Glenrothes. His first wife died in 1968 and there was some hilarity when he struck up a friendship with Tory MP Janet Fookes, whose embarrassment at being linked with so public an anti-royalist was ended when he married his former school friend, Mrs Margaret Cogle, in 1982.

In contrast to the publicity for his royal-bashing, his hard work for Commons select committees went almost unnoticed. He had been chairman of the estimates committee 1964-70, and went on to become chairman of the select committee on procedure 1975-76 and then a member of the powerful public accounts committee 1984-87. He was a tough inquisitor, not sparing his own side, as Labour ministers complained.

There was some surprise when he announced he would be standing down at the 1987 election. There had been a failed leftwing effort to oust him and he had not made himself more popular with the left in 1984 when he opposed the proposal for all Labour MPs to contribute £5 a week to the Arthur Scargill-led miners' strike. In fact, at 69 he admitted being tired of the "political battlefield".

He complicated his retirement from safe Central Fife by contesting hopeless South Hams that same year. Knowing MPs pointed out that MPs could pick up several thousand pounds more in retirement pay if defeated at the polls. This was not the case with Hamilton, who was past the ceiling for such bonuses. It was not impossible that he would have liked to cash in on any Tory tabloids claiming that this had been his motivation.

Retirement brought two shocks. He became an "unperson". "From being something of a VIP in the public eye, with a national platform and occasional TV and radio appearances, you become a second-class citizen," he observed. "Letters to the press and other public bodies are brushed aside with contempt."

The second problem was living on his pension. After 37 years in the Commons, his pension was £500 a month, rising to £600 in 1989. "For tunately I made an unearned and undeserved profit on the sale of my house in southeast London," he confessed. "So I was able to buy a comfortable wee bungalow at pretty Woodhall Spa in the Tory sticks of Lincolnshire." He and his wife raised roses, of which his favourite, he joked, was "Royal William".

 Willie (William Winter) Hamilton, politician, born June 26 1917; died January 23 2000

fields.headline: Gordon Chater
fields.trailText: The Australian actor Gordon Chater, who has died aged 77, achieved global acclaim for Steve J Spears' monologue The Elocution of Benjamin Franklin, a great tragic role which received rave reviews in Australia, Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York. In London it won nominations for the Society of West End Theatres and the Evening Standard awards.
fields.body:
The Australian actor Gordon Chater, who has died aged 77, achieved global acclaim for Steve J Spears' monologue The Elocution of Benjamin Franklin, a great tragic role which received rave reviews in Australia, Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York. In London it won nominations for the Society of West End Theatres and the Evening Standard awards.

Chater was born in London and educated at grammar school. He read medicine at Cambridge University, but the war interrupted his studies, and in 1941 he joined the Royal Navy and was a member of an entertainment troupe. On leave in Sydney, he fell in love with the city.

In 1947 he returned to live there, determined to be an actor. Chater's command of English accents won him a lot of radio work. Trashy serials were recorded during the day and stage plays and comedy - for which he had a natural talent - were acted at night. He first performed in theatrical revue at William Orr's Phillip Street Theatre in 1954. Shows such as Hit and Run and Top of the Bill anticipated the alter egos of Barry Humphries and provided a new socially-aware dimension in Australian theatre.

In the 1960s Chater played with Sybil Thorndike and Lewis Casson in The Chalk Garden and with Miriam Karlin in It's Underneath That Counts - which also played in London's West End - and became nationally famous in the television series My Name's McGooley, What's Yours?

In 1968, a depression was followed by a suicide attempt, and a career decline which lasted until the spectacular comeback in The Elocution of Benjamin Franklin. During the 1980s Chater was based in New York. He co-starred with Keir Dullea in The Interview and toured nationally. He returned to Australia in 1990, settling on southern Queensland's Gold Coast and emerging from time to time if a role amused him sufficiently.

Chater leaves a niece and a nephew.

 Gordon Chater, actor, born April 16 1922; died December 13 1999

He first performed in theatrical revue at William Orr's Phillip Street Theatre in 1954. Shows such as Hit and Run and Top of the Bill anticipated the alter egos of Barry Humphries and provided a new socially-aware dimension in Australian theatre. In the 1960s Chater played with Sybil Thorndike and Lewis Casson in The Chalk Garden and with Miriam Karlin in It's Underneath That Counts - which also played in London's West End - and became nationally famous in the television series My Name's McGooley, What's Yours? In 1968, a depression was followed by a suicide attempt, and a career decline which lasted until the spectacular comeback in The Elocution of Benjamin Franklin. During the 1980s Chater was based in New York. He co-starred with Keir Dullea in The Interview and toured nationally. He returned to Australia in 1990, settling on southern Queensland's Gold Coast and emerging from time to time if a role amused him sufficiently. Chater leaves a niece and a nephew.  Gordon Chater, actor, born April 16 1922; died December 13 1999

fields.headline: Suvi Raj Grubb
fields.standfirst: Persuasive guiding light in the classical recording studio
fields.trailText: Suvi Raj Grubb, who has died in Pune, India, aged 82, was - to his own surprise - a leading figure in classical recording from the 1970s until his retirement in 1985. That was when his company, EMI, was recording with such artists as Otto Klemperer, Carlo Maria Giulini, Dame Janet Baker, André Previn, Itzhak Perlman and Daniel Barenboim. Grubb worked with all of them, and was primarily responsible for the emergence of Barenboim as a recording artist.
fields.body:
Suvi Raj Grubb, who has died in Pune, India, aged 82, was - to his own surprise - a leading figure in classical recording from the 1970s until his retirement in 1985. That was when his company, EMI, was recording with such artists as Otto Klemperer, Carlo Maria Giulini, Dame Janet Baker, André Previn, Itzhak Perlman and Daniel Barenboim. Grubb worked with all of them, and was primarily responsible for the emergence of Barenboim as a recording artist.

It was Grubb who, as assistant to the great Walter Legge - not just an inspired recording producer but an impresario, and founder of the Philharmonia Orchestra - picked up the pieces when Legge precipitately resigned from EMI in 1964. Klemperer was recording Mozart's Zauberflöte, and Grubb stepped in to complete the project. From then on his independent career as a producer went from strength to strength.

Where Legge was a natural dictator, Grubb worked by persuasion, not just guiding his artists in the studio, relying on his acute ear, but promoting projects which he believed in, even in face of sceptical EMI bosses. It was Grubb who, on producing Barenboim's first EMI recording - of three popular Beethoven sonatas, the Pathétique, Moonlight and Appassionata - instantly saw the 23-year-old pianist's potential.

At a time when Beethoven sonata cycles were an extreme rarity - Artur Schnabel had done the first for EMI in the 1930s - Grubb instantly made the daring proposal to record all 32 sonatas with Barenboim. It seemed a rash project but Grubb, exploiting the pianist's facility to produce freshly spontaneous recordings, helped to make it an instant success.

Grubb followed that up with a series of major projects with Barenboim. They included a complete cycle of the Mozart piano concertos, Mozart symphonies and a series of chamber recordings in which Barenboim was joined by such artists as his wife, Jacqueline du Pré, and Pinchas Zukerman.

Grubb's association with Klemperer was also exceptionally fruitful, for he knew how to work by persuasion with that unpredictable artist. Klemperer knew nothing about recording, and when Grubb explained during a Mozart symphony recording that it was unnecessary to repeat the whole movement but only a section, Klemperer turned to his daughter in the control room, saying "Lotte, ein Schwindel," a swindle. And Grubb agreed.

He told that story in his memoirs, Music Makers On Record, giving a vivid picture of a producer dealing with often idiosyncratic artists, knowing how far to go in pressuring them, and when and how to encourage. His was a positive approach, stemming from his love of records and recording.

Born and educated in India, he took a science degree and was a record collector from his teens, and listened to concerts from all over the world on short-wave radio. He became an All India Radio record librarian and then music producer, but in 1953 he and his doctor wife, Chandra, moved to Britain.

He scraped a living as a freelance broadcaster and then became manager of London's Mahatma Gandhi Hall. As a founder-member of the Philharmonia Chorus he offered a rehearsal venue for the choir in the hall, and came to know Walter Legge. When Legge learned that Grubb was leaving his job, he asked him to become his assistant, after putting him through a musical-knowledge test.

Quickly Legge came to rely on Grubb to check all his recordings on matters of detail, and that was how Grubb was able to slot in so promptly on Legge's departure in 1964. For many years Grubb was the principal link between Legge and EMI, tactfully working with him on the recordings being made by Legge's wife, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf.

Grubb was sad that Legge finally came to resent his former assistant's success in the role in which he was supreme master, but which he had no chance to practice any more. After his retirement Grubb and his wife went to live in Spain and then in India, defying a series of heart attacks.

His wife survives him.

webTitle: Ecuador Indians give new leader 6 months' grace

fields.headline: Ecuador Indians give new leader 6 months' grace
fields.trailText: Thousands of pensioners have been queueing from early morning outside banks in Quito to withdraw monthly benefit payments which have lost half their value in the past month alone, in line with the declining value of the sucre, Ecuador's currency.
fields.body:
Thousands of pensioners have been queueing from early morning outside banks in Quito to withdraw monthly benefit payments which have lost half their value in the past month alone, in line with the declining value of the sucre, Ecuador's currency.

"If I eat once a day the pension lasts a week," said Rosa Duran, a retired nurse, who waited three hours to receive her 500,000 sucre payment.

A year ago her pension was worth £46 dollars, today it is worth £11. An estimated four million Ecuadoreans survive on £28 a month, while the average food basket costs four times that amount.

There was little sign of support for the new president, Gustavo Noboa, who has pledged to continue the economic policy of his predecessor Jamil Mahuad, who was ousted after Indian protests and a military coup last weekend.

"I hope they come back and finish the job," said Ms Duran, referring to the frustrated efforts of the Indian population to replace the country's discredited congress with a "government of national reconstruction", which would include Indian, labour, army and religious representatives. Last year Mr Mahuad reacted to the deepening economic crisis by freezing bank accounts, but paid $700m to one bank to keep it afloat, causing public outrage.

Two weeks ago the former president drew up the "Law of Stabilisation", which would replace the sucre with the US dollar in the hope of curbing inflation and allowing the country to borrow money at US interest rates.

Indian and labour leaders denounced the plan as little more than a lifeline to corrupt bankers and big business, while the poor watched food items double in price over the past fortnight.

The dollarisation of the economy would also wipe out much of the value of frozen savings accounts, which were deposited at 7,000 sucres to the dollar, but will be withdrawn at 25,000 to the dollar, according to the current exchange rate.

The mishandling of the economic crisis cost Mr Mahuad his job last Saturday. Mr Noboa, who was his vice president, is the fourth president to take office in two years.

Antonio Vargas, leader of the powerful Indian confederation, Conaie, announced that his organisation would give the new administration six months to reverse the economic decline or face renewed mass protest.

In the past century Ecuador has relied on single cash crops to support its economy, first textiles, then cocoa, then bananas and finally oil - much of which backfired when world prices collapsed.

Thousands of small account holders, many of them pensioners, fear they may die before they ever see the small nest eggs they deposited in banks when a degree of faith still existed in local financial institutions.

Ecuador suffered a 60% inflation rate last year, while unemployment has risen to 20% and the cost of the foreign debt is equal to the country's GNP, approximately $15bn.

"We must all have faith in Ecuador and work together to overcome this difficult situation" Mr Noboa said yesterday

But he faces an uphill task as he relies on support from a deeply-divided congress, where deputies face elections for a new parliament in two months.

fields.headline: News in Brief
fields.trailText: Wall that barred Gypsies on sale
fields.body:
Wall that barred Gypsies on sale

The concrete wall which separated Gypsies from other residents in the north Czech city of Usti nad Labem last year is to be auctioned by the local council.

The wall, two metres high and 65 metres long, caused outrage when it was built in October to segregate a Gypsy community and was torn down by protestors six weeks later. The council is hoping for £4,000.

Saudi killer is beheaded

A man convicted of murder was beheaded in Saudi Arabia yesterday - the first such execution in 2000.

Amash Mohsen al-Qahtani was executed for shooting dead a fellow Saudi following a dispute, it said. Last year at least 99 people were beheaded, following Saudi Arabia's strict interpretation of Islamic law.

Turkey bans Kurdish book

A Turkish court has ordered that copies of a book on Kurdish history by a US professor be seized for promoting ethnic separatism, publishers of A History of Kurdish Nationalism: Its Roots and Development, said yesterday.

Turkey frequently imposes curbs on books about Kurdish issues as part of its battle against Kurdish separatist rebels in the southeast.

Aborigines to protest at Games

The Australian of the year, scientist Sir Gustav Nossal, urged Aborigines yesterday, Australia Day, to protest during the 2000 Olympic games in Sydney to draw attention to the condition of the country's indigenous population.

webTitle: Jews find new refuge in Germany

fields.headline: Jews find new refuge in Germany
fields.standfirst: Ukrainians seek an unlikely haven from anti-semitism, as British plans are unveiled to ensure victims of genocide are not forgotten
fields.trailText: Marina Sloboda always wanted to be an actress. She is an evidently intelligent woman with keen eyes and an expressive face. But she said that in her native Ukraine, being Jewish meant her ambition was blocked at every turn.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Peitz, eastern Germany
fields.body:
Marina Sloboda always wanted to be an actress. She is an evidently intelligent woman with keen eyes and an expressive face. But she said that in her native Ukraine, being Jewish meant her ambition was blocked at every turn.

She was not allowed into the equivalent of sixth-form college even though she had the necessary qualifications. She went to night classes instead, before moving to a technical college.

"My grandmother had given me a Star of David on a chain to wear round my neck. I used to keep it hidden. But then one day I bent over and it swung out. The principal accused me of being me a secret Zionist. He set about trying to expel me. And in the end he succeeded."

As Jewish leaders and heads of state gathered in Stockholm yesterday for what is thought to be the biggest conference to be held on the Holocaust, Ms Sloboda waited with her family in a transit centre - one of the latest Jews searching for a refuge from discrimination.

Her story is commonplace, repeated throughout almost 2,000 years of European anti-semitism. What makes it exceptional is that the country to which she has fled - Germany - gave birth to the most gruesomely effective anti-semitic pogrom the world has ever seen.

Thanks to a project launched 10 years ago, Germany is home to the world's fastest-growing Jewish community. Since 1990, at least 60,000 people have poured in from the former Soviet Union, tripling the size of Germany's Jewish population.

They were first invited as an act of contrition by the post-Communist government in East Germany. The programme was then adopted by the heads of reunified Germany's state governments.

Applicants must spend five days in transit centres such as this one close to the Polish border between Berlin and Dresden. During that time, they must prove to German officials - and historical ironies do not come much richer than this - that they are Jewish, and thus deserving of preferential treatment similar to that given to immigrants of German origin.

Helga Peuke, the government official in charge of the centre, said the procedures were usually straightforward: "Soviet documents identified Jews as such."

From the transit centres, the refugees are taken to hostels on the outskirts of Berlin and in the big cities of eastern Germany. They are offered a six-month language course and full access to Germany's generous system of health and social security. But they can only move on from the hostel when they secure work and accommodation elsewhere.

The biggest problem most face is that they are over-qualified for the German job market. Marina Sloboda's husband, Yuri, was born a Christian and says he is now agnostic. But he is typical of those arriving under the Jewish immigration scheme. Once a doctor, he was the general manager of a pharmaceutical firm until his departure.

"We didn't leave for financial reasons," he said. "What was more important was that we didn't feel sure of our future in Ukraine or that of our daughter".

He cast a glance at nine-year old Stefania. "I hope she will become Steffi in Germany," he said with a smile. "She had a problem of identity and self-esteem in Ukraine. Sometimes she didn't want to say that she had Jewish origins."

He said there was no longer any official anti-semitism in Ukraine. It was the little things that disturbed him. Where he comes from, there is a Christmas tradition of dressing up to represent stock characters. One is the Jew. Ms Sloboda produced a photograph of a figure in a grotesque mask with a red face and a long nose. "His role is to scare the children," said Mr Sloboda.

"I have no intention of living off social security forever," he added. "I have taught myself some German in Ukraine. I hope that in a year I will be able to speak it fluently. I am under no illusions about the difficulties of rebuilding my career here. But I already have friends in a couple of pharmaceutical companies in Germany."

Such intentions are characteristic of the new arrivals, said Ms Peuke. "But I always caution them to take things slowly."

"If they are young and active, they make out somehow, legally or illegally," said Irene Runge, co-author of a guide book for new Jewish immigrants. "The real difficulty is for the 'sandwich generation', those in the 40 to 50 age bracket. We get experts in Greek philosophy. They know Greek, Latin, English and French, but not German. Those people face a challenge."

At 38, Yuri Sloboda is on the cusp. Yet he is heartened by what he has already seen. He has just read Ms Runge's guide, which says that 15% of Germans hold anti-semitic views.

"Here at least it is in the open. You would never find those sorts of facts in a publication in Ukraine. Here you have sociological data and open discussion."

His wife was more pragmatic. "In Ukraine, I did not hear of any emigrants coming back", she said. "People of Jewish origins are very sensitive to oppression. If they sense danger, they move on. If there were a danger, they would have left."

webTitle: Minister acts on France's violence-plagued schools

fields.headline: Minister acts on France's violence-plagued schools
fields.trailText: In Longwy they used soldering irons and cigarettes to torture a 14-year-old. In Mantes-la-Jolie they threw an 11-year-old off a first-floor balcony. In Bondy they hurled petrol bombs in the corridors, set fire to a door, and assaulted a teaching assistant.
fields.body:
In Longwy they used soldering irons and cigarettes to torture a 14-year-old. In Mantes-la-Jolie they threw an 11-year-old off a first-floor balcony. In Bondy they hurled petrol bombs in the corridors, set fire to a door, and assaulted a teaching assistant.

A wave of violence sweeping France's secondary schools has closed half a dozen schools, from Roubaix in the north to Montpellier in the south, after strikes by teachers and protests from angry parents.

The education minister, Claude Allègre, is today expected to announce the appointment of 20,000 new teaching assistants and social workers to patrol corridors and playgrounds, help out in classrooms and give extra civic education sessions in the 400-plus secondary schools identified as having "problematic" levels of violence.

One such school is the Collège Maurice-Thorez in Seine Saint-Denis, a notoriously difficult suburb north of Paris, whose 53 teachers - two-thirds of them probationers - voted unanimously to go on strike on Monday after a cleaner was attacked and beaten by four pupils. "It was just one incident too many," said Marie-Pierre Guibert, a history and geography teacher in her first job. She said she had got used to the students' latest sport of throwing chairs through classroom windows, and managed to harden herself to being spat on from behind every time she crossed the playground.

An older colleague, Arnaud Caussé, said: "Four years ago when I arrived, I was told I shouldn't try for any kind of results - just make sure things didn't get too out of hand. Now they have."

At the Collège Jean-Zay in nearby Bondy, which has been closed for nearly a week, a French teacher, Catherine Perrin, said she had pupils "who are so scared they won't use the staircases. They prefer to stay in the classroom rather than go into the playground. And they'll avoid going to the toilet all day."

Mr Allègre's promised reforms are the latest in a long line of "anti-violence plans" over the past 15 years.

They have not had much effect: a survey released last week by a professor of education, Eric Debarbieux, concluded that school violence had increased markedly between 1995 and 1998, and that its nature was changing.

"There is a distinct development in 'anti-school' violence, against teachers," the report said. "In addition, acts of delinquency are being committed more and more often by groups of children, and are getting more violent."

Many teachers doubt that Mr Allègre's plans will improve the situation, pointing to larger problems behind the violence. Most of the schools affected are in depressed city suburbs with high immigrant populations and unemployment of up to 30%.

"There are classic social problems here: lack of academic motivation, an atmosphere of violence outside, children caught between two cultures," said Mr Caussé. "No amount of extra educational funding will really beat them."

Others believe the educational system is at fault. Marie-Danielle Pierrelée, a former headteacher and author of a new book on difficult schools, said France's highly academic, centralised system "is tailored for one category of students - those destined for long studies at university. There are more and more pupils who can't find their place there."

Most educationists, however, agree on one essential step: continuity of school staff. Most of the hardest-hit schools have sunk into a spiral of violence, in part because they are staffed mainly by young, inexperienced teachers and because more than half the staff is replaced each year.

Mr Allègre is said to favour regional recruitment, as opposed to the present system in which most teachers are allocated posts at national level.

In the meantime, Marie Cuillerat, the mother of a final-year pupil at Collège Jean-Zay, is keeping her son out of school for now. "I don't want to have to pick him up from the doctor's or the hospital."

The education minister, Claude Allègre, is today expected to announce the appointment of 20,000 new teaching assistants and social workers to patrol corridors and playgrounds, help out in classrooms and give extra civic education sessions in the 400-plus secondary schools identified as having "problematic" levels of violence. One such school is the Collège Maurice-Thorez in Seine Saint-Denis, a notoriously difficult suburb north of Paris, whose 53 teachers - two-thirds of them probationers - voted unanimously to go on strike on Monday after a cleaner was attacked and beaten by four pupils. "It was just one incident too many," said Marie-Pierre Guibert, a history and geography teacher in her first job. She said she had got used to the students' latest sport of throwing chairs through classroom windows, and managed to harden herself to being spat on from behind every time she crossed the playground. An older colleague, Arnaud Caussé, said: "Four years ago when I arrived, I was told I shouldn't try for any kind of results - just make sure things didn't get too out of hand. Now they have." At the Collège Jean-Zay in nearby Bondy, which has been closed for nearly a week, a French teacher, Catherine Perrin, said she had pupils "who are so scared they won't use the staircases. They prefer to stay in the classroom rather than go into the playground. And they'll avoid going to the toilet all day." Mr Allègre's promised reforms are the latest in a long line of "anti-violence plans" over the past 15 years. They have not had much effect: a survey released last week by a professor of education, Eric Debarbieux, concluded that school violence had increased markedly between 1995 and 1998, and that its nature was changing. "There is a distinct development in 'anti-school' violence, against teachers," the report said. "In addition, acts of delinquency are being committed more and more often by groups of children, and are getting more violent." Many teachers doubt that Mr Allègre's plans will improve the situation, pointing to larger problems behind the violence. Most of the schools affected are in depressed city suburbs with high immigrant populations and unemployment of up to 30%. "There are classic social problems here: lack of academic motivation, an atmosphere of violence outside, children caught between two cultures," said Mr Caussé. "No amount of extra educational funding will really beat them." Others believe the educational system is at fault. Marie-Danielle Pierrelée, a former headteacher and author of a new book on difficult schools, said France's highly academic, centralised system "is tailored for one category of students - those destined for long studies at university. There are more and more pupils who can't find their place there." Most educationists, however, agree on one essential step: continuity of school staff. Most of the hardest-hit schools have sunk into a spiral of violence, in part because they are staffed mainly by young, inexperienced teachers and because more than half the staff is replaced each year. Mr Allègre is said to favour regional recruitment, as opposed to the present system in which most teachers are allocated posts at national level. In the meantime, Marie Cuillerat, the mother of a final-year pupil at Collège Jean-Zay, is keeping her son out of school for now. "I don't want to have to pick him up from the doctor's or the hospital."

webTitle: Blair sets date for Holocaust memorial

fields.headline: Blair sets date for Holocaust memorial
fields.trailText: Special stamps, memorial candles and a free book for every household in Britain are among the ideas being considered by ministers to mark the first national Holocaust memorial day, on January 27 next year.
fields.body:
Special stamps, memorial candles and a free book for every household in Britain are among the ideas being considered by ministers to mark the first national Holocaust memorial day, on January 27 next year.

Tony Blair confirmed yesterday that the anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp will be used to honour the memory of the victims of genocide.

"As the Holocaust survivors age and become fewer in number, it becomes more and more our duty to take up the mantle and tell each generation what happened and what could happen again," the prime minister said.

The Holocaust is already marked by memorial days in the US and nine European countries. Mr Blair, who made his announcement on a visit to the Anne Frank Trust exhibition in Westminster's Central Hall, London, said he saw the remembrance as part of a bid to build a new sort of patriotism open to all.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said a working group was being set up to consider exactly how the day is to be marked, but it will include a national "non-religious" ceremony with senior public figures.

Other ideas under consideration include a commemorative stamp or franking stamp on all mail, and invitations to Holocaust survivors to speak in classes and school assemblies.

There are also plans to offer every household in Britain a free book on the Holocaust, following a similar initiative in Sweden.

fields.headline: China blocks internet explosion
fields.standfirst: Secret checkers to be used to control online activity as regime takes fright
fields.trailText: Beijing has imposed tough new controls on the country's estimated 9m internet users, banning them from publishing "state secrets" on the web. The catch is that no one in China can be entirely sure what is or is not a secret.
fields.byline: John Gittings in Hong Kong and Patrick Barkham
fields.body:
Beijing has imposed tough new controls on the country's estimated 9m internet users, banning them from publishing "state secrets" on the web. The catch is that no one in China can be entirely sure what is or is not a secret.

Human rights observers said it was the most swingeing clampdown the world has known on the free use of cyberspace. The new regulations, announced in yesterday's Communist party newspaper, say that "all organisations and individuals are forbidden from releasing, discussing or transferring state secret information on bulletin boards, chat rooms or in internet newsgroups".

Interpreting the new rules could prove a very difficult task in a political culture where the limits of secrecy are never defined. The term can cover economic statistics and political news as well as military information. With the press still controlled largely by the Communist party, it is often hard to determine what has been published officially; the only definite criterion for what is not a "state secret".

Any electronic links between domestic and foreign websites are also covered by the ban, "whether direct or indirect" - raising fears that the use of the internet to connect political groups with the outside world will also be suppressed. China has already blocked access to some foreign websites including the BBC Online service, but users are continually finding mirror sites which can evade the restrictions.

State interference

Observers expressed alarm yesterday at the scale of the Chinese clampdown. Andrew Puddephatt, director of the freedom of expression campaign Article 19, said that up to now the internet had been allowed to exist in most countries relatively free of state interference.

"Any attempt by any government to impose censorship of the kind commonly applied to newspapers and television networks around the world must be regarded as a very dangerous precedent," he said.

Beijing leaders, from President Jiang Zemin downwards, became anxious last year when sensitive and supposedly secret information surfaced on several Chinese websites. The launch of China's first unmanned spacecraft in November was revealed on a domestic website two days before it actually took place. The unauthorised report even gave details of the spacecraft's planned return to earth in Inner Mongolia.

Other embarrassing breaches of security included sites which published details about China's naval ship-building programme and information about new aircraft construction. Most of these lapses appear to originate from computer fanatics who have no political motive but want to show they are well-informed.

An engineer at a space centre is said to have used a picture of a secret workshop as an illustration on his own website. A technician at the Shanghai Jiangnan shipyard ended up in court after bragging that his yard was making China's first aircraft carrier.

The regime's fears about the growth of internet culture in China extends to religious groups organising themselves through cyberspace. Mr Jiang suspects that the banned Falun Gong cult, which believes it can prolong life through breathing exercises, used the internet to mobilise thousands of its members for a silent demonstration last April in Beijing.

Mr Jiang is also well aware that President Bill Clinton and other US leaders, including the secretary of state Madeleine Albright, have hailed the internet as a way of "opening up" China to foreign ideas.

The authorities' concern is heightened by the rapid surge in China's internet use, which grew by more than four times last year. The number of individual online users increased from from 2.1m in December 1998 to 8.9m last month and is forecast to double this year to 20m.

Secrecy checkers

A recent survey shows that about half surf the net from their homes. Previously most users went online from internet cafes or at work where monitoring is easier. Half of all users live in Beijing but access is spreading and the first internet cafe has just opened in Lhasa, capital of Tibet.

The clampdown will create a new breed of locally-created censors. Every website or large organisation with computer links to the internet must now employ its own monitors, dubbed "secrecy checkers", to make sure nothing which the government defines as a secret is published.

The new regulations, like all other internal Chinese legislation, do not apply in Hong Kong. But Beijing is concerned that "secret" information transmitted from China is then "re-broadcast" back to the mainland where it may even be picked by official newspapers.

The new regulations also prohibit China's domestic websites from hiring reporters to generate their own news content. "I don't think news will be completely banned from the websites," said an independent website manager from Shanghai who was quoted yesterday by the Shanghai Daily. "What the government really wants is to curb unauthorised news."

Users are in the dark as to what penalties Beijing will apply to those who break the new restrictions. Offending websites are likely to be closed down.

In recent months the Chinese government has closed down several newspapers as a punishment for printing "sensational stories" and "articles with political errors". Some journalists have also been sent to prison for publishing "state secrets".

The slow spread of cyber suppression

Burma

The Burmese authorities announced a ban on using the internet to disseminate political information last week.

It forbade emails and other information published on the internet deemed "detrimental to the government". Those found spreading such information will join the 13 journalists currently in Burmese jails.

The watchdog group Reporters Sans Frontières says internet access is severely curtailed in Burma. A month ago, two local, privately owned internet service providers (ISPs) were shut down. The only ISP left is the government-operated Myanmar Posts & Telecommunications.

The country's 1996 computer law decrees that only those with official authorisation can use the internet. A cybercafe opened in the capital Rangoon last year, but it offered no access to the internet.

Indonesia

Internet newsgroups and websites were used to mobilise support for East Timor's battle for independence both inside and outside Indonesia.

A year ago, an Irish-based ISP was forced to shut down after the East Timorese site it was hosting was bombarded by cyber "terrorists". The Indonesian government was implicated in the attack on the website.

Jordan

The Jordanian government maintains that "there is no blocking or censoring by the government of the content of any websites or of electronic communications via newsgroups, email or other internet forums".

Jordanians have used the internet to access foreign newspapers banned in Jordan, but Human Rights Watch has found evidence of state suppression of online political activity.

Last October, two university students were arrested for trying to launch a website to "combat normalisation" of relations with Israel. The Jordan Times wrote: "It is somewhat worrying that the authorities were not more forthcoming in describing the nature of the students' offences in creating the website."

Malaysia

Email and newsgroups were widely used by students in the 1998 uprisings against the Malaysian government.

Four people were arrested that year and charged with spreading email rumours about riots in the capital, Kuala Lumpur.

In December 1998, the government ruled that cybercafes must record all people who use their computers. The government vowed that the police would examine all internet postings in the country.

But there are signs that Malaysia is relaxing its internet regulations. Last spring the prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, announced that internet access would be free from censorship.

Sri Lanka

Last August, a Sri Lankan government minister admitted intercepting an email sent to the leader of the country's opposition from the British advertising company, Saatchi & Saatchi. The science and technology minister, Batty Weerakoon, admitted he handed the email to the state-run media.

The opposition said the incident was typical of the government's snooping on private emails between politicians, journalists and private businessmen.

webTitle: Tasmanian tiger may return from the dead

fields.headline: Tasmanian tiger may return from the dead
fields.standfirst: Scientists hope to recreate extinct beast with DNA from specimen
fields.trailText: The Tasmanian tiger might once again skulk through the forests of Australia. A complex experiment is this week extracting the first tissue samples from a preserved specimen of the beast, which became extinct 70 years ago.
fields.body:
The Tasmanian tiger might once again skulk through the forests of Australia. A complex experiment is this week extracting the first tissue samples from a preserved specimen of the beast, which became extinct 70 years ago.

The team at the Australia Museum in Sydney hopes that enough well-defined DNA can be found in the samples of the tiger (or thylacine) to begin a cloning process, leading eventually to the creation of a living Tasmanian tiger and the re-population of the species.

The thylacine was a large dog-like, carnivorous marsupial that inhabited Tasmania and the eastern ranges of the mainland. It had distinctive tiger-like stripes across its lower back and rump.

The leader of the project is the museum's director Professor Mike Archer.

"I've had the idea for over a decade. Many people thought cloning of animals would never come around and then along came Dolly the sheep. There were all those statements that we could not clone an animal and then suddenly we could," he said.

"What is unique and so exciting about this project is that we are dealing with effectively dead DNA - bringing a creature back to life

"Almost all we know about the thylacine is from mythology. Everybody took them for granted and it wasn't until the last one died in 1936 did the authorities get worried.

"We played God when we pushed the thylacine to extinction. I'm suggesting we play smart human and try to reverse a tragedy that we precipitated," Prof Archer said.

The tissue samples are being taken from a specimen of a six-month-old thylacine pup preserved in alcohol - a solution which also maintains DNA.

Scientists need to find a comprehensive DNA sample and extract it in one piece from the pup. From that DNA the tiger's genetic blueprint would have to be inserted into the egg of a close relative, probably the Tasmanian devil or the numbat, for incubation.

Depending on how close a relative the host animal is, the risk of it rejecting the egg could be high and even if the experiment works, the result might look very different from the true Tasmanian tiger.

The use of a surrogate mother to carry the egg would not result in the birth of a perfect Tasmanian tiger offspring but a hybrid mix of both species' genes. To get a creature closest to a thylacine scientists would have to devise a way of minimising the transferral of genetic characteristics from the host species to the tiger embryo.

Prof Archer has crossed picket lines to get to his office at the museum and his work has been denounced by religious groups who accuse the scientists of playing God.

"There are theological objections to this work but the objectors have to back off," said Prof Archer. "This is the way science, and life, is going."

The cloning of the Tasmanian tiger is being funded by a charitable foundation set up by two former Tasmanians who want to see the re-creation of the beast. Prof Archer said the premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, had pledged Aus$20,000 (£8,000) to the programme.

The decline might have been due to the prevalence of the more aggressive dingo. Prof Archer says the thylacine was a "gentleman hunter" and not given to acts of aggression.

"But the thylacine is also extinct because we are stupid," he said. "We took it for granted and hunted it out."

webTitle: Chileans see straight through art project

fields.headline: Chileans see straight through art project
fields.trailText: General Pinochet has been driven off the front pages of Chile's newspapers by a naked performance artist. Much larger crowds than those which rallied last weekend in support of the general have been clogging the streets of central Santiago to glimpse the woman taking a shower in a transparent house.
fields.body:
General Pinochet has been driven off the front pages of Chile's newspapers by a naked performance artist. Much larger crowds than those which rallied last weekend in support of the general have been clogging the streets of central Santiago to glimpse the woman taking a shower in a transparent house.

The house is part of a piece of performance art designed to reflect the limits of privacy in society, according to the director of Fondart, the government's arts fund which is sponsoring the project.

For the next two months, the actor Daniella Tobar will carry on her daily life in the specially constructed house which stands on an empty building site in the heart of the city.

Every morning she will get up at around 9am, brush her teeth, take a shower, attend to her bodily functions and eat her breakfast in full view of people on their way to work.

"It is a call for people to reflect on the relationship between the public and the private," said Nivia Palma, the director of Fondart. As part of the project, named Nautilus, the passers-by who stop to watch are filmed.

Nautilus is the brainchild of two young architects, Arturo Torres and Jorge Cristi, who say they accept that not everyone will understand what they are trying to achieve.

"We are taking the notion of art to the limit in the sense that life can be an artistic work," said Mr Torres, who has been working on the idea for two years. He said that he had chosen a woman to play the part because women are traditionally linked to sin in the Judaeo-Christian culture, and because people were more used to seeing men urinating in the street or stripped to the waist on a building site.

"Perhaps Chile is not ready for it," Mr Torres said. But part of Chile was clearly more than ready for it and by lunchtime, crowds of mainly men - some of them standing on the tops of vans - had gathered to watch Tobar.

Her morning shower had been greeted with cheers and many in the crowd were anxious to persuade her to repeat it in the middle of a 30C (86F) day. Tobar, a friend of the architects, chatted on her mobile phone to friends and busied herself around the house.

Chile is much more culturally conservative than its neighbours Argentina and Brazil. Since the 1973 military coup, artists and actors have often been regarded by Pinochet supporters as subversives.

It was not long before the police arrived to question Tobar and see whether an offence against public decency was being committed. They left after seeing her identity card. She has described the project as an interesting experience which she is enjoying.

The news coverage has focused on the notion of what art is, whether the government should be funding the project to the tune of £6,000 and how many showers one should take in such hot weather.

During the recent presidential election campaign, there were calls for greater transparency in public life in a country that is still emerging from the dark days of dictatorship, but the transparency on Moneda Street might not be exactly what the candidates had in mind.

The house is not permanent and will be taken to Buenos Aires for a repeat performance.

Despite some criticism from city officials that Tobar's performance was taking place too close to a nearby church, the general reaction on the street, even among older residents, seemed favourable, with many jokes being cracked and cheerful al fresco discussions breaking out.

Tobar is fast becoming a celebrity as hundreds assemble to tell her just what people in glass houses should do.

Despite some criticism from city officials that Tobar's performance was taking place too close to a nearby church, the general reaction on the street, even among older residents, seemed favourable, with many jokes being cracked and cheerful al fresco discussions breaking out. Tobar is fast becoming a celebrity as hundreds assemble to tell her just what people in glass houses should do.

fields.headline: Fear of falling
fields.standfirst: This week a lift in the Empire State Building fell 400ft in four seconds.  Emma Brockes  finds out what really happens when the bottom drops out of your world
fields.trailText: This week a lift in the Empire State Building fell 400ft in four seconds.  Emma Brockes  finds out what really happens when the bottom drops out of your world
fields.body:
There is a small fairground near Lyon, south east France, where revellers can pay 10 francs to experience the thrilling few moments preceding death by lift accident. A cage is raised to the top of a 40-ft pole where, after pausing for the stiff breeze to register how high it is, it plunges to a standstill several feet above the ground and ejects its passengers, limp with fright. The whimpers of my French exchange partner in those terrible seconds before the drop, remain with me 10 years on.

That was a fall of 40ft in five seconds. Imagine then, the gut-flipping ride endured by Shameka Peterson and Joe Masoraca, two office workers who stepped into a lift on the 44th floor of New York's Empire State Building on Monday and arrived at the fourth floor four seconds later. "I thought I was going to die," said Masoraca, of the 400-ft dive. "It was like a bungee fall," said Peterson. "Golly," said a receptionist at Elevator Building Services in Kent. "We've been talking about it all morning."

Lift disasters occupy a special place in popular imagination, something to do with the few seconds of anticipatory dread before impact. Remember the opening sequence in the film Speed, where a woman hangs over a lift shaft with a runaway car racing tantalisingly towards her legs. Or the irresistible combo of fire and elevator terror explored in the film Towering Inferno. Or the sequence in Superman II in which Lois Lane falls the length of the Eiffel Tower before her hero catches the run-away lift.

For the non-scientist, every lift ride is a small and disturbing negotiation with the laws of physics. How many times have you ridden a lift and idly choreographed the action you would take in the event of a terrifying death plunge? And how often has that plan involved jumping in the air at the moment of impact? Well, forget it. Once and for all, that jumping thing won't work.

"You would have to jump so hard you would break your legs," says Dr Richard Jameson, lecturer in physics at the university of Leicester. "Imagine you are hurtling towards the earth at 50mph. In order to avoid impact, your jump must propel you from 0-50 in one second. It is an entirely bogus proposition."

What will save you, in this fondly imagined scenario, is a series of advanced safety mechanisms that, according to lift experts, are proof against any eventuality bar acts of God. "There was one case, in the 1930s, when an aircraft flew into the side of the Empire State Building and severed the suspension cable with its wings," says Ish Buckingham, the editor of Elevation Magazine, trade paper for the British lift industry. "But apart from cases like that, which smash the whole system, even if a lift cable snaps there are safety devices to stop it from falling."

The likelihood of being involved in a lift accident is slightly lower than that of hurting yourself on a flight of stairs. "In a straightforward traction lift there is something called an over-speed governor," explains David Sazakerley, director of the Lift and Escalator Industry Association. "In an extreme situation like the Empire State Building, a safety gear is activated, which fits into the guide rails and locks the lift into the shaft."

That is what saved Gary Ronaldson, Melanie MacDonald and their pet dog Tara in 1995, when the lift they were in fell six floors down the shaft of an Edinburgh tower block. Like the people in the Empire State plunge, the Scottish pair were rescued by an emergency braking system programmed to narrow the lift shaft when the carriage hurtled past. Except, frown experts, that "hurtled" is an image only applicable to the Hollywood fantasy version of events.

"It sounds like the whole thing has been exaggerated," says Buckingham with an expert's scepticism. "In the Empire State Building case, only the compensatory cable snapped, which means that while the lift may have moved uncontrollably for a while, it would not have gone over a critical speed. We're not talking a Disney park ride here."

"If a lift was actually free-falling, those inside would experience weightlessness," says Dr Jameson. "It would be rather like jumping off a high diving board."

Instead, a wobbly but otherwise intact Peterson and Masoraca, emerged from the lift shaft after clambering along a beam to an adjoining car. It is doubtful this will deter movie producers, however, for whom Monday's plunge is something of a long-awaited green light. Instead of being a titillating frill on the main action, the grisly lift scene can, with "based on true story" authority, now occupy the entire plot.

fields.headline: I wanna go home
fields.trailText: Old age drove Lexy Campbell, the last resident, off Taransay. But for the rest of her life, there wasn't a day that went by when she didn't look back over the short, green stretch of sea from her new home at Seilebost on nearby Harris.
fields.body:
Old age drove Lexy Campbell, the last resident, off Taransay. But for the rest of her life, there wasn't a day that went by when she didn't look back over the short, green stretch of sea from her new home at Seilebost on nearby Harris.

Neighbours say she would have stayed out on Taransay all her days if she could have, instead of passing her final two decades watching from the window when the light was good.

Quite what Lexy would have made of the comings and goings on the remote island of Taransay these past few weeks is anyone's guess. Most think she would have been bemused. Some say she would have been horrified. Others suspect she might have quite enjoyed it all, especially the lights at night, shining out across the darkness of the sound - proof of a new community on her beloved island.

But the truth is that not everybody is home on Taransay. In fact a pretty large proportion of the BBC's celebrated castaways actually seem to be here, a mile and a half away across the water on the island of Harris. Ensconced in the warmth of the Harris Hotel in Tarbert, they are taking tea and arguing about the ablutions on their temporary home.

"Public health are coming to have a look at it and once they see there's only one toilet for 50 people, they'll see how bad it is," says one woman in a smart waterproof.

"Five scones, please," says another, as the waitress hovers patiently for their order. They seem to have acquired a dog - Charlie, a collie - and make plans to watch themselves on TV later from the sofas in the residents' lounge. They introduce themselves to other guests as the castaways, and ask if they can switch to BBC1.

Charlie gets walked in the hotel garden and the children play chase around the chairs and tables, getting bored and restless. A helicopter, specially chartered by the programme makers, shifts them back and forward from the island; commuting, really. This is clearly not how it was supposed to be and it's getting dreadfully tense.

It must have looked good on paper, though. Drop 36 complete strangers on an uninhabited island on Hogmanay, give them some help to build their eco-pod homes, film them for the first few weeks then give them a video camera, leave them to it and watch the ratings rise. They weren't supposed to come off the island. At least not this often.

Yesterday, with the press gathering in hordes in the hotel's public bar, the show's executive producer Jeremy Mills held an impromptu news conference and admitted that the community has become split between those who are staying on the island and those staying in the hotel.

He lists 18 people who have been off the island for some or most of the time. Most are families, some are ill. Jeremy thinks this is a good thing. He won't accept that the BBC's £2.4m flagship millennium project is disintegrating into chaos and farce before his eyes.

"From my point of view all that is fantastic material," he says brightly. "The pressure that it's put them all under as two groups of people has brought out some utterly fascinating insights into human nature and human relationships from a TV point of view. That's the key thing."

The castaways in the hotel don't look so sure. They say they'd love to talk, that all is not well, but contracts are keeping them quiet. Jeremy says if they did talk they would have to leave. One family are considering doing just that. The programme makers have told the troubled castaways that Friday is the deadline for getting back to the island if they want to stay in the show. A kind of relaunch. All or nothing. Stay or go.

When the castaways got there, Taransay itself was much as Lexy had left it. A few small buildings falling to ruin, a sheltered beach - and sheep. Now they have a washing machine - cold water only - shower facilities and a school.

But there's also been the flu, and forces of nature, and roofs blown off, and crates of belongings dropped in the sea, and housing blocks not ready, and chickens that never came and personalities that didn't mesh.

Just round the corner from the hotel in the kitchen of her neat terraced house, 88-year-old Mary Munro makes you tea and laughs gently at the complete absurdity of it all. She can remember being on Taransay with Lexy, her second cousin, when they were children, spending hours scraping crotal, a form of lichen, off the rocks to dye the Harris Tweed.

"There were about 12 to 14 houses then, and a community," she says. "It was lovely. It is very different now. We were used to doing without water. There was no washing machine. You just had to get on and do it all. We were quite happy with it, doing everything, You used to have to draw the water from the well, bring it home and heat it and do the washing. Quite a handful when I think on it now.

"The castaways aren't isolated the way they were in the old days. If the weather was bad you couldn't get a doctor over. Mind you, we never seemed to be sick in those days."

She's not being judgmental - she has quite enjoyed the spectacle these past weeks and is not surprised so many of the visitors seem to be spending their time in the shelter of Tarbert. "Ach, they wouldn't be used to it. They had to bring them over here. They had small children and you couldn't put children through that. They seem very nice. One or two looked a bit like hippies but mostly they are very respectable. It really quite brightens up the place."

And the local economy. At Tarbert Stores, Jane Morrison has been doing a roaring trade in everything from fishing rods and torches to batteries and sweets.

"They buy quite a lot of things from us locally," she says. "They're no different from anyone else we have coming into the shop.

"I don't disapprove of what they're doing. They're not bothering us at all. They seem to be very nice people, all of them that have been in. It's quite a change for them to be stuck there for a year. We were brought up on that, but they weren't. It's nice to see the lights there - it looks more homely."

Mary Munro, too, has seen the benefit. "My son runs the bunkhouse that they stayed in the first weekend and my other son who runs a shop has had quite a lot of orders from them. All the stuff they're eating. I think they pick it up. They have a helicopter to take in everything they need. Tarbert's doing well from them."

Not everyone is so pleased, though. Bill Lawson, a well-known local historian, feels the community has been duped by the strangers in their midst. Lawson visited Lexy and her family when they still lived on Taransay and remembers the warmth and welcome of a real home.

"The hotel is doing very well because it's filled with those who are supposed to be on the island," he says. "The shops are doing well and the tradesmen in Stornoway, on the nearby island of Lewis, are doing nicely repairing all the storm damage. It's bound to help the tourist industry as well. My thoughts are that if you're going to waste £2m on something then yes please, waste it here.

'If this now was a real social experiment I wouldn't mind so much but there's much misinformation coming out now about what's happening. There is a bit of bad feeling. We keep getting told that everybody's over on the island and the people you meet in Tarbert are just a figment of your imagination. The helicopters that you see ferrying back and forth aren't really there. It might have started off as a survival exercise but it's all mod cons now. It's nothing like the life that Lexy had."

Most here say lack of preparation and lack of understanding of the nature of Taransay has been the biggest hurdle to the project's success. But anyone within a stone's throw of the island could have advised them on the best time to start the project. For all its beauty Taransay is a harsh, unforgiving home when the winter storms come rolling in.

"This past week the climate has been very, very mild but at the new year, when they were going over, it was wild," says Jane Morrison in the Stores. "The worst it's been on Harris for many a year. They should have started earlier building their houses and been ready before the bad weather set in. That kept them back."

Mary Munro, meanwhile, thinks if they can hang in, one good spring day will sort them all out and they will fall in love with it. How could they not with the air so clear and the sea turning turquoise as it churns onto the shore?

And in the meantime, she says gently, who are we to be so hard on them for feeling beaten by the weather and the lack of facilities?

After all, even Lexy Campbell quit Taransay when she felt it was time.

fields.headline: No: 1565 Belgium
fields.trailText: Appearance: Short, squat, dull country, filled with people eating too many chips and not being able to make up their minds which language to speak. Comes very low on the Interesting Countries in Europe scale (although fortunately Luxembourg is there to prevent it coming last). Perhaps the most apposite comment on the country comes from the famous Mannekin Pis statue in Brussels.
fields.body:
Appearance: Short, squat, dull country, filled with people eating too many chips and not being able to make up their minds which language to speak. Comes very low on the Interesting Countries in Europe scale (although fortunately Luxembourg is there to prevent it coming last). Perhaps the most apposite comment on the country comes from the famous Mannekin Pis statue in Brussels.

Why's it in the news? Everyone's been very surprised by Belgium's decision to take a principled stance on the issue of General Pinochet by asking the International Court of Justice in The Hague to stop Britain returning him to Chile.

Why the surprise? Surely the Belgians have principles too? Beyond their firm principles about the way to prepare Patates Frites, we're not sure. The UN has rapped Belgium's knuckles several times recently: for its troops' behaviour in Somalia (which Amnesty describes as including torture and unlawful killing); for a nasty little habit that the Belgian Football Federation had of bringing boys over from under developed countries in what the UN called "slave trafficking"; and for ill-conduct by their law-enforcement officers, which has led to at least one death in police custody.

Crikey. Anything else? Well, two years ago, the Belgians warmly welcomed President Laurent Kabila, leader of the blood-spattered Democratic Republic of Congo. Few protesters pointed out that Kabila is associated with the Rwandan government, blamed by many for one of the worst acts of genocide in recent history.

Do the Belgians not see a slight discrepancy here? Oddly, when EU officials gave China a hard time over human rights, the Chinese pointed to Belgium as being in no position to preach. They mentioned something about child molesting.

Child molesting? Found time to do a bit of that as well, have they? Only one of the biggest child porn stories in Europe, mixed in with police corruption and bungling.

Don't say: "Had any presidents round recently?"

Do say: "May I move to your fine country tomorrow?"

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In a report headed Southern discomfort on pages 4 and 5, Society, December 1, last year, we referred to a report by an independent panel comprising Stephen Crow and Rosamund Whittaker and said "after consulting interested parties - including many extremely interested house builders - they have decided that the [south-east of England] region needs 1.1m new homes by 2016".
fields.body:
 In a report headed Southern discomfort on pages 4 and 5, Society, December 1, last year, we referred to a report by an independent panel comprising Stephen Crow and Rosamund Whittaker and said "after consulting interested parties - including many extremely interested house builders - they have decided that the [south-east of England] region needs 1.1m new homes by 2016".

It was wrong to suggest that Professor Crow and Miss Whittaker "consulted" those who, in fact, gave evidence to their inquiry. There was no intention to suggest that their deliberations were in any way subject to improper influence and we apologise if such an idea was conveyed. Professor Crow and Miss Whittaker heard over 100 people and organisations in an examination in public, a form of public inquiry.

The subject of their quasi-judicial examination was the most important of the issues raised by public representations made about draft regional planning guidance issued earlier by Serplan, a consortium of local authorities in the south-east of England. We are happy to make that clear.

 In editing a piece about the development of a dockside site in Bristol, pages 8 and 9, Society, yesterday, we excised a reference to the architect Stephen Macfarlane while mistakenly attributing some of his thoughts to Sir Hugh Casson, who died last year. Apologies.

 Three of the four pictures illustrating an item in a column, page 5, G2, yesterday, were wrongly chosen and/or captioned. One captioned Beatrice and Dante would have been correct had Dante been in the picture. Another captioned Edward and Mrs Simpson actually showed Ed ward Fox and Cynthia Harris in the title roles of the television series, Edward and Mrs Simpson. The third identified the couple in the picture as Elizabeth and Robert Barrett Browning. He was Robert Browning. She became Elizabeth Barrett Browning.

 We keep referring to industrial tribunals (as in a report, page 26, yesterday). They have been called employment tribunals for some time now.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Squirrel stats
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Highlands
fields.body:
Highlands

It seems probable that by the end of the 18th century the red squirrel was extinct in Scotland because of woodland clearance and severe winters; a number of reintroductions took place, one of which was in the Highlands on the Beaufort estate, a few miles west of Inverness. This was the only reintroduction north of the Great Glen and it took place in 1844 at the instigation of a Lady Lovat.

The squirrels rapidly spread along the wooded sides of the glens and straths until in 1890 they had reached Caithness in the north; by 1896 they were down to Ardnamurchan in the south west. They did so much damage to woodland that they began to be killed in large numbers.

However the damage continued and this led to the formation of the Highland Squirrel Club, which lasted from 1903 to 1946. The annual statements of this club were recently given to the archivist in Inverness and when I analysed them there were certainly some surprises.

In the first few years there were a total of 47 estates on the list in the counties of Ross-shire, Inverness-shire and Sutherland and the incentive to kill the squirrels was a "bonus" of 3d per tail that rose in later years to 6d per tail. During the time of the club, an incredible 102,900 red squirrels were killed with the maximum year being in 1909 when 7,199 were killed. In 1907 there were 6,628 killed by shooting, trapping and poisoning.

A graph indicating numbers throughout the year has a marked dip in each of the two world wars because so many foresters/keepers were called up. Ironically some of the highest numbers of squirrels killed each year were from the Beaufort estate, while the lowest was from Farr (which is our nearest estate) and it is interesting that red squirrels are still on both these areas.

The minutes of the annual meeting are virtually confined to squirrel business, but in the first world war estates were asked to collect, because of the country's food shortages, as many gulls' eggs as they could and take them to the nearest egg collecting depot who should be urged to send them to the nearest military hospital free of charge.

fields.headline: Capital Radio
fields.trailText: At 6.00am on Monday the champagne corks will be popping indecently early as Capital Radio, the regional commercial broadcaster, goes national for the first time.
fields.body:
At 6.00am on Monday the champagne corks will be popping indecently early as Capital Radio, the regional commercial broadcaster, goes national for the first time.

The company yesterday announced the launch of Life, described in radiospeak as a "soft contemporary adult" station on Digital One, Britain's national digital radio network. That translates to an airplay list including Celine Dion, Phil Collins, Bryan Adams and George Michael - enough to whet the conservative appetites of the City which marked Capital shares up 5% to £16.52.

Around 15 months ago Capital shares were worth less than 450p; they doubled in value by October last year. But the shares, predictably, caught fire in November after the company presented its strategy to build a presence on the internet. The business is pouring £5.5m into Capital Interactive, a web-based music site which benefits from strong cross promotion on air. Capital too has been a beneficiary of the huge increase in advertising from dot.coms.

At the same time, the company brought the shutters down on its ill advised foray into the restaurants business.

Digital radio, which offers CD quality sound, has been in the shadow of the introduction of digital television but could have an equally dramatic impact.

Capital has won 18 digital licences to date covering most metropolitan areas and competition for franchises has begun to increase. The second London licence was won by Switchdigital, a consortium of Ginger Media, Talk Radio, Carphone Warehouse and Clear Channel of the US.

fields.headline: New Citroen for UK plant
fields.standfirst: Peugeot decision comes after 206's success
fields.trailText: Peugeot, the French car group, is planning to produce within the next two years a new Citroen car in Ryton, near Coventry, to build on the runaway success of its 206 model.
fields.body:
Peugeot, the French car group, is planning to produce within the next two years a new Citroen car in Ryton, near Coventry, to build on the runaway success of its 206 model.

Jean-Martin Folz, Peugeot's chairman, said yesterday that Ryton would continue to make the 206 "for some considerable time" but, as in all group plants, would add a Citroen model using the same platform.

Peugeot aims to build 2.7m cars this year compared with 2.5m last year and just 2m in 1996. Mr Folz has brought forward his target for producing 3m cars to 2001-2.

Ryton, which built 160,000 206s last year, mostly for export, should raise its output to 200,000 this year.

It is the only European car plant working seven days a week, and helped Peugeot capture third spot in British car sales last year with an increased market share.

Like Aulnay and Poissy, the two French plants producing both Peugeots and Citroens, Ryton will also, towards the end of 2002, produce a Citroen model. It is not yet clear whether this will be a new model or an existing car, such as the Xsara.

Company sources said it was also uncertain whether Ryton would take on more staff to build Citroen after creating 900 jobs last April. Peugeot now employs 3,500 there.

Mr Folz, setting out his strategy to retain Peugeot's independence in the current wave of consolidation, launched a savage attack on the mania among car makers for mergers and acquisitions.

"The key factor for success in manufacturing is not the ability to produce five million identical cars that nobody will buy but a wide range of different cars," he said.

Industry experts say annual output of 5m cars is the minimum scale required to stay alive as an independent group - an idea Mr Folz dismissed as "politically correct" and embraced by American car groups "who keep saying they will buy the rest of the world".

Mr Folz said: "We will be building 75% of our production on three different platforms, rather than five million cars on 20 platforms."

Peugeot has 5% of the global car market.

Mr Folz, presenting the car group's annual environment report, said sales of the diesel Hdi engine - produced in eastern France and claimed to be the world's cleanest engine - will rise from 470,000 units last year to 700,000 this year.

Peugeot plans to introduce a two litre "lean burn" petrol engine - which cuts fuel consumption by up to 20% - on an unnamed model later this year, and is working with Ford on a range of "green" diesels.

However, Mr Folz, who is investing 3bn Euro dollars a year on new models, ruled out the possiblility of any closer alliance with any of the world's big players, arguing that the market was "segmenting" more and more into smaller groups of critical consumers. Consolidation was not the only or the best answer to the challenge of globalisation, he said.
