fields.headline: Coca-Cola wields axe worldwide
fields.trailText: Coca-Cola is to cut over 5,000 jobs around the world, more than a fifth of its entire workforce. The job cuts, the largest in the drinks company's 114-year history, will fall heaviest in the US as Coca-Cola aims to decentralise operations following a series of mishaps in its international operations.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is to cut over 5,000 jobs around the world, more than a fifth of its entire workforce. The job cuts, the largest in the drinks company's 114-year history, will fall heaviest in the US as Coca-Cola aims to decentralise operations following a series of mishaps in its international operations.

Some 2,500 jobs will be cut from the Atlanta headquarters, almost as many as the 2,700 to be lost around the world; four-fifths of the workforce is outside the US.

Paul Pendergrass, Coca-Cola's European spokesman, said the group had still to decide how many of the continent's 2,500 workers would have to go. The group said that the restructuring, which will lead to a charge of about $800m this year, was designed to "put more responsibility, accountability and resources in the hands of the local business units in the more than 200 countries where the company does business".

The company, which has a 51% share of the world's soft drinks market, plans a series of marketing initiatives around the world this year. While admitting that cutting jobs had been painful, chairman Doug Daft said: "Throughout the year, we will remind consumers how Coca-Cola adds a little magic to the real moments in people's everyday lives."

Coca-Cola's reaction to a European contamination scare attracted unprecedented criticism last year. The group disclosed yesterday that the incident, which affected children in Belgium and France, cost more than $100m, contributing to a fourth-quarter loss of $45m in the three months to the end of December.

The incident led to a welter of bad publicity highlighting the corporation's reputation for arrogance and aggressive behaviour. Last summer, the European commission ordered an investigation into allegedly monopolistic actions by Coca-Cola and three of its bottlers.

Last month, the chairman, Doug Ivester, announced that he was to retire after the group's largest shareholders, including Warren Buffett, were said to have expressed their dissatisfaction with his two-year tenure. His successor, Doug Daft, has appointed a new management team and emphasised a conciliatory approach to regional issues.

Shares in the group edged lower yesterday after rising 11 per cent since Mr Daft's appointment. At about $64, they are still well below the record $87 3/16 reached in July 1998.

Andrew Conway, drinks analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said that yesterday's job cuts - three times more extensive than expected - suggested that earlier growth expectations would not be met. Mr Daft has come under pressure to scale back aggressive earnings targets set by his predecessor. He told analysts in a conference call yesterday: "My sense at this stage is that our current range of volume and earnings-per-share growth rates are probably a little on the high side."

Earnings are also set to be between 11 and 13 cents lower in the first half because of a decline in inventory levels as well as the $800m charge. The group is expected to save $300m in operating costs as a result of the job cuts. Economic difficulties in Russia, the Baltic states and Japan prompted the group to write down $813m on its assets last year. With about two-thirds of sales outside North America, the group is keen to beef up its local management.

fields.headline: Greens take on BP Amoco
fields.standfirst: Environmental lobby wins shareholders support
fields.trailText: Environmental pressure group, Greenpeace, yesterday claimed shareholder backing for its plan to block controversial plans by BP Amoco to expand its exploration for oil in Alaska.
fields.body:
Environmental pressure group, Greenpeace, yesterday claimed shareholder backing for its plan to block controversial plans by BP Amoco to expand its exploration for oil in Alaska.

Greenpeace said it intended to halt further development of BP Amoco's Northstar exploration project at the company's annual meeting in April.

The prospect of a vote on Northstar comes as BP Amoco is trying to persuade American regulators that its $27bn (£16.5bn) acquisition of Atlantic Richfield should proceed despite concerns that the deal will diminish production competition in Alaska.

BP said it was "dealing with the resolution" from Greenpeace which is signed by 100 shareholders speaking for about 150,000 shares in the company. It is understood that BP will check the identity and shareholdings of all signatories to the motion, which will take about a week.

Greenpeace raised the issue of the Northstar development - which it claims uses risky and untested technology to bring oil ashore - at last year's annual meeting. Since then BP Amoco has proposed to the government that multi-national companies should be allowed to dispense with conventional annual meetings.

Greenpeace has managed to exploit the activist approach of some American investors, many of which joined the investor register when BP acquired Amoco in late 1998, to gain support for its hostile motion. The need to attract the backing of more than 100 shareholders means it is very difficult to table resolutions at an annual meeting without company endorsement.

One of the US investor groups that has signed up to the Greenpeace motion is Trillium Asset Management - a socially responsible investment organisation which speaks for about $600m, although not all of that is committed to voting in favour of the resolution.

Simon Billenness, an analyst with Trillium, said: "We have yet to see any sign of BP Amoco actually acting on [its] green vision. With this resolution, shareholders in the US and, for the first time in Europe, have a chance to put policy into practice."

Greenpeace wants BP Amoco to switch the $5bn investment planned for Northstar into a solar energy proposal.

webTitle: Byatt's U-turn on mergers lifts shares

fields.headline: Byatt's U-turn on mergers lifts shares
fields.trailText: Outgoing water regulator Ian Byatt yesterday delivered a fierce attack on the government's utilities bill - but softened his opposition to takeovers in the industry.
fields.body:
Outgoing water regulator Ian Byatt yesterday delivered a fierce attack on the government's utilities bill - but softened his opposition to takeovers in the industry.

Mr Byatt, a staunch opponent of water mergers in the past, said consolidation within the industry might be justified in future by the growth of competition.The shift in his position gave a fillip to the share price of many of the big water companies, with Anglian 30.5p up at 517.5p, Thames 39.5p ahead at 791.5p and Severn Trent 35.5p higher at 664.5p.

Mr Byatt, who is due to retire as director general of Ofwat in July, said parts of the utilities bill published last week were too prescriptive and bureaucratic, and that he would seek to have them amended.

"We have a bill which shows how difficult governments can find it to translate good intentions into sensible legislation," he said. "I find the bill over-complicated because it is over-prescriptive. Nothing is left to good sense."

Mr Byatt, speaking at an industry conference in London, said the development of competition could lead to less regulation in the future.

"Competition has brought big gains in other utilities," he said.

"If a proper framework can be established for access to the ultimate monopoly - the network - regulation could be confined to the regulation of that essential facility."

He urged companies to introduce competition without waiting for the regulator to tell them what to do.

He said mergers between water companies involved an automatic reference to the competition commission because parliament did not want to see an aggregation of regional monopolies without tangible benefits.

He now felt that the development of market competition could be such a benefit.

However, water companies wishing to merge would have to be ready not only to deliver competition but also to see a loss in market share in their own areas.

Water companies' shares have been under severe pressure since Mr Byatt announced the price controls for the next five years. These included an average 12% cut in 2000-01.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The market sprang back to life yesterday, surging on the back of the Footsie's telecom trio Vodafone, C&W and BT, and underpinned by a strong banking sector.
fields.body:
The market sprang back to life yesterday, surging on the back of the Footsie's telecom trio Vodafone, C&W and BT, and underpinned by a strong banking sector.

The main FTSE 100 index ended the session up 101 points at 6,375.6, close to its best level of the day.

Vodafone AirTouch was again the most actively traded stock, with more than 200m shares changing hands as the price suddenly jumped from 330p to 349p - reversing the trend of the past few days.

But all the hot money was heading in the direction of Cable & Wireless, with reports of potential interest from Deutsche Telekom prompting a further 83p advance to £13.20. At the beginning of the month the stock was sitting below £10 - before news of the plan to merge its HKT associate with SingTel emerged.

BT, meanwhile, put on 39p to £12.43, helped by news of its e-commerce deal with retailer WH Smith.

Among the banks, with the year-end reporting season under way with figures out from mortgage lender Northern Rock, Woolwich added 18p to 286p and Halifax put on 29p to 552p, while Abbey National surged 40p to 777p and Barclays closed the session 102p higher at £14.81.

ARM Holdings, which has put in a volatile performance over recent sessions, moved up 200p to £33.97, with many investors feeling that the slide seen since the launch of the rival Crusoe chip launch is looking overdone. Year-end figures are due from ARM next week.

Telecoms equipment group Marconi, the re-fashioned GEC, was back in the spotlight, climbing 57p to 913p. Investment bankers CSFB were said to have issued a positive note on the stock.

But over in the retailing sector, on the day of the launch of its new spring collection, Marks & Spencer shrank 21p to 275p. Dealers put the move down to the fact that bid speculators are now trying to get out of the stock, rather than the market taking a sudden dislike to the new clothes.

After a steep fall on Tuesday, Kingston Communications rallied 57p to 852p, excited by hopes of early news on a possible link-up with a mobile phone operator. Goldman Sachs is also positive on the stock.

Meanwhile, in a property sector, which has been free of speculation for months, there was suddenly talk of an unnamed American predator eyeing British Land. The shares jumped 23p to 369p.

On the first day out in its new form, Celltech Group - formed by the merger of Celltech and Chiroscience - added 76p to 872p.

But all the hot money was heading in the direction of Cable & Wireless, with reports of potential interest from Deutsche Telekom prompting a further 83p advance to £13.20. At the beginning of the month the stock was sitting below £10 - before news of the plan to merge its HKT associate with SingTel emerged. BT, meanwhile, put on 39p to £12.43, helped by news of its e-commerce deal with retailer WH Smith. Among the banks, with the year-end reporting season under way with figures out from mortgage lender Northern Rock, Woolwich added 18p to 286p and Halifax put on 29p to 552p, while Abbey National surged 40p to 777p and Barclays closed the session 102p higher at £14.81. ARM Holdings, which has put in a volatile performance over recent sessions, moved up 200p to £33.97, with many investors feeling that the slide seen since the launch of the rival Crusoe chip launch is looking overdone. Year-end figures are due from ARM next week. Telecoms equipment group Marconi, the re-fashioned GEC, was back in the spotlight, climbing 57p to 913p. Investment bankers CSFB were said to have issued a positive note on the stock. But over in the retailing sector, on the day of the launch of its new spring collection, Marks & Spencer shrank 21p to 275p. Dealers put the move down to the fact that bid speculators are now trying to get out of the stock, rather than the market taking a sudden dislike to the new clothes. After a steep fall on Tuesday, Kingston Communications rallied 57p to 852p, excited by hopes of early news on a possible link-up with a mobile phone operator. Goldman Sachs is also positive on the stock. Meanwhile, in a property sector, which has been free of speculation for months, there was suddenly talk of an unnamed American predator eyeing British Land. The shares jumped 23p to 369p. On the first day out in its new form, Celltech Group - formed by the merger of Celltech and Chiroscience - added 76p to 872p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Essential Greenspan

Low, stable inflation is the "essential ingredient" to allow economic expansion to continue, says Federal Reserve board chairman Alan Greenspan. "Our challenge in monetary policy is to foster the financial conditions that will allow this economic expansion and technological revolution to continue as long and as vigorously as possible," Mr Greenspan said, in remarks prepared for delivery to the senate banking committee.
fields.body:
Essential Greenspan

Low, stable inflation is the "essential ingredient" to allow economic expansion to continue, says Federal Reserve board chairman Alan Greenspan. "Our challenge in monetary policy is to foster the financial conditions that will allow this economic expansion and technological revolution to continue as long and as vigorously as possible," Mr Greenspan said, in remarks prepared for delivery to the senate banking committee.

The committee is holding a hearing on President Bill Clinton's decision to nominate Mr Greenspan for a fourth term. Mr Greenspan said: "I believe that we have learned from our past mistakes and hope that we will recognise the new misjudgments we will inevitably make quickly enough to prevent them becoming too serious and disruptive."

Telekom profits fall to DM1.1bn
Deutsche Telekom expects profit after tax but before extraordinaries to drop to 1.1bn marks (£340m) this year from DM2.5bn in 1999, despite an expected DM3.8bn growth in sales at almost DM73bn, Capital magazine said, citing a confidential report from the company.

The weekly journal said the "bad" results were attributable to tough price competition in the fixed network business as well as the high goodwill amortization for its acquisition of British mobile operatior One2One. Company sources last week said Telekom expects to post a net profit of 6bn euros, compared to a net profit of €1.2bn in 1999.

Ford losses 'unacceptable'

Losses at Ford's European operations were "unacceptable", chief executive Jac Nasser warned yesterday. He said the European operations had lost $55m (£33.5m) in the fourth quarter of 1999 - an improvement on the $63m lost in the same quarter of 1998. Ford is believed to be preparing a radical restructuring of its European operations with possible plant closures. Overall the group achieved a record profit of $7.2bn last year, up from $5.9bn the previous year.

Sainsbury warns on ATMs

Sainsbury's has warned Barclays and other high street banks that it would not tolerate customers being charged for taking cash from hole in the wall machines at its outlets. The retailer says it may not renew banks' licences to operate dispensers if the warning is not heeded. Financial services manager Alison O'Mahoney said: "The banks need to remember customers have a free [cash back] alternative only a few feet away."

Briton on OECD tax committee

Britain scored a symbolic victory in its battle against plans for a EU-wide tax on cross-border savings yesterday with the appointment of a former treasury official as chairman of an international committee on tax evasion. Gabs Makhlouf, Gordon Brown's former private secretary, is to be head of the OECD's committee of fiscal affairs, signalling that Britain is winning the argument on the witholding tax, said a treasury official.

fields.headline: The wrong kind of reality?
fields.standfirst: Why did a middle-aged white American spend months photographing Birmingham's Jamaican immigrants? And why was his first show blocked at the last minute?  Chris Arnot  investigates
fields.trailText: Why did a middle-aged white American spend months photographing Birmingham's Jamaican immigrants? And why was his first show blocked at the last minute? Chris Arnot investigates
fields.body:
At the beginning of last year, Larry Herman was approached by two young black men who demanded to know what the hell he thought he was doing. A fair question in the circumstances. Here was a middle-aged white man, loitering after dark in inner-city Birmingham and wielding a camera. Was he working for a newspaper? Or the police? Relations between residents and the local constabulary might have improved since the riots of the 80s but, after all, this was still Handsworth.

Herman told them he was here to photograph British Jamaicans for a project chronicling immigrant communities all over the country. After 10 minutes of waning hostility, one of the men patted him on the shoulder and said: "You're doing OK." Then they walked off, but not before he had invited them to his show at nearby Soho House, once the home of the great industrialist Matthew Boulton.

Had they turned up there last May, they would have been disappointed. Herman's exhibition had fallen victim to the racial politics that are never far from the surface in an area like Handsworth. Soho House was recently restored as a museum and Birmingham City Council has been keen to involve those who now live in its immediate vicinity, predominantly black and Asian people.

Questions were raised only when council employees had their first view of what Herman was proposing to exhibit. "In no way was it a quality issue," says Val Loggie, curator and manager at Soho House. "But we felt that the exhibition didn't give a balanced view of what Handsworth's like now. We were aware that some members of the black community weren't happy with the way the images were going to be presented."

Other local people now have their chance to see them in an exhibition at the City College in Handsworth. "They have to be able to make up their own minds," says Jenny Bartley, the college's director of curriculum. "This is one photographer's view of the community. Some of the pictures challenge and ask questions about the conditions people are living in. That's what art's about."

Herman argues that there are positive images of black achievers, such as headteacher Carlton Duncan and artist Barbara Walker. There are light-hearted images, too, such as the shot of two teenagers canoodling. Others are more controversial. In one there's just a bed, its sheets glowing white in the dimly lit ward of a hospital. The body beneath the rumpled sheet is shrouded from view, although its outline is visible. The caption refers to local concerns over the number of young black men kept in hospital as a form of social exclusion under section three of the 1983 Mental Health Act.

"The deputy care manager provided the words and I just subbed them down," the photographer insists. "And I had permission to wander around the hospital and take which shots I liked." Whoever is under the sheet can't be identified from the photograph. Otherwise it would have breached a Herman article of faith: he only photographs images that the subjects want him to see, after painstakingly building up trust.

Herman was a sculptor back home in New York. In 1968, when he was 26, Uncle Sam required his presence in Vietnam and was losing patience with four years of defiance. Given a choice between prison, the jungles of south-east Asia and London, he chose London and landed a job in the cutting room of the director Ken Loach.

Herman was soon planning to make pictures of his own. Still ones. He was an artist who had changed his medium. "I wanted something that would communicate with people more directly than sculpture," he says.

In style, he's very different from the Bill Brandt documentary school of a carefully posed realism. "I never move so much as a cup or a chair," he says, "because I don't want to impose myself on reality. If I manipulate the image, then my photography becomes faction. Design and form is important, but my first question during the editing process is 'What do I want to say with this photograph?'"

His pictures have won awards on both sides of the Atlantic. In 1998, he was a finalist in the International Fund for Documentary Photography, based in San Francisco. In Britain, he's managed to attract seven grants from the Arts Council. Three of them are for his project on immigrant communities, which began over five years ago.

"What marks our epoch, even more than war," he says, "is the movement of people around the world. When I was a child, New York was one of the biggest cities in the world. Now Mexico City has a population of over 18m and the number of people in Cairo is going up by 1,000 a day. Britain's not isolated from this process and I wanted to record its effects in this country."

He has photographed Kurds and Congolese in London, Yemenis in Sheffield, Bangladeshis in Bradford, Chinese in Manchester and, of course, Jamaicans in Birmingham. When I catch up with him one Friday in Handsworth, he's on his way to see Bill Duffus, a black community worker. Duffus has tried to impart some local street wisdom, with limited success. Only the day before, the photographer had wandered into a barber's shop that turned out to be a notorious haunt of drug dealers. "Even I wouldn't go near that place," says Duffus. Cameras were not welcome. Herman had to make his excuses and leave. Hurriedly.

This afternoon Duffus has arranged for us to see Sonia Smith at the Organisation for Sickle Cell Anaemia Relief (Oscar). Sonia has a photogenic face, remarkably youthful for a grandmother of nine. Herman listens respectfully, taking copious notes while she outlines the harrowing details of a disease which devastates so many Afro-Caribbean people. By the time the camera emerges, she is talking with passionate authority and he has gathered enough trust for her to continue while he snaps away.

Darkness is falling when we leave, but the nearby barber's shop is still open for business of one sort or another. Herman is careful to stay on the other side of the road, keeping the bag containing his Leica well hidden. For once, he's taking no chances.

We're From There: Jamaican Brummies is at City College, Handsworth, Birmingham (0121-256 1111), till April 13.

fields.headline: Lord of the dance
fields.standfirst:
When Bob Fosse, creator of Chicago, Cabaret and The Pajama Game, died suddenly in 1987 his career was faltering. Today he is more popular than ever.
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: When Bob Fosse, creator of Chicago, Cabaret and The Pajama Game, died suddenly in 1987 his career was faltering. Today he is more popular than ever.
fields.body:
Some say that Bob Fosse danced himself to death. Certainly his feet never stopped moving from the day in 1935 when he was sent to a Chicago dance class as a companion to his shy elder sister. He was just eight at the time. By the time he dropped dead of a heart attack on a Washington pavement in 1987, just a few minutes before the curtain was due to rise on his revival of Sweet Charity, the dancer-turned-choreographer-turned-director was a Broadway legend. His kooky, angular style, all pigeon toes and teacup fingers, was familiar to millions from shows such as The Pajama Game and Chicago and the Oscar-winning film Cabaret.

Yet when Fosse died, aged just 60, Broadway was changing. Just as the burlesque clubs in which Fosse made his professional debut - and to which he owed so much of his sleazy style - had gone, so the kind of theatre for which he was famous was in decline.

Stephen Sondheim certainly wasn't writing the kind of musical that featured dancers with bowler hats and white gloves - the trademarks that had grown out of Fosse's own insecurities about his hairline, which began to recede when he was 17, and his fingers, which refused to behave like a ballet dancer's and always spread. Broadway was being invaded by British-produced musicals such as Les Misérables, and when they used dancers - which was rarely - it was in a very different way from Fosse's showy style.

Fosse was a success all his life but was so terrified of failure that he always announced himself by his full name, in case anyone asked him, "Bob who?" In the year before he died he suffered a crushing blow. As he was trying to come to terms with the panning of Star 80, his movie about murdered Playboy playmate Dorothy Stratton, a Broadway musical called Big Deal that he had been developing for more than 20 years closed after just 70 performances.

In a business in which you are only as good as your last show, the pressure was on Fosse. He had once told an interviewer that he wanted to die young so that people would mourn his brilliant promise. Instead, despite the constant use of amphetamines to keep him going and Seconal to get to sleep, a history of epileptic seizures and two heart attacks, it looked as though Fosse was going to live to a ripe old age. You could say that dying was just the kind of break he needed.

Now, 13 years after his death, fulfilling the prophecy of his 1979 autobiographical film All That Jazz, Bob Fosse is more famous than ever. Chicago has been running for two years in London, and previews have just begun in the West End for Fosse, an all-singing, all-dancing celebration of the man's work that has already wowed Broadway. It seems that Fosse was absolutely right when he once joked: "I'll have to be dead to find out if I'm any good."

The Fosse revival is almost entirely down to one woman: Gwen Verdon, a small red-haired ball of energy who was the last of Fosse's three wives. A Broadway hoofer and a legend in her own right, Verdon, who is now in her 70s, was the mother of his only child, a daughter called Nicole, and his muse - and the woman who made Bob Fosse have faith in himself.

'He was a driven man. His family was Norwegian and he had that dark Scandinavian side to him. He worked and worried himself to death. He never believed he was good enough," recalls Verdon, who was by Fosse's side when he died, even though they had been separated for more than 20 years. "We were separated, but we were always together. He never missed a Thanksgiving or a Christmas. He'd always say 'Why doesn't my house feel like a home?'" says Verdon proudly.

She is a forgiving woman. She refuses to talk in any detail about their private life, but Fosse was a serial womaniser as well as having an addictive personality. Verdon likes to play down that side of Fosse, shrugging off the drug-taking by saying that he exaggerated his exploits and suggesting that back in the 60s people weren't so aware of the dangers of amphetamines. "Even airline pilots took them to stay awake."

While Verdon acts the loyal wife, protecting both Fosse's reputation and artistic legacy, she makes little of her own contribution to his success. Yet Verdon was always much more than a wife and a muse to Fosse - she was also his "mother", his inspiration, his teacher and his collaborator. Those who saw them dance together say that it was like watching two people have sex. Without Verdon, Fosse would never have been the choreographer and director he became.

Verdon gives Fosse all the credit for the showpiece dance Whatever Lola Wants, Lola Gets from the 1955 musical Damn Yankees - in which he really made his name. But many say that it owes a lot to Verdon herself, her mannerisms and her training with Jack Cole, a choreographer who brought a touch of the exotic East to the American lounge dance circuit. The sexy-funny effect of Lola had similarities with the satirical sexiness of Marilyn Monroe singing I'm Just a Little Girl from Little Rock in the 1953 movie Gentlemen Prefer Blondes. Who had taught Monroe how to do it? Gwen Verdon.

Without Verdon, whom Fosse married in 1960, Fosse would never have got the break that allowed him to make the step from being a choreographer to a director. Verdon, by then big box office, only agreed to star in the musical Redhead on condition that Fosse be given the chance to direct. To the end of his life, Verdon was often to be found side by side with Fosse in the rehearsal room. When people talk about Fosse style, they mean Verdon style, too. Fosse may have got a reputation for being a star-maker - Shirley MacLaine, Liza Minnelli and Ann Reinking were just a few who got their breaks in Fosse shows - but it was Verdon who gave him the breaks, and it is she who ensures his legacy lives on.

In some ways, Verdon thinks he never died. "Sometimes I think he is up there hovering over us, watching what is going on and smiling," she says. And perhaps he is. On the night that Fosse died, Joel Grey was also in Washington, on stage playing the Master of Ceremonies in Cabaret, a repeat of the screen role for which he had won an Oscar. Looking out into the auditorium as he sang the final reprise of Life is a Cabaret, Grey swears that he saw Fosse sitting there in the dark. He had been pronounced dead at Washington University Hospital two hours previously.

webTitle: Elian set for reunion with Cuban family

fields.headline: Elian set for reunion with Cuban family
fields.standfirst: More about the Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Two months after he was shipwrecked off the Florida coast, Elian Gonzalez was sent to meet his two Cuban grandmothers in Miami yesterday as the cold war-style tussle over the six-year-old boy entered a new phase.
fields.body:
Two months after he was shipwrecked off the Florida coast, Elian Gonzalez was sent to meet his two Cuban grandmothers in Miami yesterday as the cold war-style tussle over the six-year-old boy entered a new phase.

Under an agreement with US immigration officials, Elian's Miami-based relatives were excluded from the emotional reunion, but they held a vigil nearby to maintain their opposition to a government ruling that Elian should return to his father in Cuba.

"I'm dying to see him, hug him, to be with him even for a short while," Mariela Quintana, the boy's paternal grandmother, said before leaving Washington. She and the other grandmother, Raquel Rodriquez, had appealed to members of congress to oppose Republican attempts to hinder Elian's repatriation by awarding him US citizenship.

The grandmothers will have to return the boy to his great uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, in Miami after the meeting as a court order has temporarily blocked any repatriation.

"No one will be in the meeting with Elian except the two grandmothers," said Rev Joan Brown Campbell, an official of the National Council of Churches who has escorted the women during their visit to the US.

In a letter in the Cuban daily Granma yesterday, Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, asked to be allowed to speak to his son by mobile phone during the meeting.

His father has demanded his return to Cuba but has refused to come to the US for fear of being enmeshed in political and legal manoeuvring. The two grandmothers came on his behalf.

The Miami relatives agreed to the meeting, in the home of the president of a local Catholic university, after the authorities warned them that their failure to produce Elian would jeopardise his temporary immigration status.

Each side has accused the other of manipulating the boy for political ends since the boat on which he was being smuggled to the US sank, killing his mother, her boyfriend and nine others. Elian survived by clinging to a car inner tube.

If passed, the citizenship bill would mark the first time an individual had been naturalised by an act of congress, but the Republicans are split over the issue.

Chuck Hagel, a Republican senator from Nebraska, said that the grandmothers had told him that Elian's mother did not board the ill-fated boat to Florida to flee communist oppression, as the Cuban exiles have argued, but because she was pressured into going by her boyfriend.

President Bill Clinton has hinted that he might veto any congressional move to make Elian a citizen before his case is decided in the courts.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which animated "animal" film will be the biggest earner in 2000?
fields.trailText: Which animated "animal" film will be the biggest earner in 2000?
fields.body:
Chicken Run 1/2

Tigger Movie 9/4

Spirit Of The West 9/1

Tusker 12/1

Hollywood's tendency to milk any successful formula for all it's worth suggests that this year will be a big one for animals in toon town. Disney's domination of the box office last year with Tarzan and Toy Story 2, and this year's success story of cute mouse Stuart Little has had a predictable effect on the moguls.

Ladbrokes spokesman Ed Nicholson can see who this trend will really benefit: "Voice-overs have always been an attractive sideline for actors, but where it was mostly advertising work before, actors can now earn a fortune voicing over cartoon characters. And you don't have to be a contestant on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? to work out that cartoon characters are the next big thing."

"Chicken Run must be favourite as it is produced by Dreamworks, and stars among others the voices of Mel Gibson, Miranda Richardson, Jane Horrocks and - wait for it - Phil Daniels."

"This is a certainty to do well - written by the Wallace and Gromit team, it is a 'Great Escape with chickens' film and will certainly pull the crowds in", says Ed.

"Disney expect the Tigger Movie to prove as popular as Toy Story. Rumour has it that the uncut version had audiences crying and laughing. Success is not just needed but expected", he adds.

"But as a testament to the rollercoaster mentality in Hollywood, there are others to consider, which are waiting to see how the others fare before going for it", says Ed.

"Spirit Of The West will have a horse as the main animated hero - and that's not yet been done, so it could get the novelty vote. On the other hand you've got our old favourite from the golden age of Disney's Dumbo - elephants are on parade with the film Tusker. But with allegedly no stars on the list as yet, it might be hard for them to beat the main protagonists."

fields.headline: Go back to college
fields.trailText: I'm a chef and understand the pressures of working in a busy kitchen. Sometimes you can't help getting stressed at other members of your team (especially the waiting staff) but I think it's a bit over the top for the chef to throw a cold pheasant. After all it wasn't the pheasant's fault for not being hot. I think the chef in question should go back to college and learn how to cook again.

fields.headline: Perfect self-deprecation
fields.standfirst:
Lloyd Cole
Dingwalls, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: About 15 minutes before Lloyd Cole is due on, a floppy-haired, bashful man in white shirt and chinos sidles through the velvet curtain and starts tuning guitars. We pretend he's not there. Bloopy ambient noise continues to spill from the PA and the crowd chats on. It is hot and densely packed: Cole is evidently still widely admired, to the extent of attracting a man who looks disturbingly like Roger Scruton. A while later the guitar tuner reappears to deafening hoots and cheers. It is Lloyd Cole. Such is the consensual magic of pop.
fields.body:
About 15 minutes before Lloyd Cole is due on, a floppy-haired, bashful man in white shirt and chinos sidles through the velvet curtain and starts tuning guitars. We pretend he's not there. Bloopy ambient noise continues to spill from the PA and the crowd chats on. It is hot and densely packed: Cole is evidently still widely admired, to the extent of attracting a man who looks disturbingly like Roger Scruton. A while later the guitar tuner reappears to deafening hoots and cheers. It is Lloyd Cole. Such is the consensual magic of pop.

Easing on to a stool, Cole apologises wryly: "I feel bad sitting down when you're all standing up. But I'm very, very, very old these days." Yet age has not withered him: he looks the same as ever. For this solo tour, his roadie is his dad, and the stage is dressed with bohemian simplicity: two mic stands, a rickety wooden side-table for whisky and guitar gadgets, and a music-stand.

Cole is in splendid vocal form, that swooping baritone flirting at the edge of crackly dissolution. He happily delivers the oldies: Brand New Friend, Cut Me Down, Undressed and Lost Weekend, during which he stops comically to complain: "It's that bloody piano solo now - I always hated this song." His guitar-playing is deceptively deft, picking out pellucid treble drone notes in arpeggios or sliding around lugubriously on the bass strings.

Cole has also been learning other people's songs: Lou Reed's Patience, Leonard Cohen's Famous Blue Raincoat. Nick Cave's People Ain't no Good is beautifully modulated by the swapping of Cave's sodden growl for Cole's bittersweet tunefulness. His own new material is soaked in beatnik imagery and Dylanesque wails: "Traded my holy water for cheap wine".

It is a cunning solution to the problem of what to do when you are most famous for jangly youth: you reinvent yourself as an artist in a serious singer-songwriter tradition. Of course, Cole spent most of the 80s with a tattered copy of Kerouac stuffed down his trousers, but his looks and amiability might mitigate his intellectual ambitions. Cole will never be as iconically ugly or majestically rude as Lou Reed. But maybe that's a good thing.

 Tonight at Ronnie Scott's, Birmingham (0121-643 4525) and Saturday at Queen's Hall, Edinburgh (0131-667 7776)

fields.headline: Teeth damaged by daily grind
fields.standfirst: How does work get you down? Have your say on the scruples poll
fields.trailText: Rising stress at work is causing increasing numbers of young professionals to grind their teeth while they sleep. Dentists report higher numbers of people in their 20s and 30s showing the symptoms of grinding which include headaches, painful teeth, an aching jaw or neck and ringing ears.
fields.body:
Rising stress at work is causing increasing numbers of young professionals to grind their teeth while they sleep. Dentists report higher numbers of people in their 20s and 30s showing the symptoms of grinding which include headaches, painful teeth, an aching jaw or neck and ringing ears.

Other problems include broken fillings and worn down teeth but many sufferers do not realise what is causing them.

The British Dental Health Foundation's chief executive, Nigel Carter, said he had noticed more and more young people needing treatment for the condition, technically known as bruxism.

"It is certainly increasing and one of the things you can put that down to is increased stress at work and in life in general. Certainly a lot of people in their 20s and 30s are showing signs of worn down teeth whereas traditionally that wouldn't be noticeable until they were in middle age. "A lot of people as well as grinding at night tend to clench their teeth during the day when they are concentrating and doing something with their hands. In the past it was generally more women who were affected with symptoms but now with a lot more people using keyboards that isn't the case and overall stress in the muscles during the day is building up.

"Once teeth are worn it can make a terrific noise like a circular saw and very often the first people know is if a spouse says something. In some cases you can really see great chunks ground out of teeth at a relatively early age."

Being made aware of daytime teeth clenching may be enough to help some people stop it but people who grind their teeth at night may have to wear plastic guards to stop their teeth rubbing together or have dental work done to give them a more balanced bite.

One sufferer is Verity Williams, 30, who works as an account handler for a London-based advertising agency.

"I get jaw ache and headaches in my temples but the dentist said the only way to stop doing it is wearing a brace at night which sounds revolting. I have done it since I was a child but it does get worse when I'm stressed.

"Several people I know do it because it does come up in conversation occasionally."

A British Dental Association spokeswoman, Jacinta Yeo, who has a practice in Harley Street, said: "In society life is faster and for some people they can find that stressful. If you tend to grind, stress will make your grinding worse. Some people say there is a genetic component, others say it is to do with the way the teeth meet but there's no question that stress makes it worse.

"I find that a lot of people who work in city jobs will tend to be grinders and a lot of them will tend to be young. Over the past 10 years I have seen more of it and I think it is on the increase because of the pace of life."

Stephen Palmer, director of the Centre for Stress Management, said there were a wide range of symptoms of stress.

The physical effects included palpitations, breathlessness, nausea, chest pains, clenched jaws or fists, back or neck ache, excessive sweating and frequent colds and flu.

The psychological symptoms included anger, anxiety, a lack of concentration and enthusiasm, mood swings and paranoid thinking.

Sufferers may also become more aggressive, more accident prone, eat more comfort food and have disturbed sleep.

fields.headline: The Beta Band
fields.trailText: Many things about the Beta Band are confounding. Their records teeter between brilliance and indifferent, wibbly jamming. In interviews they come across as petulant and self-centred. Yet they are engaging, communicative showmen and a fantastic live band. Taut yet limber, languid yet dynamic, they manipulate their music with such gusto that the barely recognisable results are exhilarating.
fields.body:
Many things about the Beta Band are confounding. Their records teeter between brilliance and indifferent, wibbly jamming. In interviews they come across as petulant and self-centred; you expect them to be equally miserable on stage. Yet they are engaging, communicative showmen and a fantastic live band. Taut yet limber, languid yet dynamic, they manipulate their music with such gusto that the barely recognisable results are exhilarating.

The Cow's Wrong, from last year's much-disliked (by band and critics alike) album, is typical: muted on record, here it shuffles from a conventional indie start to a golden, sloping dub affair. The new single To You Alone is greatly enhanced by some flamboyant drumming. Each song reels with confidence, particularly as Richard Greentree's nimble basslines become more prominent, in the snappy Dr Baker and The House Song. The Hard One is accompanied by a surreal cartoon of Bonnie Tyler being abducted by aliens, and that's the sound that the melancholy bass and pensive, off-kilter keyboards conjure.

The show was more spare than usual: fewer instruments cluttered the stage; most of the backing films were obscured by the glaring lights. Apart from a couple of impish improvised numbers featuring a fan from New York rapping, they were just four blokes on a stage doing their best with guitars, keyboards and percussion. But as they launched into a rapturous version of their first single, Dry the Rain, that was enough to make them one of the finest live bands around.

fields.headline: Doubled up dynamism
fields.standfirst:
John Zorn
Barbican, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: John Zorn's early reputation as a fearsome avant-garde jazzer still precedes him. Since he is many other things, this undoubtedly drives him nuts. But his scalding concert to open the Barbican Jazz 2000 season overturned all narrow views of his talents.
fields.body:
John Zorn's early reputation as a fearsome avant-garde jazzer still precedes him. Since he is many other things, this undoubtedly drives him nuts. But his scalding concert to open the Barbican Jazz 2000 season overturned all narrow views of his talents.

The gig was a triple-header. The Masada String Trio began, with the lilting, softly insinuating Yiddisher dance-music themes Zorn has adopted in the 90s. These were beautifully expressed by violinist Mark Feldman, who can play the instrument on his lap like a jazz guitar, or produce stomping riff-packed solos like a hoe-down fiddler. His technique makes the most passing sound sing. The material mixed explosive Ornette Coleman-like pieces (Coleman, John Cage, Anthony Braxton and Derek Bailey are the self-taught Zorn's big influences) with mellifluousness. Dense melo- dies tumbled with notes separated by sudden crash-stops. Feldman's exchanges with improvising cellist Erik Friedlander absorbingly fused jazz's rhythmic elasticity and classical music's sonorities. Bassist Greg Cohen was a rock and a gazelle in all three bands, sometimes both at once.

The second set, from the septet Bar Kokhba, brought some of the trio's material into contact with Latin rhythms, engagingly mingling the acoustic strings with Marc Ribot's twangy, 60s-surfer guitar. It often worked up a whooping clamour that brought the show an urgent intensity. Zorn lounged in a chair but the beseeching movements of his hands and fluttering of his fingers for tempo changes confirmed his presence in the music's shape.

The Masada quartet's finale was the killer. Though much of the material preserved the night's cultural references, Zorn's saxophone-playing revealed both tender lyricism and rawness (flat-out, he sometimes suggests the abstract multiphonics of UK virtuoso Evan Parker). His no-prisoners exchanges with Dave Douglas were astonishing: Douglas brilliantly combines free-music's looseness with bop trumpet's discipline, and he was contributing to a remarkable exposition of jazz at the limits. The music changed pace and shape so quickly that he took to playing out of the corner of his mouth so he could watch his mercurial partner at the same time.

Balancing chaos and order has long been Zorn's mission, and fans of his hellraising free-style might find his enthusiasm for strict rules contradictory. But he has always been prepared to alternate the worlds of "out" and "in" music, and this concert showed how creatively the two can come together. You would have to be a pretty strict improv-purist to insist it is nothing but a compromise to both.

fields.headline: Consultants parachuted in to NatWest
fields.trailText: NatWest has parachuted in management consultants Boston Consulting to shake up its sluggish retail operation as it attempts to escape the clutches of its Scottish predators.
fields.body:
NatWest has parachuted in management consultants Boston Consulting to shake up its sluggish retail operation as it attempts to escape the clutches of its Scottish predators.

Gordon Pell, lured from Lloyds TSB to run NatWest's retail and corporate bank, has told Boston to work with the management team to devise a "14-day plan" to re-energise it. The retail bank has grown at only 1.6% per annum over the last two years.

Mr Pell, who predicted yesterday that a standalone NatWest would soon take part in fresh consolidation said he expected to bring in people from outside if the bank retains its independence after the Valentine's day deadline for the four-month battle.

Investors are not expected to decide whether to back NatWest's new management team or one of the competing bids by Royal Bank of Scotland or Bank of Scotland until they see any higher offers from the banks. Their offers both stand at about £22bn. The Scots are expected to play a guessing game with each other in the run-up to the Monday deadline for them to raise their bids.

Royal Bank, which is widely expected to call on the fire-power of its Spanish shareholder BSCH to raise its offer, will today highlight its profitablilty since its September year-end when it reported a 21% rise in profits to £1.2bn.

Mr Pell, who officially takes up his new role at NatWest in February, insisted that any "new blood" brought in would not be a fresh layer of management. Provided the bank retains its independence, he intends to simplify the bonus structure of the bank's branch staff. NatWest is shedding 15,000 staff and selling non-core businesses as part of its defence against the bids.

Mr Pell said: "Shareholders will be much better off if we survive, come through at a full value and participate in consolidation [later]."

Mr Pell, who predicted yesterday that a standalone NatWest would soon take part in fresh consolidation said he expected to bring in people from outside if the bank retains its independence after the Valentine's day deadline for the four-month battle. Investors are not expected to decide whether to back NatWest's new management team or one of the competing bids by Royal Bank of Scotland or Bank of Scotland until they see any higher offers from the banks. Their offers both stand at about £22bn. The Scots are expected to play a guessing game with each other in the run-up to the Monday deadline for them to raise their bids. Royal Bank, which is widely expected to call on the fire-power of its Spanish shareholder BSCH to raise its offer, will today highlight its profitablilty since its September year-end when it reported a 21% rise in profits to £1.2bn. Mr Pell, who officially takes up his new role at NatWest in February, insisted that any "new blood" brought in would not be a fresh layer of management. Provided the bank retains its independence, he intends to simplify the bonus structure of the bank's branch staff. NatWest is shedding 15,000 staff and selling non-core businesses as part of its defence against the bids. Mr Pell said: "Shareholders will be much better off if we survive, come through at a full value and participate in consolidation [later]."

webTitle: Holiday buying binge adds to threat of higher rates

fields.headline: Holiday buying binge adds to threat of higher rates
fields.trailText: Shoppers went on a combined Christmas and millennium binge last month, raising fears that the Bank of England will deliver another blow to homeowners next month in the form of higher interest rates.
fields.body:
Shoppers went on a combined Christmas and millennium binge last month, raising fears that the Bank of England will deliver another blow to homeowners next month in the form of higher interest rates.

Retail sales surged by 5.3% last year - their strongest annual rate for more than two years - following a 0.6% rise in December, according to the Office for National Statistics. Although analysts believe a further rate rise in February is now inevitable, many now think rates could peak at lower levels than the market had been expecting.

Yesterday's sales figures showed that despite robust demand, fierce competition is keeping the lid on price pressures. "With retail price inflation still subdued, sterling at such strong levels, and no convincing evidence that growth is still accelerating in any meaningful way, forecasts that rates will eventually move to 7% and above are beginning to look too pessimistic," said Jonathan Loynes, UK economist at HSBC markets.

The minutes of January's MPC meeting where the committee put up rates by 0.25%, published yesterday revealed that while all nine members favoured higher rates, there was little support a larger increase. Only one member, Willem Buiter, favoured a 0.50% rise.

"There are few signs that even the more hawkish members believe rates need to rise very aggressively from current levels," said Mr Loynes.

December sales appear to have been significantly boosted by partying over the millennium which pushed up food sales by 1.8%. But despite bouyant demand, retailers found it hard to make price rises stick. The sales deflator which measures how fast prices are falling, fell by 1.5% in the year to December. Economists are puzzled by the combination of robust demand and weak price presssures.

"A bouyant consumer market in which prices should be up and not down will get a few people scratching their heads," said Neil Parker, at the Royal Bank of Scotland. The Bank of England's governor, Eddie George, said in a speech last night that the debate over interest rates was finely balanced.

"The monetary policy debate is a narrow one," Mr George said. "It is about just how strong the growth, just how high the employment and just how low the rate of inflation. It is as good a prospect for the economy as a whole as we have known for some time."

He acknowledged that the strong pound was proving difficult for sectors of the economy exposed to international competition but reiterated that the Bank could not protect exporters by lowering rates to take the heat off sterling at the expense of letting inflation lose in the rest of the economy.

webTitle: I deserve a pay increase but I'm afraid to ask

fields.headline: I deserve a pay increase but I'm afraid to ask
fields.standfirst: What do you think? Have your say at the Talking shop
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I want a pay increase because I am doing more work than I was hired to do and have the results to show for it.

My problem is that my company has a salary increase scheme in place, plus I know my manager will say he has to keep the costs down.

What makes my request doubly difficult is that one of my colleagues has just handed in his notice because he got a better offer. I am worried that if I go ahead and ask for a salary increase, my boss will suspect I am planning to leave as well - which I am thinking about doing if I don't get an increase - but I need your advice on how to go about pleading my case without fear of organised removal (ie the sack).

I have been with the company for more than a year so I think it would be unfair dismissal if I were sacked.

The solution

If you ask for a deserved rise they might think you want out and sack you, but if you don't ask, you don't get. What a conundrum!

My advice would be to follow your friend's example and find another, better-paid post first.

Clearly, you have every right to ask for, and expect, a pay rise, but once your company says 'no', it is difficult for all concerned, since your superiors know you are not happy and, as you fear, may push you before you jump.

So, if you get a better offer lined up (and this should be perfectly possible, given your track record), you will then be able to ask for what you want, confident in the knowledge that if your request is refused, you have something in reserve.

Once you have your offer (and you may have to bide your time for a while), arrange a meeting with your manager. Prepare a report outlining the extra work you are doing (including a copy of your job description) and the results. If possible, include any savings or earnings you have made for the company. Use this evidence to justify your request for a reasonable rise.

Do not, at this stage, tell them about your better job offer since your manager might resent being 'threatened'. You could, however, point out your comparative market rate and the discrepancy between this and your current salary.

Presenting your case like this should make it hard for your manager to issue a point-blank refusal. What is more likely is that s/he will either agree to offer you something or else plead poverty and suggest you ask again in six months.

It will then be up to you to decide what to do (but remember that old saying about a bird in the hand).

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: Lenders to limit arrears chase
fields.trailText: The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) yesterday announced that its members will cease chasing loan arrears on repossession cases over six years old.
fields.body:
The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) yesterday announced that its members will cease chasing loan arrears on repossession cases over six years old.

Under the old system, cases up to 12 years old were being pursued leading to claims from the National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux (Nacab) that the problem had reached crisis point. Advisers at the bureaux were spending up to 25% of their working time helping those being hunted down by lenders, even where they had voluntarily surrendered the keys to their property.

The new voluntary code to be adopted by CML members will take effect from February 11. Anyone whose property was taken into possession and sold more than six years ago and has not already been contacted by their lender will not be asked to make up any shortfall. This will free many of those who became victims of negative equity in the 1980s when the property market dived.

The CML said the rule was introduced as a direct result of consultations with Nacab and the Federation of Independent Advice Centres.

Liz Phelps, a policy officer at Nacab, said it was delighted by the move but that it would still press for primary legislation to ensure equal treatment for all borrowers. "There will be some lenders who do not follow the CML line and there will be some lenders who are not members of the CML."

Nacab is also putting pressure on lenders to moderate their treatment of borrowers in arrears who have already been contacted.

fields.headline: Wake-up call for pension funds
fields.standfirst: Small, fleet of foot firms are outperforming the industry's traditional big players
fields.trailText: It may seem like a contradiction in terms, but the pensions industry is heading for dramatic times. This year heralds one of the most radical shake-ups ever experienced by the sector which has, until very recently, enjoyed a well deserved reputation for corporate somnambulance.
fields.body:
It may seem like a contradiction in terms, but the pensions industry is heading for dramatic times. This year heralds one of the most radical shake-ups ever experienced by the sector which has, until very recently, enjoyed a well deserved reputation for corporate somnambulance.

The latest league tables, published yesterday by the Combined Actuarial Performance Service, illustrate some of the issues now being grappled with by the companies trying to invest sufficiently successfully to ensure millions of workers can retire in some form of comfort.

The CAPS annual survey of pension fund managers showed all but one or two of the largest investment organisations were eclipsed by the performance of small, often newly formed organisations.

At the top of the performance league was Orbitex, with 1% of Mercury's assets under management, while Fuji-Lord Abbett - a joint venture between the Japanese Fuji Bank and independent American investment group Lord Abbett - came second.

Gartmore, the fund management business NatWest has put up for sale in its desperate attempt to escape the predatory assault of both Scottish banks, was the only one of the "big five" investment groups to make it into the top 10. Nicola Horlick, the so-called superwoman who so spectacularly quit Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, seems to be living up to her nickname by managing 12th ranking. The other end of the performance league table, however, is positively bursting with big names such as Phillips & Drew and Legal & General.

The results are by no means a one-off - the rise of the fleet of foot fund at the expense of behemoths has been a feature of the past three or four years.

Although Legal & General appears to have stumbled during the past 12 months, the previous success of its huge index tracker fund, which invests in proportion to the weighting of firms on the stock market, raised the spectre of whether active stock selection was about to become a thing of the past.

That debate was given added momentum when L&G became the first to declare itself happy to offer the government's stakeholder pensions at the proposed 1% commission.

The group argued that it could accommodate a fee seen in traditional terms as derisory because the costs of running an index tracking business are lower than its active equivalent.

But just as L&G seemed set to hoover up all the prospective work-place pensions business - the company also planned to cut costs by offering financial advice on a group rather than individual basis - the companies started to feel queazy about the implications of funnelling workers into the arms of a single pension provider.

One pension fund manager of a FTSE 100 company said : "When you look at all the problems there have been about private pensions mis-selling and then think about the rising trend to take legal action, then we have got to be careful not to be seen to be pushing people towards one investment firm or another."

His company is now considering establishing a panel of pension providers with a different risk profile so employees are offered a wider work-place choice.

But another FTSE100 pension fund manager - whose company intends simply to expand its scheme to meet the requirements of stakeholder pensions - says there is a real doubt that employees will want to sign up at all.

While some big organisations are now trying to find out how to encourage people to invest, others are increasingly worried that employees who are already members of their pension fund will try to take a pop at them if they fail to measure up to the ethical investment statement fund trustees must publish this summer.

The debate about where a fund's money is invested resurfaced last week, when it emerged that Phillips & Drew had put some of the Labour party's superannuation money into Huntingdon Life Sciences, a company which undertakes experiments on animals.

"I think this whole thing is a minefield," commented one pension fund manager who is also a trustee. "Clearly we want to try to invest in a socially responsible way, but we have a fiduciary duty to do the best for our pension fund members.

"I'm worried that we will produce an investment statement which will either be so vague as to be pretty meaningless or which could be a hostage to fortune and will lay us open to attack."

fields.headline: Pressure builds for tax cut
fields.standfirst: Report says chancellor must give away £2bn in budget 'just to stand still'
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will need to cut the equivalent of a penny off income tax in his budget to reduce Britain's tax burden and fend off the main Conservative attack on his handling of the economy, according to an influential report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will need to cut the equivalent of a penny off income tax in his budget to reduce Britain's tax burden and fend off the main Conservative attack on his handling of the economy, according to an influential report published yesterday.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies and the investment bank Goldman Sachs said the chancellor would need to give away £2bn in the March budget just to hold the tax burden steady - and £3bn to put it on a downward trend. With the chancellor highly sensitive to charges from the opposition that taxes have gone up under Labour, the IFS and Goldman Sachs said that the government would have to use some of Mr Brown's burgeoning war chest to offset so-called fiscal drag - where rising incomes automatically push people into higher tax brackets and increase state revenues.

The Conservatives have been pressing Mr Brown to admit that the tough action taken in Labour's first two budgets has resulted in a rising tax burden since the Blair government came to power in May 1997. Yesterday's report said that taxes had risen under Labour, with the £3.5bn reduction in last year's budget and November's pre-budget report dwarfed by the £11bn increase in previous budgets.

Income tax is coming down by a penny in the pound this April to soften the blow from the abolition of mortgage tax relief and the scrapping of the married couples allowance. Labour has made no specific commitment on the share of national income accounted for by taxes, but the prime minister is thought to be keen to keep the government's middle-class supporters happy in the run-up to the next general election, expected to be in the summer of next year.

The report, called the "green budget", predicted that the government was in the enviable position of being able both to cut taxes and respond to demands for higher public spending from its core supporters. In addition, Mr Brown will be able to meet his stringent rules for borrowing and help the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to keep the lid on interest rates.

The IFS and Goldman Sachs estimate that even after cutting taxes, the impact of falling unemployment and faster economic growth will give Mr Brown an extra £19bn to distribute in the next three-year spending review due to be unveiled in the summer. That would enable Mr Brown to increase spending by 2.5% a year in real, inflation adjusted, terms, slightly more than in the current programme.

Within that total, he could give 5% more a year to the NHS but there is question mark about whether substantially higher increases are affordable without jeopardising other departmental budgets.

The IFS and Goldman Sachs estimate that the chancellor would have to spend 5.7% to take Britain's spending on health up to the simple European average of the 15 EU member states.

A treasury source said that forecasting the public finances was notoriously difficult, and that the average error per year was £11bn, more than enough to wipe out the surplus cash identified by the green budget. He added that in the light of the policy mistakes in the late 80s, the government would err on the side of caution.

fields.trailText: I'm a chef and understand the pressures of working in a busy kitchen. Sometimes you can't help getting stressed at other members of your team (especially the waiting staff) but I think it's a bit over the top for the chef to throw a cold pheasant. After all it wasn't the pheasant's fault for not being hot. I think the chef in question should go back to college and learn how to cook again.

webTitle: Stock market beset by stamp duty angst

fields.headline: Stock market beset by stamp duty angst
fields.standfirst: Something to shout about
fields.trailText: It happens once a year, and always around this time. Think of it as a strain of pre-budget tension. Various City financiers, having given up alcohol for January, come over all ratty towards the end of the month and start looking around for somebody or something to shout at.
fields.body:
It happens once a year, and always around this time. Think of it as a strain of pre-budget tension. Various City financiers, having given up alcohol for January, come over all ratty towards the end of the month and start looking around for somebody or something to shout at.

This year, once again, the target is stock market stamp duty - the 0.5% cut the government takes every time an investor buys a block of shares. It is said that Gavin Casey, chief executive of the stock exchange, has had his ear bent to such an extent that he has agreed to head a lobbying effort to have this obstacle to efficient markets removed.

Apparently there is an intense danger of investment business deserting these shores - the argument being that since technological advancement has sent transatlantic dealing costs tumbling, we now face the prospect of hordes of private investors trading in the American depository receipt, or ADR, versions of UK firms rather than in regular London-listed shares to avoid stamp duty.

ADRs were created long ago in New York to get around the old Glass Stegal rules preventing Americans buying shares in nasty foreign firms. They are cumbersome things involving special taxes, and are only really used by American institutions such as pension funds.

It is doubtful that many British retail investors pay much attention to the small cost at the bottom of their hopelessly complicated trading statements. There is little chance of them deciding to trade simply to avoid stamp duty. At a professional level, the big players with offshore trading arms have been avoiding the tax for years using the mechanism of "contracts for difference" - effectively synthetic shares. Any investor can, of course, use one of the growing number of financial bookmakers where, famously, the winnings are tax-free and so are the losses.

That said, Britain's stamp duty remains the highest in the world, and is a real impediment to creating a vibrant pan-European stock market.

Meeting the last government's promise in 1992 to scrap the tax now would amount to a big, bright signal from this government that it does understand why the stock market exists and how important it is to business and the UK's standing internationally.

Yet the tax brought £2bn to the treasury's coffers in the year to last April, and the figure for the current year has probably all but doubled, given the outbreak of crazy punting by the public. This is why there is no chance of stamp duty disappearing in the short term.

Setting Labour's funding plans aside, the mere idea of giving the stock market an adrenaline shot in its present state would appear positively Lawsonesque.

Decline and fall

Rarely in the history of corporate mergers has so much shareholder value been destroyed by so few so quickly. The decline and fall of Somerfield since it merged with Kwik-Save has been brief and, for investors, extremely painful. Sales and profits plummeted as the entire basis of the takeover proved riddled with errors, with the shares collapsing at one stage from 494p to 58p.

Last November chief executive David Simons, whose vision landed Somerfield in this situation, announced a new idea - to get rid of half the Kwik-Save stores for which he paid so handsomely but which were now dragging down the rest of the company, sell off up to 144 of Somerfield's biggest supermarkets and concentrate on becoming the finest convenience store group.

Three months on, and 45 big stores have been sold - well actually, 19 have been sold and Somerfield has options to sell the other 26. But four in 10 of the big stores have been withdrawn because no buyer is willing to pay the fancy prices demanded. Ultimately, the company conceded yesterday, if the bids being made are not good enough it could be left with seven out of 10 of the big stores it said it wanted to get rid of.

Meanwhile there is no sign of a buyer for the burdensome 400-strong Kwik-Save estate, and now the company concedes that it will not raise enough to cover its £200m book value.

Three months ago Mr Simons admitted: "I would be foolish if I did not recognise that there has been a loss of management credibility", and yesterday he conceded that at least some of the supermarket chain's problems were "internally created".

Various City financiers, having given up alcohol for January, come over all ratty towards the end of the month and start looking around for somebody or something to shout at. This year, once again, the target is stock market stamp duty - the 0.5% cut the government takes every time an investor buys a block of shares. It is said that Gavin Casey, chief executive of the stock exchange, has had his ear bent to such an extent that he has agreed to head a lobbying effort to have this obstacle to efficient markets removed. fields.headline: Northern Rock's £150m buy-back
fields.trailText: Northern Rock is to boost its flagging shares by starting a £150m buy-back programme and embarking on a charm offensive of American and European investors.
fields.body:
Northern Rock is to boost its flagging shares by starting a £150m buy-back programme and embarking on a charm offensive of American and European investors.

The former building society, which yesterday reported a 6% rise in pre-tax profits to £230m, also plans to "securitise" £5bn of its mortgages over the next three years, £1.5bn of which will take place this year.

It securitised £600m of its mortgages - repackaging them and selling them to professional investors - last year, allowing it to use the proceeds to offer cheaper products or fund other projects.

The bank, which floated on the stock market in October 1997 at 470p, has watched its shares underperform its rivals recently; yesterday they closed at 315p, down 1p. Bob Bennett, the finance director, said: "We don't believe the current share price [correctly] values the franchise we possess."

He acknowledged that the bank might lose out because it is outside the FTSE 100 share index but hoped the buy-back of 10% of its shares would help shareholder value.

He said the bank, which issued debt in the US and Europe last year, would register with US regulators this year to make it easier to sell debt and equity there, and open an offshore operation in the Bahamas.

The bank said that competition pressures had eased off during the second half. It will pay a total dividend for the year of 13.6p, up 13%.

webTitle: Somerfield gives up on selling its stores

fields.headline: Somerfield gives up on selling its stores
fields.trailText: Somerfield, the supermarket chain planning to reinvent itself as a convenience store operation, has taken 57 of its large stores off the market after failing to get the prices it was demanding.
fields.body:
Somerfield, the supermarket chain planning to reinvent itself as a convenience store operation, has taken 57 of its large stores off the market after failing to get the prices it was demanding.

Last November, Somerfield's chief executive, David Simons, spelled out a plan to refocus on the convenience store sector. As a result the company put 144 of its large format supermarkets up for sale.

But yesterday - as the group announced dismal trading figures and a slump in profits - it revealed it had agreed deals to sell just 45 outlets, for £305m, and that it was to keep 57 stores which failed to attract high enough bids. A further 42 stores remain up for sale.

Yesterday, however, Somerfield - which had the dubious accolade of being the second worst performer in the FTSE-250 index last year - insisted that things were still proceeding according to plan.

The group is having no more success in selling off the 350 Kwik-Save stores which are similarly up for sale. Negotiations are under way but there is unlikely to be an announcement for two or three months, said Somerfield's finance director, Martin Gatto.

Somerfield shareholders have had a rough ride ever since the company agreed the £1bn merger with Kwik-Save. It intended to convert the 800 discount grocery stores to the Somerfield fascia and sell far more fresh and high margin food.

But the plan backfired as value-conscious Kwik-Save shoppers took their custom elsewhere and sales collapsed.

There has been a series of profit warnings and the shares collapsed from 494p only 18 months ago to a low of 58p.

Yesterday Somerfield confirmed that its half-year profits had collapsed from £114m to £64m.

It slashed its dividend from 4p to 1p. In the first 10 weeks of the second half underlying sales are down a further 8.4%.

Mr Simons blamed a combination of tough market conditions and "internally created problems".

Nevertheless the shares rose 11p, or 17.8%, to close at 75p.

Analysts explained the increase on relief that Somerfield had made a statement without even more unexpected bad news on trading.

Some said that the shares had now reached rock bottom, but retail specialist Rowan Morgan at Teather & Greenwood insisted there was nothing to cheer about.

He said: "There is nothing in these figures which suggests the stock is anything other than a sell."

fields.headline: Possessed by Iago
fields.standfirst:
My Best Friend
Hampstead Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Behind Tamsin Oglesby's intriguing 90-minute play, commissioned by Birmingham Rep, lurks the shadow of Pinter's Old Times. But, even if the resemblances emphasise Pinter's technical mastery, Oglesby has written that relatively rare thing: a successful second play.
fields.body:
Behind Tamsin Oglesby's intriguing 90-minute play, commissioned by Birmingham Rep, lurks the shadow of Pinter's Old Times. But, even if the resemblances emphasise Pinter's technical mastery, Oglesby has written that relatively rare thing: a successful second play.

What separates her play from Pinter's is that her three characters are all women, old school friends shakily reunited in a French farmhouse. Em, married with two children, is seemingly the blandest of the three. Bee, her supposed best friend, is a childless, nervily brilliant logistics consultant. The unexpected guest, and catalyst amongst the pigeons, is the glamorous Chris, who was Bee's former schoolgirl tormentor and who claims to enjoy a superior intimacy with the hapless Em. What follows is a battle for ownership in which the past is not only resurrected but used as an instrument of power.

Memory is shown by Oglesby to be shifting and subjective. Bee has never forgotten, or forgiven, an incident in which she was buried alive by the sadistic Chris. For Chris, the episode was simply a collective childhood prank; what she principally recalls, and passionately envies, is Bee's gift for poetry. As Em Pinterishly observes, "we shared our past but that's not to say it's the same past."

Oglesby convincingly shows how old resentments are never buried - even if Bee was - and how adolescent female friendship, perhaps all friendship, is deeply equivocal. But, in an otherwise naturalistic play, it seems to me a mistake to give us intermittent glimpses of Bee's sub-conscious thoughts and desires. I was reminded of Groucho, parodying O'Neill's use of a similar device, crying "Pardon me while I have a strange interlude". And, in building Chris up into a destructive female Iago, Oglesby undermines the idea that she and Em could ever have enjoyed a clandestine intimacy. It makes for narrative tension but is implausible.

It remains, however, a tensely enjoyable play that shows how the present is always informed by the past. Anthony Clark's production has a gathering momentum and is exceptionally well-acted. Sara Crowe lends Chris a superficial ditziness and underlying malignity, while Eve Matheson's Bee is a high-flyer clearly full of unresolved hurts. But I was most taken with Teresa Banham as Em: she makes seeming ordina riness interesting and finally reveals a self-awareness denied to the other two. When the plays moves on to Birmingham, it will be joined by Peter Tinniswood's On the Whole it's Been Jolly Good, seen at Edinburgh and performed by Leslie Phillips. They will make an uncommonly strong double-bill.

 At Hampstead Theatre (0171-722 9301) until February 12. At The Door at Birmingham Rep (0121-236-4455) from February 17 to March 4
